Today I turn one year older ğŸ‚

Itâ€™s crazy how fast time moves. Over the years, Iâ€™ve learned, failed, grown, met incredible people, and taken on challenges I never imagined I would.

Feeling grateful for the journey so far (both personally and professionally) and excited for everything thatâ€™s still ahead.

Now, be honest...how old do you think I am? ğŸ˜‰ ğŸ˜‚

In January my phone always explodes with comp plan SOS calls.

â€œCan you sanity-check our plan?â€
â€œDoes this quota make sense?â€
â€œAre we missing something obvious?â€

These calls come every January.
From friends.
From customers.
From people at companies I donâ€™t even work with.

And itâ€™s not because theyâ€™re lazy or careless.

Itâ€™s the opposite.

They know compensation is strategic.
They know it shapes behavior, cost of sales, trust, and retention.
And they donâ€™t want to improvise it.

The real problem is simpler â€” and harder.

There is no public, trusted playbook for comp.

Most plans are confidential.
Highly context-specific.
Tied to a very particular GTM motion, maturity stage, and risk profile.

So you canâ€™t just copy â€œwhat others do.â€

Whatâ€™s left?

A few close-network conversations.
1:1 Zooms with people whoâ€™ve â€œseen some stuff.â€
And generic internet or AI answers that ignore nuance and context.

When leaders call, theyâ€™re not asking for perfection.

Theyâ€™re looking for someone whoâ€™s seen enough plans to say:
â€œYouâ€™re not crazy â€” this fits your motion.â€
Or:
â€œThis will blow up in three months.â€

They want a second opinion on a high-stakes decision â€” without flying blind on behavior, cost of sales, or fairness.

What still surprises me is this:

We have data for everything else.
Pipeline.
Forecasting.
Pricing.
Headcount.

But most comp plans are still designed via Zoom calls and spreadsheets.

No simulations.
No real trade-off visibility.
No system-level feedback loop.

If youâ€™re tweaking your 2026 comp plan right nowâ€¦

What are you using as your â€œsecond opinionâ€?
Data, tech â€” or just a few trusted phone calls?

Many teams finally simplify their comp modelâ€¦

And then stop halfway.

Because the finance brain beats the behaviour brain.

I recently spoke with a team that had escaped a jungle of manual calculations.
They landed on a clean, elegant model.

On paper, it was perfect.

In reality, it was built for safety, not motivation.

There was:
â€¢ No real upside
â€¢ No meaningful differentiation
â€¢ No moment where a rep thought,
â€œIf I crush this, it really matters.â€

The plan reduced errors.
It reduced risk.
But it also reduced ambition.

So I asked them one question:

â€œWhat behaviour would you be genuinely happy to overpay commissions on?â€

That question changes the entire conversation.

Because comp plans donâ€™t just pay outcomes.
They signal what the business wants more of.

If your model is optimised only for control,
donâ€™t be surprised when it produces flat behaviour.

If you realised your comp plan is â€œsafe but flatâ€,
what would you change first:
thresholds, tiers, or accelerators?

Sessions like this are a great reminder of why cross-team collaboration matters ğŸ’ª 

Together with our CS and Product teams, we spent time unpacking customer feedback, discussing real pain points, and shaping the improvements that will make the biggest impact on Remuner.

Listening first helps us build smarter.

How do you usually collect and prioritize customer feedback in your team? ğŸ¤”

I spoke to a design engineer for solar parks last week. They're optimizing solar and battery storage projects. Already have solid DSO relationships. Know their regions well. Still signed up for Engrate's Power Tariff API. Why? 



Because even when you understand the tariffs, the data is "overwhelming and hard to structure". This is the pattern we keep seeing. It's not about lack of knowledge. It's about the format. 

You can have great DSO contacts and deep regional expertise. But when you're trying to feed that information into optimization algorithms, spreadsheets and PDF tariff documents don't cut it.

Machine-readability changes everything. That's the shift. From knowing the information to having it in a format that lets you actually build with it.

Are you optimizing projects on tariff data you have to manually structure? Check out https://app.engrate.io/
#RenewableEnergy #EnergyStorage #SolarEnergy #BESS #EnergyTech #GridIntegration #Effektavgifter #PowerTariffs #Effekttariffer

On the surface, this looks like just another list of startups, mainly AI. The world is full of them.

But when you look a little deeper, the Swedish story goes beyond flashy breakthrough models. It is about smart and precise entry into real industries.

If you look at Endra, you see the difference immediately. They are going deep into MEP design in construction, which is a traditional, highly regulated and complex field. Instead of building something on top of the market, they are embedding themselves inside Revit and within the actual engineering workflow. That is real vertical AI, not a decorative layer.

Or Engrate in energy. On the surface, it sounds like just another API. But the Swedish energy market is fragmented and data heavy. The ability to aggregate data across transmission points and make it usable for smart applications is infrastructure thinking, not just an app.

Even companies like Dentio or Vetnio (YC W25) are not simply chatbots for doctors. They are integrating into clinical workflows, documentation, compliance and privacy. When you build correctly within GDPR and a strict European regulatory environment, you are building a foundation that can scale globally.

And maybe what is most interesting is the speed. Companies founded in 2024 or 2025 already have products and integrations. That tells you something about an ecosystem that can move from a focused idea to an industrial solution very quickly.

So yes, each company on its own might not look like a sparkly revolution.

But as a pattern, it is a different story.

Sweden is building AI that is embedded deep inside the real economy.

Not another abstract tech vision.

But practical, vertical infrastructure with clear business value.

And to me, that is far more interesting.

In this talk with pioneering energy tech CTOs at Netlight in Stockholm (thanks for hosting, Johan Hagert Oldgren!), I had the privilege to discuss how we enable agentic development of our energy future, and what we can do already today to solve the integration landscape and, ultimately, have machines do the work for us.

It was absolutely amazing to see Gustav StÃ¥l, in his 15-minute demo, one-prompt an Energy Management System optimizing a battery, pulling knowledge, integration logic and data from the Engrate MCP Server to instruct his agent to build something for a very complex scenario: battery optimization based on real tariffs across all of Sweden with real-time cost savings.

Great example of how different roles and organisations struggle with the same problem - understanding how grid tariffs affect their business.

Power tariffs change the game for everyone.

The goal is clear: reduce the load and congestion of the grids and thus avoid billions in infrastructure upgrades. The challenge? Complexity just multiplied by 2400 (the number of power tariffs that we cover today).
In sweden, all 170 DSOs are implementing power tariffs differently, even across their own tariffs. Different peak windows. Different pricing structures. Different time-of-use periods. For anyone building flexibility and optimization services in Sweden, this isn't just a regulatory change. It's a fundamental shift in how energy pricing works.

Are you ready for 2400 different power tariff models across Sweden? To optimze for all of them using a singel model, try Engrates power tariff product for free. https://lnkd.in/dPmrUicJ

Changing human behavior takes years. Programming a machine takes minutes. For the energy transition to accelerate we need machines to understand the complex landscape of grid tariffs.

Meet DSO Connect, our latest addition for all DSOs to publish API-ready, machine-readable, and deterministic tariffs. Ultimately allowing machines to properly respond to price incentives without delay.

Are you a DSO looking to level up your API game and verify your tariffs for machine-readability?

Learn more and create an Engrate DSO account:
https://lnkd.in/dypNThsM

I am extremely excited to start 2026 by welcoming Eddie Surtees as Business Development Director and Seamus Barnett as Website Developer to Build Concierge.

2026 is a big year for us. Our focus is on helping service businesses automate customer engagement and scale more efficiently - using AI to handle conversations, bookings and follow-ups seamlessly, all in one place.

Strengthening our commercial and digital capability is a key part of that plan, and Eddie and Seamus will play an important role as we continue to build and grow the platform.

As we light the Chanukah candles this year, weâ€™re reminded of the power of peace, warmth and light, especially when the world feels uncertain.

Our thoughts are with everyone impacted following the recent tragic events in both Manchester and Australia. At times like these, Chanukahâ€™s message feels especially important: that even in moments of darkness, light, unity and compassion must prevail.

From all of us at Build Concierge, we wish you and your loved ones a happy Chanukah, filled with peace, warmth and light.

Great to catch up today with my good friend and Build Concierge customer, Stephen O'Brien founder of S O'Brien Heating Solutions Limited, at our office.

It was brilliant to hear first-hand how much value Steve and his team are already getting from Build Concierge, and how the platform is helping modernise the way they handle sales, customer engagement and operations.

We also spent time looking ahead, discussing how AI is becoming fundamental to the future of the trades, but just as importantly how the real value comes from integrating great technology with great people. The best outcomes happen when AI removes friction and gives teams the space to focus on what humans do best.

The future of trades isnâ€™t AI or people - itâ€™s the two working seamlessly together, and itâ€™s great to be building that future alongside forward-thinking businesses like Steveâ€™s.

Delighted to welcome Robbie P. to Build Concierge as our Platform Lead, working closely with our CTO Matt Fisher. 

Robbie joins us to take ownership of the infrastructure that underpins our platform, making sure itâ€™s scalable, resilient, and ready for the pace weâ€™re moving at. This work is critical to how we support our customers as we continue to grow quickly.

Robbie brings strong experience as a Lead Developer, and weâ€™re excited to have him helping shape the technical foundations of Build Concierge.

Welcome aboard, Robbie!

Last night we celebrated our Winter Celebration, and it was fantastic to get together as a team and take a moment to appreciate how far weâ€™ve come.

Itâ€™s hard to believe that not long ago it was just Martin Port and I, sat in a WeWork with an idea and a huge amount of belief. We launched, we learned, we adjusted, and ultimately we pivoted into the business Build Concierge is today.

Fast forward to today and weâ€™re now a team of 20 talented, dedicated professionals, all working hard to build an AI-powered platform thatâ€™s genuinely helping our customers transform the way they operate. Seeing businesses benefit from a solution that started as a simple idea makes every step of this journey worthwhile.

Last night was about celebrating that journey, but more importantly, celebrating the people behind it. Iâ€™m incredibly proud of the passion, resilience, and commitment shown across the whole team this year.

A huge congratulations to the whole team but especially our award winners Jack Pickering, Tazeen Tariq, Tirza Tariq, Saul Shapiro and Harry Smithurst!

At Build Concierge, we spend a lot of time talking about automation, AI and efficiency - making it easier for trades businesses to cut out the manual admin and focus on the work that actually matters.

But the more we grow, the clearer it becomes: the real value in any business still comes from its people.

Our system doesnâ€™t replace them, it gives them the space to be better at their jobs. When you remove the repetitive tasks, people suddenly have time to think, to solve problems, to look after customers properly, and to drive the business forward. Thatâ€™s where the real impact happens.

And itâ€™s exactly the same inside our own company. The progress weâ€™ve made isnâ€™t down to software alone - itâ€™s down to a group of people who care, who work hard, and who genuinely believe in what weâ€™re building.

Weâ€™re growing fast, and weâ€™re proud of how far weâ€™ve come. But more than anything, weâ€™re proud of the team thatâ€™s got us here, and the people our platform is helping every day.

I can usually tell in 10 minutes whether a new comp plan will fail.
And it has nothing to do with the formulas.

It happens in the rollout meeting.

Hereâ€™s what a plan that will work looks like.

The room is mostly quiet.
People nod.
Thereâ€™s visible relief.

The questions reps ask are about action and strategy:
â€œHow should I prioritize my pipeline?â€
â€œWhat do I need to do to hit the top tier?â€
â€œWhere should I focus my time?â€

You can almost hear it:
â€œFinally, this makes sense.â€

Now compare that to a plan that wonâ€™t work.

The meeting gets stuck in edge cases.
Micro-math.
Clarifications on basic mechanics.

â€œSo do I actually get paid on X?â€
â€œWhat happens if this deal slips?â€
â€œWait, how is this calculated again?â€

And the biggest red flag of all?

Managers leave saying:
â€œWeâ€™ll explain it laterâ€
â€œWeâ€™ll solve it on a case by caseâ€Â 
â€œWeâ€™ll decide it when it happensâ€

That sentence tells you everything.

This 10-minute test isnâ€™t about communication skills.
Itâ€™s a symptom of design quality.

When CRO, CFO, and CEO have aligned the plan around:
â€¢ strategy
â€¢ motivation
â€¢ financial logic

â€¦the explanation comes out naturally simple.

When the plan is a patchwork of compromises, assumptions, and last-minute fixes, the confusion shows up immediately.

Clarity and emotional buy-in at rollout are leading indicators.
Confusion and anxiety are lagging ones.

Whatâ€™s your own 10-minute test for knowing whether a comp plan will work?

Should I pay a 10% commission?

I get this question all the time.
And my honest answer is: I have no idea.

If you show me your commission rates before you show me your context, I have zero opinion.

This is the worst question I get: â€œIs 10% commission good?â€

With no context at all.

I have one non-negotiable before I touch any comp plan:

I refuse to judge percentages, splits, or accelerators until I understand how the business actually works.

Without context, any recommendation is just a smart-sounding guess.

At a minimum, I need to understand two things.

On the GTM side:
â€¢ Business model (i.e. SaaS, consumption based, GMV based, etc.)
 â€¢ACV and deal distribution
â€¢ Sales cycle length
â€¢ Sales channel (i.e. outbound, inbound, partner/indirect sales)
â€¢ Who owns renewals and expansion
â€¢ Role structure (hunters, farmers, hybrids)
â€¢ Mix of new vs existing revenue

On the business side:
â€¢ 2026 goals: growth, profitability, or both
â€¢ Margin realities
â€¢ How much risk leadership is genuinely willing to take
â€¢ What team behaviour from last year you want to keep (if any)
â€¢ Which one you want to change (if any)

Only then does â€œ10%â€ start to mean anything.

This is where most generic advice â€” and most templates â€” fall apart.

They jump straight to mechanics:
â†’ 50/50 vs 60/40
â†’ Tiers
â†’ Caps
â†’ Accelerators

All before understanding the story underneath.

Thatâ€™s how teams end up with beautiful plans on paperâ€¦
that are completely misaligned with how they actually sell.

Comp is downstream of context.
If your context changes and your plan doesnâ€™t, performance will.

Next time you ask anyone â€” including AI â€” for comp advice, try this:
Spend 80% of your message on context and 20% on the question.

Youâ€™ll be surprised how different the answer is.

How much context did you really give when you designed your 2026 comp plan?

Forget the â€œgarage startupâ€ clichÃ©.

Not thinking about â€œscalingâ€ or â€œfundraisingâ€.
Just obsessed with one question:

How do you design compensation that actually works in the real world?

This room forced us to stay close.

Everything Remuner is today started right here.

Yesterday I had the pleasure of joining KPMG EspaÃ±a in Barcelona for the first session of the Ready to Scale series.

We talked about something founders often underestimate until itâ€™s too late:
how early decisions around structure, tax, and incentives quietly shape your ability to scale.

A few reflections Iâ€™m taking away from the panel:

â€¢ scaling isnâ€™t just about growth. Itâ€™s about designing the company so growth doesnâ€™t break you later
â€¢ equity, incentives, and compensation plans are strategic tools, not just HR or legal topics
â€¢ getting the right advice early is almost always cheaper than fixing things post-Series A (or pre-exit)

Great discussion alongside David Alonso Martinez, CEO ofÂ Zinco, Xavi Pont Martin, co-founder and chairman of FundaciÃ³n Ship2B and managing partner at Ship2B Ventures and the KPMG team who made it happen.

And most importantly: a very engaged room asking the right questions â€” the ones that usually come right before things get complex.

For founders reading this: whatâ€™s one structural decision you wish you had made earlier in your startup journey?

Telling your team â€œweâ€™re making bets this yearâ€ doesnâ€™t have to scare them â€” if youâ€™re clear about where the bets stop.

In our first all-hands of 2026, we did two things at once.

We set an ambitious direction for the year.
And we openly named our big â€œbetsâ€ â€” the areas with real unknowns.

New motions.
New priorities.
Things we believe in, but donâ€™t yet fully control.

The key part?
We called them bets instead of selling them as certainties.

People can handle uncertainty when youâ€™re honest about it.

But thereâ€™s one area where we donâ€™t bet: compensation.

We keep comp transparent and predictable.
We avoid anchoring pay to untested assumptions.
And weâ€™re explicit upfront: if reality shifts, weâ€™ll adjust the plan â€” not pretend the original model was flawless.

That line matters more than most leaders realize.

It keeps ambition high.
But it also keeps people grounded.

Reps know exactly whatâ€™s expected of them.
They know how theyâ€™ll be measured.
And they know the difference between:

â€œWeâ€™re betting on this motionâ€
and
â€œYour paycheck depends on a guess.â€

Your team can handle bets.
What they canâ€™t handle is pretending everything is certain while tying their income to leadershipâ€™s guesses.

Do your people know which parts of your 2026 plan are proven â€” and which ones are bets?

If a rep canâ€™t explain their comp plan to their grandma after three gin-tonics, the plan is too complex.

This doesnâ€™t mean reps need to calculate exact payouts in their head.

It means they must understand the logic:

â€¢ Who gets paid
â€¢ For what
â€¢ And why

I see two very different worlds.

World A:
Reps guess.
They build shadow spreadsheets.
They argue about edge cases.

World B:
Reps understand the rules.
They check real numbers in seconds.
They trust the system.

Complexity doesnâ€™t make plans more â€œaccurateâ€.

It makes variable comp feel fixed.
And fixed pay doesnâ€™t drive behaviour.

Would your team pass the gin-tonic test today?
If not, whatâ€™s the first rule youâ€™d remove?

My main takeaway was simple:
building a company is more about staying alive and making decent decisions than getting everything right.

Whatâ€™s been the hardest thing to sustain for you as a founder?

The real AI revolution in sales isnâ€™t bots closing deals.

Itâ€™s co-pilots that make good sellers 2â€“3x more effective.

Not by replacing them.
By removing friction.

Think:
â†’ Deeper meeting prep, not generic discovery

judgement, negotiation, and trust.

And this creates a comp problem most teams are ignoring.

If your 2026 plan still pays mostly for:

The best plans I see starting to emerge reward:

If your comp plan hasnâ€™t evolved with AI yet,

â€No commissions, no problem.â€

Thatâ€™s what a sales leader texted me recently.
What stood out wasnâ€™t the statement itself.

It was the relief behind it.

This wasnâ€™t someone ideologically opposed to incentives.
He understands how powerful variable comp can be.

But after years of living with commissions, he was tired.

Tired of over-engineered plans with endless exceptions.
Tired of Excel chaos and manual reconciliations.
Tired of month-end tribunals between Sales, Finance, and HR.
Tired of reps feeling things were unfair or opaque â€” even when everyone had good intentions.

So he did the one thing that guaranteed peace.

In that moment, â€œno commissionsâ€ wasnâ€™t a strategy.

Hereâ€™s the uncomfortable truth:

The enemy isnâ€™t variable compensation.
Itâ€™s how we usually implement it.

â†’ Over-complicated rules.
â†’ Spreadsheet-based processes.
â†’ Poor communication.
â†’ And zero trust in the numbers.

All of that drains time.
And even more importantly, it drains emotional energy.

But thereâ€™s a hidden trade-off in killing commissions.

And when markets get tougher, youâ€™ve removed one of your highest-impact growth tools.

Long-term cost.

Thereâ€™s another path most teams never get to.

â†’ Simple, aligned rules that connect company goals to what gets rewarded.
â†’ Transparent plans reps can actually explain to each other.
â†’ And a trusted system that automates calculations â€” so Sales, Finance, and HR stop fighting the spreadsheet.

So if youâ€™ve ever felt tempted to say â€œno commissions, no problemâ€â€¦

Do you really think incentives donâ€™t work â€”

â€¢ data cleaning

â€¢ reporting

the value shifts.

to designing systems.

The best RevOps leaders donâ€™t think in dashboards.

Marketing â†’ SDR â†’ AE â†’ CS â†’ AM

And more importantly, they think in second-order effects:

â€¢ what happens to CS when quotas change?
â€¢ what breaks when routing is â€œoptimizedâ€?

One of the most underrated parts of onboarding?

Most 2026 quotas for new BUs and new markets are polite fiction written in spreadsheets.

Treating a new motion like a mature one.

Same â€œindustry standardsâ€.

Year one is not about perfect attainment.

Itâ€™s about learning velocity and behaviour.

A more honest approach for new motions:

1ï¸âƒ£ Declare assumptions explicitly

2ï¸âƒ£ Shorten quota cycles

3ï¸âƒ£ Overweight leading indicators
Activity indicators, pipeline quality, deal progression, ICP fit.

4ï¸âƒ£ Pre-schedule a Q1/Q2 recalibration
Not as a failure. As part of the design.

If the motion is new, pretending the quota is â€œrealâ€ can be more dangerous than missing it.

So whatâ€™s worse in your experience:

Under-attainmentâ€¦ or a quota nobody actually believes in?

Money drives behaviour. Full stop.

Every compensation plan either accepts that reality
or fights it.

And the plan never wins.

When 30â€“60% of someoneâ€™s pay is variable, youâ€™re not â€œincentivisingâ€.
Youâ€™re programming behaviour.

Every line in the plan sends a signal:

â†’ Caps donâ€™t control cost. They push deals into next quarter.
â†’ Accelerators donâ€™t â€œreward excellenceâ€. They pull deals forward at any cost.
â†’ Clawbacks donâ€™t protect the company. They change risk appetite.
â†’ Exceptions donâ€™t solve edge cases. They create shadow rules.

Yet I still hear leaders say:
â€œReps wonâ€™t optimise for that.â€

They will.
They always do.

Not because theyâ€™re bad actors.
Because theyâ€™re rational.

I see the same patterns over and over:

â†’ Activity bonuses inflate noise, not revenue
â†’ Opaque rules create shadow spreadsheets and permanent distrust
â†’ Artificial caps turn top performers into expert time-managers
â†’ Overlapping metrics create internal trade-offs no one intended
â†’ â€œTemporaryâ€ SPIFFs quietly become the real comp plan

Then leadership is surprised when behaviour drifts.

â€œWe wanted quality, but we got volume.â€
â€œWe wanted long-term value, but we got quarter-end games.â€
â€œWe wanted collaboration, but we got optimisation.â€

None of that is a sales problem.

Itâ€™s a design problem.

Leaders say money drives behaviour.
Then design plans as if it doesnâ€™t.

A simple test I like to use:

If someone studied your comp plan with zero context,
no culture deck,
no values slide,
no leadership speechesâ€¦

What behaviours would they assume you actually want?

And are those the behaviours youâ€™d be happy to scale?

4 months ago, we closed our â‚¬5,5M seed round.

Here's the one thing I told every founder who asked for advice:

Choose your investors like you choose your co-founders.

Most founders donâ€™t realize this early on:
your investors are part of the team.

Theyâ€™re not in the office every day.
Theyâ€™re not in Slack or sitting in pipeline reviews.

But they own a piece of what youâ€™re building.

They influence decisions.
And youâ€™re going to be working side-by-side with them for the next 10 years.

So when we raised â‚¬5,5M for Remuner, I approached it differently than I had in my 20s.

Hereâ€™s how I thought about it:

1. Investors I already knew

Some came from previous companies.
Iâ€™d seen them in real situations:

- Board calls when we missed revenue
- Restructuring moments nobody enjoys
- Tough conversations where things werenâ€™t going our way

That experienced mattered above everything.

It showed me how they behaved when things were hard, not just when things were exciting.

2. Investors I met while building

Others I met at events, grabbed coffees with, and stayed in touch with over years.

No pitch. No ask. Just great conversations.

And you learn a lot from that:

- Who follows up
- Who you never hear from again
- Who sends something helpful out of nowhere
- Who only shows interest when things look shiny

Early behaviour always repeats later.

3. New investors we didnâ€™t know yet

For them, we went deep on references.
Not the curated ones they want you to call.
I reached out to founders who had them on their cap table.

I only asked two questions:

1ï¸âƒ£ Would you let them invest again?
2ï¸âƒ£ Tell me a moment when things went badly - how did they behave?

That second question helps you make your decision.

Anyone is supportive when you're growing fast.
The real test is who they are when youâ€™re not.

What I was looking for: Alignment.

Not on metrics or pricing or growth rates, because those change every year.

I looked for alignment on:

- How we treat people
- How we think about long-term value
- How we make decisions under pressure
- How patient they are with the messy middle

Thatâ€™s is what the next decade looks like.

The lesson above everything:

You donâ€™t just raise capital.
You choose who youâ€™re going to build with.

So my advise is to picture the hardest moment of your next 10 years -
team burnout, a missed quarter, a tough strategic call.

Now imagine that investor sitting across from you.

Do you want them in that room?
Or would they make that moment harder?

That answer is your decision.

How do you vet your investors?

Our research shows that in high-complexity enterprise deals, decisions do not move because of more activity or stronger persuasion. They move only when three internal conditions inside the buying organisation are in place.

We call these The Three Gates of Complex Buying:

Gate 1: Recognition
Stakeholders must understand who you are and where you fit. This is supported by research on how people categorise and interpret new information.

Gate 2: Relevance
Stakeholders must see that your solution genuinely fits their world. This is supported by research on similarity, social proof and how people judge applicability.

Gate 3: Safety
Critical roles must feel the decision is acceptable and low risk. This is supported by research on how organisations perceive risk, loss and uncertainty.

When all three gates are open, decisions move.
When even one gate is closed, they freeze, no matter how strong the business case is.

I have written a longer article that explains the model in more detail and shows the research domains behind it. Comment or message me if you want a copy.

Ideas. Courage. Imagination.

This weekâ€™s theme centres on building something meaningful.

Not imposed.
Not demanded.
But created through voluntary contribution.

The vision is clear: build a structure that represents purpose, values and shared responsibility. The starting point is unusual. It begins not with materials or measurements, but with willingness.

Take contributions from those who genuinely want to give.

Great things are not built through obligation alone. They are built when people choose to participate.

Ideas

Before construction begins, there is vision. Clarity of design. Precision of detail. Intentionality in every dimension.

Strong ideas come first. Without them, activity becomes noise.

Courage

Building something that lasts requires discipline.
Standards must be upheld. Details must matter.

Courage is committing to excellence even when compromise would be easier.

Imagination

The real lesson is not about a building. It is about creating an environment where meaning, trust and shared purpose can exist.

Imagination turns materials into significance. It transforms resources into impact.

Leadership is not only about solving problems.
It is about designing spaces where people can thrive.

Ideas define direction.
Courage maintains standards.
Imagination brings vision to life.

Mark Rogerson MBE 

I agree. For established enterprise software businesses, the reality has always been the same: innovate or decline. Private equity can bring capital, focus and operational discipline, but sustained value creation still comes down to product relevance, continuous innovation and customer success.

What has changed is the acceleration driven by AI. The opportunity is enormous, but so is the responsibility. In enterprise environments, the biggest risks remain security, accountability and reliability. These are not abstract concerns. They sit at the core of customer trust.

My view is simple: if AI generates code, a human is still accountable for it. Even if something else has written it, someone must read it, understand it and take responsibility for it. That is not a technical limitation. It is a governance and safety requirement.

Enterprise software buyers still buy from people they trust. Relationships matter. Reputation matters. And accountability matters even more in an AI enabled world.

The businesses that win will be those that combine:
â€¢ Continuous innovation
â€¢ Rigorous oversight
â€¢ Strong customer relationships
â€¢ Clear ownership of outcomes

Speed without control creates risk. Control without innovation creates stagnation. The balance is where long term value is built.

Consistency in values builds trust.

Leaders earn respect by doing whatâ€™s right, especially when no one is watching.

Wishing everyone a peaceful and enjoyable weekend.

Thank you to Nieve Higgins for taking both Andrew S. and myself around Kibbutz Beâ€™eri today.

It was an incredibly powerful and deeply sobering experience. In all likelihood, it will be the last time we see these buildings as they are the homes that stood for the past two years as silent witnesses to the murders and the hostages taken on October 7th 2023.

Walking through these spaces, seeing the photographs, the names, the remains of ordinary lives destroyed, brings home the scale of the atrocity committed by Hamas. 

These were not symbols or abstractions. These were people. Families. Homes.
We must never forget what happened on October 7th.

And we must also never forget what followed from October 8th onwards the hate marches across Europe and around the world, falsely branded as â€œpro-Palestinian,â€ but so often revealing themselves as something far darker: open antisemitism, disconnected from peace, disconnected from humanity, and disconnected from truth.

Memory matters. 

Bearing witness matters. And silence is not an option.

Thank you again, Nieve, for guiding us through such a difficult but necessary place of remembrance.

The Behavioural Constraint Line!

There is a line in every enterprise market where the rules of physics change.

Below the Behavioural Constraint Line, traditional economics apply. Buyers evaluate value, price, and features. If your product is better, you win.

Above the line, the logic inverts. Decisions stop behaving like commercial choices and start behaving like risk decisions.

Above the line:
Value does not convert; Proof converts.

Persuasion fails; Defensibility wins.

The status quo isn't inertia; it's a defensibility strategy.

If you are selling above the line using below-the-line tactics (better demos, ROI calculators, feature comparisons), you aren't selling. You are just educating a market that is structurally unable to buy from you.

Risk bearing roles vs business benefitters, Assymetric risk, Interest market fit vs product market fit.

The EU is making a bold move to align public spending with climate goals.
Commission President von der Leyen just announced that the EU will introduce low-carbon requirements for public procurement â€” creating a powerful new incentive for clean industrial production.

The new rules, part of the upcoming Industrial Accelerator Act, would set minimum standards for low-carbon goods in public contracts, starting with sectors like batteries, solar and wind components, EVs, power cables, and charging infrastructure.

Why it matters: Public procurement accounts for roughly 14% of EU GDP. By embedding sustainability criteria into that spending, the EU is turning government purchasing into one of the largest demand signals for green manufacturing on the continent.

What to watch:
1. Steel and cement are strong candidates for early inclusion â€” sectors where scaling low-carbon production has been held back by cost gaps that demand-side policy can help close.
2. A broader procurement overhaul is expected in late 2026, with a labelling system for low-carbon industrial products starting with steel
Tangible effects will take time, but that also gives businesses a runway to adapt and invest

This is an exciting step toward using public investment as a catalyst for decarbonization and industrial innovation. The challenge now is in the execution â€” getting the criteria right, keeping timelines ambitious, and ensuring the transition is accessible for businesses of all sizes.

What do almost all B2B companies on the Fortune 500 list have in common?
They followed the same three steps to get there.

1. First, they landed smaller initial deals with large companies â€” getting a foot in the door.

2. Second, they expanded 10 to 100 of those accounts toward the full solution through disciplined deal orchestration. Not by selling harder, but by navigating complex buying centers systematically.

3. Third, they developed new offerings for their top clients and combined organic growth with strategic acquisitions â€” creating cross-sell momentum that compounds over time.

The pattern is remarkably consistent. The vast majority of B2B Fortune 500 companies generate over 80% of their revenue from fewer than 100 top accounts. A handful of exceptions exist â€” pharmaceutical distributors like McKesson, AmerisourceBergen, and Cardinal Health operate with a broader base â€” but they are exactly that: exceptions.

This pattern is why I wrote the Megadeals book. And it's why we founded Njord â€” the deal orchestration platform built to help companies execute steps two and three, where the real value is created and where most organisations struggle the most.

What does this insight mean for your company?

Stop selling "value" to people who are only worried about "blame."

In complex enterprise deals, we assume that if the ROI is strong enough, the deal will close. But the thinking on "Decidable Growth" by Jonas Lind at Njord highlights a critical flaw in that logic.

It introduces the concept of Risk-Bearing Roles.

These are the specific individualsâ€”in Legal, Security, Finance, Operationsâ€”who have to sign off on your deal. And for them, the math is different. They face Asymmetric Downside.

-> If the deal succeeds: The credit is shared. The organization moves on. 
-> If the deal fails: The blame is personal. It hits their credibility, their internal trust, and their career.

Under these conditions, it is rational for them to stop optimizing for value and start optimizing for defensibility.

They aren't asking: "Is this the best solution?" They are asking: "Will this still look reasonable when an auditor asks me why I signed?"

If your champion loves the product, but the CFO or CISO can't find a "defensible position" to protect themselves against future scrutiny, they won't say no. They will just issue a "soft veto":

"I cannot recommend this. If you decide to go ahead, it will be your decision."

And just like that, the deal dies.

The takeaway: In complexity 5 and 6 deals, you aren't selling upside. You are providing the safety required for a Risk-Bearing Role to say "yes" without risking their career.

Risk bearing roles is one of the reasons why the marketing and sales playbook for complexity 5 and 6 is different. Multithreaded, not following a sequential sales process and with other messaging.

#SalesStrategy #EnterpriseSales #RiskManagement #ComplexSales #B2B

One of the most consistent patterns we see is how win rates improve once companies begin using the Njord Deal Orchestration. 

The shift comes from giving stakeholders a clearer, more structured decision environment.

Njord starts by mapping the full stakeholder group, including the hidden influencers who shape how decisions move internally. This clarity allows teams to communicate more consistently and reduce the friction that often comes from misalignment or missed stakeholders.

With the stakeholder environment understood, the Njord solution creates coordinated visibility across all relevant individuals through multi-platform exposure (News sites, Instagram, Facebook, LinkedIn). When everyone involved encounters the same narrative, familiarity increases and internal traction strengthens. Buyers move with more confidence because information is consistent and reinforced across channels.

The result is a smoother experience for every stakeholder.
Confusion drops, decision paths become clearer, and organisations feel more certain about moving forward long before final discussions begin.

A better win rate is not created at the end of the funnel.
It is created by bringing clarity, consistency, and confidence to every part of the decision environment.

Why do sales people that claim that their key skill is relationship building less successful in B2B deal complexity 5 and 6?

In high-complexity B2B (often referred to as Complexity Level 5 & 6, involving large buying committees, consensus decision-making, and high strategic risk), "Relationship Builders" are statistically the least likely to be high performers.

Here is why relying on "Relationship Building" fails when complexity spikes:
1. They manage tension incorrectly (The "Friend Zone" Trap)
The Problem: Relationship builders prioritize reducing tension. They want the customer to feel comfortable and happy. They acquiesce to requests to keep the peace.

Why it fails in Complexity 5/6: To get a large organization to change its behavior (buy your solution), you need to create tension, not reduce it. You have to challenge their current thinking and show them that their status quo is dangerous. Relationship builders are often afraid to say "You are wrong" because they fear damaging the rapport, so the deal stalls in a state of "polite inaction."

2. They build bridges with the wrong people
The Problem: Relationship builders naturally gravitate toward people who are accessible, friendly, and have time to talk.

Why it fails in Complexity 5/6: In large enterprises, the people with time to chat are rarely the decision-makers. They are often "Talkers," not "Mobilizers." The Relationship Builder spends months having coffee with a manager who has no budget authority, thinking they are "working the account," while the real decision is being made in a closed-door C-suite meeting they weren't invited to.

3. They confuse "Support" with "Value"
The Problem: When a client asks for something, the Relationship Builder says, "I'll get that for you right away!" They act as a concierge.

Why it fails in Complexity 5/6: In complex sales, customers don't need a servant; they need a teacher. High-level executives (the C-Suite) don't buy from people who are just "helpful"; they buy from people who offer commercial insight that helps them compete better. If your value proposition is "I am responsive and nice," you are a commodity.

4. They cannot navigate Consensus Conflict
The Problem: In a committee of 6â€“10 stakeholders (Finance, Tech, User, Legal), there is always internal conflict. The CFO wants to cut costs; the CTO wants the best tech.

In high-complexity sales (Level 5â€“6), people buy from people who challenge and educate them on how to survive.

The Rainmaker wins because they build relationships based on respect and value, not just likability. They teach the client something new, tailor the message for resonance, and take control of the commercial conversation.

Energy storage is a system resource - and should be priced as one!

When flexibility is priced properly, long-duration energy storage becomes investable, scalable and bankable, exactly what the power system needs as it transitions from energy scarcity to system scarcity.

Mine Storage welcomes the new proposition and hopes to contribute to this category in the future.

Every apple you pick has been through something.

Thatâ€™s what I like about orchards. You see resilience in its purest form. But letâ€™s be honest â€” resilience doesnâ€™t mean simplicity.

Temperature swings. Soil moisture fluctuations. Disease pressure building quietly in the background. Small changes can have a big impact on quality and yield.

And you canâ€™t manage what you donâ€™t see.

Thatâ€™s why more growers are turning to sensing technologies. Not because tradition isnâ€™t enough â€” but because experience combined with real-time data is powerful. When you understand what your trees are actually going through, you can act before stress turns into loss.

This sequence shows a flower field on a late August in the South of Germany. And yes, you are allowed to enter it, you are officially invited to!

AcrossÂ Germany, youâ€™ll find something quietly remarkable: flower fields where anyone can walk in, cut their own bouquet (Selbstschneiden), and payâ€”often by dropping cash into a simple box. No cashier. No cameras. Just trust.

At first glance, this feels naÃ¯ve in a world obsessed with control and monitoring. But these fields work. Season after season.

Why? Because trust changes behavior. When people are treated as honest, many choose to act that way. The absence of friction creates a positive social contract:Â this is ours to take care of. Farmers reduce overhead, customers enjoy autonomy, and the community reinforces shared norms.

Of course, trust-based models arenâ€™t about ignoring riskâ€”theyâ€™re aboutÂ designing for responsibility instead of suspicion. Clear pricing, social visibility, and local embeddedness all play a role. But the core insight is powerful: not every problem needs a gatekeeper.

In times when businesses default to complexity, theÂ SelbstschneidenÂ fields remind us thatÂ simplicity plus trust can be a competitive advantage. Sometimes, the most resilient systems are the ones that assume the best in peopleâ€”and let them prove it. ğŸŒ»

And also from a business perspective quiet simple: Choose the right flowers, who match with the soil and climate - e.g. monitored by hexafarms sensors (and shown at IPM ESSEN next week) -, plant the flower bulbs, occasionally water them and voilÃ . ğŸŒ·

Fear of failure is rising.

In just 5 years, the proportion of people who didnâ€™t take advantage of a good business opportunity because they were scared of failure has increased to 49%. The belief that others demand perfection from us has risen 32% since 1989. 

Weâ€™ve all felt the pressure to be perfect, whether itâ€™s for ourselves or others. I think it might be holding us back from taking the risks that give us our biggest wins.

Moving countries 9 times, I grew up with failure often being a necessity of success. You have to try over and over before you manage to rebuild your whole life. 

I found that if you experiment enough, you get to the best answer and win. 

At a startup like Tracelight, you canâ€™t afford not to experiment. We tried 5 different acquisition channels before we found the 2 that worked. When youâ€™re up against companies worth over $300b, never settling until you find the best way is often the only way to succeed.

Something Iâ€™ve noticed in the startup world is the people who are winning big aren't the ones who stopped failing.Â They're the ones who stopped letting fear of failure drive their decisions. They focus less on perfection, and more on winning.

In a world where more people are afraid to take risks, thereâ€™s opportunity for those who will. Doesnâ€™t mean we should always take crazy risks - sometimes the safe way is the best bet.

But there is a change in mindset I noticed when I entered the startup world - from "what if I fail?" to "how do I find the best answer?". 

Iâ€™m still learning this myself, but perhaps that's all it takes to unlock things we never thought we could achieve.

Google released benchmark results for Gemini 3 Deep Think yesterday, and theyâ€™re extraordinary. Reasoning is being solved fast. If youâ€™re an analyst, what should you take from this?

Benchmarks are easily gamed, and models usually perform worse in real life than in contained test scenarios. 

But donâ€™t be in denial. Itâ€™s obvious where this is going.

You are about to lose your advantage to computers in reasoning. That sounds really really scary, I know. But you shouldnâ€™t be scared - you should be excited.
Machines have overtaken us on many other things in the past - and every single time we emerged better off for it. 

AI will complement you. Thereâ€™s a million things you can do that it canâ€™t. Your new ideas are better. You perceive more, you understand peopleâ€™s motivations, and you know how to work with others to achieve goals. You can influence the world in ways that models canâ€™t. And you are the economic decision-maker. 

The combination of you + AI is extraordinarily powerful - much more so than AI alone. At Tracelight we get a front-row seat on this. Our customers do daysâ€™ worth of financial modelling in hours, and then re-invest that time in delivering more value. 

What a time to be alive!

Precedent Tracing just got a big upgrade in Tracelight. Figuring out long chains of formulas across multiple tabs is now easy.

Weâ€™ve rebuilt this experience AI-first. You now get instant explanations of every formula, and you can toggle to see what every cell reference actually means. (â€˜RevenueBuildâ€™!AA623 --> â€˜2024 New Logosâ€™)

Increasingly, our usersâ€™ models are built primarily by AI. So giving you great interfaces to inspect those models is a top priority for us.

And, of course, you never have to touch the mouse.

We hope you love it.

At 1am last night, I couldnâ€™t sleep. I was brainstorming ideas, and wanted to work. Not because I felt stressed, but because I couldnâ€™t contain my excitement.

Over the past 6 months Iâ€™ve discovered something that makes a startup team great - and it surprised me. Hard work, insane learning pace, using AI right, and high agency are all critical, but they're not what I value most about working at a startup.

Itâ€™s having a team and a mission that inspires you. Once you have that, you stop wanting to sleep, and start wanting to do everything you can to build the future.

At 1am, our Head of Sales Ammar H. sent a message in Slack (screenshot below). He said he couldnâ€™t sleep either - and was unbelievably excited about what we were doing.

When you have a team with a shared vision, who are all thrilled beyond measure to build a massive company, everything becomes possible. Yesterday:

JoÃ£o Conrad stays late in the office helping me build a website case study / ads system

Aleksander Misztal reviews at 10pm while building a new feature in Tracelight.

Janek Zimoch gives feedback on case studies at almost midnight the same evening.

Ammar and I brainstorm ideas at 1am

When you have a team like that, you can win anything. Itâ€™s why weâ€™ve expanded offices 3 times in 6 months, and are now leading our space.

To be clear, this isnâ€™t about embracing extremes of hustle culture, a 9-9-6 schedule, or reducing your personality to work (I somehow find time to do other things, donâ€™t worry), itâ€™s about finding something that makes your work so exciting it feels like a fun sport you can play forever.

If youâ€™re the kind of person that thinks they can find something like that, you might want to check out a startup like Tracelight - we're (always) hiring.

Tracelight is hiring for a Technical GTM specialist. Iâ€™m biased of course, but I think itâ€™s the coolest job in the world for an ex-IB / consulting person with great client hands wanting to get into AI. Hereâ€™s why:

There is a once-in-a-generation change underway in these industries. Every firm knows AI is real now, and everyone is buying.

Realistically, a small number of companies will win. A handful of people within those companies will be responsible for building the AI products that power the next generation of this entire sector.

As part of Tracelightâ€™s technical GTM team, you would be one of the select group of people.

You will:
- Work with our customers to figure out which problems Tracelight should tackle next, and how
- Work alongside our amazing engineers to design and test those new features
- Figure out how our customers get value from Tracelight within their first minute using the product, so they see the power of AI, and change how they work
- Build our customersâ€™ workflows into Tracelight, so AI works specifically for them
- Onboard our customers, train them, and do whatever it takes to make Tracelight useful to them

Technical GTM is an emerging role in our industry. High-achieving ex-IB and consulting people with great client hands and the ability to solve problems from first principles will be exceptionally good at it.

If this sounds like you, please apply via our website, or tag a friend who would be interested.

When you hit 'Send' on a launch, you find out if your last month of work mattered. Last week, our Tracelight 1.0 launch went viral with 500,000 impressions across finance, consulting, and tech. 

This is the story of how it happened, and a few of the secrets to our success.

We gave back to our community on launch with a one-time Pro access offer, turning them into our biggest public champions. 

This contributed to 30% growth in our Pro tier within a matter of days. If you have thousands of users, activating their goodwill can be enormously impactful. You just need to get their attention and give them a reason to show up for you - whether that's token credits, beta access, or a genuine thank you. 

Thereâ€™s nothing worse than a viral launch moment with a leaky conversion funnel.

The week before, our incredible growth advisor James McAulay, our amazing Engineering team Aleksander Misztal JoÃ£o Conrad and I obsessively made dozens of small improvements to our website and funnel analytics.

Animated CTA buttons in a floating navigation bar, a Vision Statement, adding the launch video to our landing page, setting up conversion funnels in PostHog integrated with our product, and countless others. 

Together, these changes increased our conversion by 2x, making the launch itself around twice as effective.

Load your script with every psychological tool in your arsenal

One powerful example in our launch video is that our CEO Peter Fuller starts with - â€œWhat if you could reach a completely new level of performance in Excelâ€, and ends with â€œYou can get Tracelightâ€. 

Asking people a question about their attitude towards a positive target action massively increases the likelihood they follow through. One study by Prof. Greenwald at the University of Washington found that asking voters about voting a few weeks before an election increased turnout by over 25%!

When you're an early stage startup going up against the biggest behemoths in tech, you canâ€™t win by just playing bigger - you have to play smarter.

I just looked back at a post from June.

It was the first video of Tracelight writing a formula in a spreadsheet.

Six months later, we are building entire models for thousands of users and becoming the go-to choice for the biggest institutions in our space.

Building in AI is the journey of a lifetime. Looking at how far we've come since the summer makes me quite emotional. Or maybe I'm just tired after launching yesterday.

Back to work!

Introducing Tracelight 1.0
Six months in, and weâ€™re already live with 5 of the 10 biggest management consultancies in the world, as well as PE funds and asset managers with over $600B in AUM.

Tracelight is the best AI add-in to Excel. In testing against the leading alternative add-ins, Tracelight 1.0 was:

- The most accurate
- 2x faster building analysis on average
- 24x faster at finding human errors in complex spreadsheets

Weâ€™ve been building with early adopters and enterprise partners for months. You can now reach a completely new level of performance in Excel. Thatâ€™s why today weâ€™re proud to launch a major new version.

To celebrate, Iâ€™m giving 1 month of Tracelight Pro for free to professionals who comment LAUNCH below or TAG a friend who needs this.

Welcome Catherine Lavender to Tracelight as our new Chief of Staff!

Catâ€™s goal is to make our people, culture, and processes a lasting source of advantage.

She joins us from a background in Consulting and Private Equity. She knows our customers and the problems we are trying to solve inside-out.

We got a flood of applications for this role. But Cat stood out because of her drive, structure, and focus on people. We spoke to a lot of her ex-colleagues, and everyone only had phenomenal things to say about her performance and who she is as a person. It quickly became obvious to us that this was who we wanted to build our business with.

She has already had a big impact in her first couple of days...and has quickly optimised for peak startup performance by hitting the beanbags and wearing Uggs to the office.

Welcome Cat, we couldn't be more excited to build Tracelight with you.

Iâ€™m happy to share that Iâ€™m starting a new position as Chief of Staff at Tracelight!

Incredibly excited to join Peter Fuller, Janek Zimoch, Aleksander Misztal and the rest of the team. 

If you work in professional services / finance and havenâ€™t turned your 2 hour excel tasks into 20 minutes yet, then please reach out!

Pretty remarkable that over Christmas, our engineers:

- Built our own high-performance spreadsheet calculation engine in Rust
- Completely changed how Tracelight puts content in your sheet (you used to have to click Approve, you no longer have to)
- Improved formatting and sheet operations - Tracelight freezes panes, groups cells, does nice borders for you now
- Made the entire experience keyboard-navigable - I now barely touch the mouse when using the add-in

...all alongside the usual fixes and less visible improvements.

This isn't even a 'grindset' post - our team wasn't working the same hours as usual.

They're just focussed, and very good. And there were no meetings!

2026 is going to be one of the most exciting years ever in consulting and finance. Here are my predictions:

- Analyst workflows will change more this year than any year since the 1980s

- You are going to get AI tools that actually work; you will notice your jobs becoming higher-leverage

- There's going to be a lot more insight in Proposal documents. If you're not using AI to do a strong 'first pass' at the client's problem in the proposal phase, you will find yourself losing bids and market share. (For example, our customers often use Tracelight to comb through client-provided financials and generate deep insights at the proposal phase.)

- You will hear more about new business models. Consultancies and banks are using their internal knowledge to build AI-powered workflows that their clients can initiate whenever they want; this will of course lead to follow-up human advisory fees. Big moment for retention and scalability for the winners here. (It will take a while for this type of revenue to become truly significant.)

- Some private market funds will figure out how to compress deal timelines to a scary extent; they will win a lot of deals. The pace will be superhuman and they will need advisors who can match that. They will pay well for that.

Where am I wrong and what have I missed? Let me know what you think!

I recently saw an M&A deck from 2008. It was indistinguishable from the same bankâ€™s decks today. 17 years and no change. How could that be?

Same structure, same fonts, same charts. More than that - the whole M&A process seems to be frozen in time. For decades now, itâ€™s been a CIM, a financial model, the same valuation methodologies, etc

The easy take is to say bankers are just "stuck in their ways".

But I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s it. Investment bankers are some of the sharpest and most competitive people in the world. If there was a better way to win a mandate or close a deal, they would have found it.

The reality is that for a long time, the cost of innovation was simply too high. The risk of breaking a proven process with a new tool or approach was not worth it. The safest bet was the best bet.

But that risk calculation is changing.

The cost of experimentation is in free-fall. Products like NotebookLM or Lovable transform static presentations into interactive experiences in minutes. The classic CIM is looking more and more dated by the day.

And increasingly, AI is handling the grunt-work that used to fill analystâ€™s time. Tracelight users are taking core modelling workflows, like cleaning and presenting management financials in a professional format, and performing them with two keystrokes.

In my opinion the standard playbook is no longer the best bet. There is alpha on the table for the firms ready to change their process. The biggest risk now is missing that boat.

Introducing Change Reviews in Tracelight. You want AI to help build your financial model. But you also want to be sure that every change is correct. Hereâ€™s how we do it.

Any time Tracelight builds in your spreadsheet, it will now give you a list of every change you need to review. The list is designed to help you validate as efficiently as possible.

For example, if Tracelight has written a formula which is then dragged across or down, you only review it once. You can navigate to references in each formula with one keystroke or click. That means you can jump to precedents effortlessly, even if theyâ€™re on other tabs.

When I used this for the first time, it felt like a big step forward. With the right user interface, itâ€™s surprising how quickly you can get 100% confident in the model you are building.

Thereâ€™s a lot further we can go with this and we would love your feedback. We hope you like it!

People said moving back to London was career suicide when I graduated from USC. Europe was a "backwater". I soon found nothing could be further from the truth.

For 4 life-changing years I lived in sun-drenched California. I was infected with the manic creativity of Hollywood and the relentless drive of the LA-SF tech scene, and made lifelong friendships that shaped who I am today. After many wild adventures, I knew what I wanted next:

To join the defining technological revolution of our time: I wanted to work at an AI startup.

Europe has its problems - and London in particular. Itâ€™s wet and cold 9 months a year. Iâ€™m an avid surfer - no waves or pretty beaches in London, thatâ€™s for sure. Some people even told me it was dangerous and miserable. 

I decided to move anyway. Mostly on a strange feeling, a gravitational pull towards the city I grew up in. My peers in the US were landing prestigious MBB offers and jumping into launch pads at YCâ€™s hottest startups.

By comparison, my move back to Europe seemed a ridiculous gamble at best, career suicide at worst.

What kind of things did I hear when I announced I was moving to London? 
â€œAll the opportunity is in the USâ€
â€œthereâ€™s no startup ecosystem in Europeâ€
â€œyouâ€™re wasting your chanceâ€.

The moment I moved to London and met Peter Fuller, Aleksander Misztal, and Janek Zimoch, I realised that the doom and gloom around Europeâ€™s startup scene couldnâ€™t be further from the truth.

There is a thriving startup ecosystem in Europe. Countless startups like Lovable, ElevenLabs, 16 new Unicorns, and my home, Tracelight, are pushing the boundaries of AI. If youâ€™re driven to entrepreneurship and tech, thereâ€™s a ton of opportunity. Some say if you build in Europe you canâ€™t scale the US market. Our biggest clients are in the US. I joined as the 5th employee 4 months ago. Weâ€™ve since expanded offices twice and are at 12.

In terms of lifestyle, London is the best place Iâ€™ve ever lived - cozy pubs, lovely people, amazing music on every corner (thanks Fred again!), and pretty streets buzzing with cafÃ©s and activity.

California is fantastic. Donâ€™t let the world convince you itâ€™s the only place you can build something meaningful. The right place to start is different for everyone - trust your instincts, and you might just find it.

I was chatting to an investment banker this week. He told me about 19-hour days, 7-day weeks, and cancelled holidays. Then he said something that stayed with me:

"Deals are like babies. There's one born every minute, but each one is a miracle."

Why are they a miracle? Because a million things have to go right to close a deal. You have to work ferociously hard to get one over the line.

Many AI companies are selling bankers and investors a false dream. Use their products so you don't have to work hard anymore. "Prompt an LLM so you can go home at 8pm."

I'm not going to tell you that. I don't believe it. Tracelight's customers work in viciously competitive industries, and they are the type of people who push themselves to the absolute limit. I respect them for that.

What I'll tell you instead is that AI will help more "babies" be born. Time kills deals. Always has done. Tracelight and other AI products are going to speed things up radically. More deals will close. 

My contrarian view (no one agrees with me) is that this is the best time in history to be an investment banker, private equity investor, or management consultant.

Will your lifestyle improve? No, I don't think so. Will you work on more successful deals, learn faster, and make more money? Yep.

One of my New Year's Resolutions this year was "build a team you feel honoured to work with". 

Happy to say I did well on that one. It's a privilege to work with Janek, Aleksander, Louis, Jeremi, Benediktas, Varun, Ben, JoÃ£o and the exciting new hires starting in the next few weeks.

But I don't think my 2025 resolution went far enough.

For 2026, the bar is higher: build Tracelight into the place where the best people do the best work of their lives.

Talent matters enormously and we will continue to work ridiculously hard to get the strongest people through the door.

But culture matters just as much. If you find the best talent, your next job is to build an environment where those people get the very most out of themselves. 

Most of the time that means working hard on ambitious goals. But once in a while it means putting on silly Christmas hats and having a pint.

There was some critical discussion about the responsible deployment of AI in policing, and what was needed to unlock its safe use for the benefits of us all.  It was great to sit alongside the new Biometrics and Surveillance Camera CommissionerÂ Prof.Â William Webster,Â Dylan AlldridgeÂ from National Police Chiefs'â€‹ Council, Dr.Â Mackenzie J.Â from PROBabLE Futures, Lara Groves from Ada Lovelace Institute andÂ Ellen LefleyÂ from JUSTICE andÂ (thank you for the invitation!).

The report focuses on what must be in place for AI in policing to be trustworthy, value for money, support policing goals, and comply with human rights and the fair administration of justice.

This report identified five specific learnings, all which chime with how we think about AI at PIMLOC:
1ï¸âƒ£ Fitness for PurposeÂ â€“ AI tools must work, and must work for the context in which they are used.
2ï¸âƒ£ Competent, Ethical and Lawful UseÂ â€“ Human oversight must be real, informed and supported.
3ï¸âƒ£ Understanding ImpactsÂ â€“ AI tools must be evaluated both before and after deployment.
4ï¸âƒ£ Proportionate and Effective SafeguardsÂ â€“ Clear limits, accountability routes and effective redress are essential.
5ï¸âƒ£ Public ParticipationÂ â€“ Trust requires visibility, involvement and accountability.

The manufacturing talent gap is becoming a national emergency in more and more countries.

Fordâ€™s CEO recently revealed they have 5,000 mechanic jobs open, each paying around $120,000/year. And still, they canâ€™t find people to fill them. Thatâ€™s $600M in waiting investment from Ford alone.

The message is clear: weâ€™ve neglected manufacturing skills for far too long. And now, demand for skilled technicians has exploded.

At IPercept, we see this every day.
The only way to close the gap is to deploy technology that empowers people, making complex machines simple, data accessible, and intuitive to work with.

Itâ€™s time to reboot the narrative around choosing manufacturing as a career. People on the factory floor are essential. High-impact. And the field is full of opportunity.

Bringing AI into factories is the hardest frontier of this decade.
Manufacturing is hard, but the value unlocked is enormous.

The data below makes it obvious:
Manufacturing is still the least scaled function for AI. Only 5% of AI high performers have fully scaled AI in manufacturing, yet itâ€™s also the function delivering the strongest ROI.

This gap isnâ€™t surprising.
Factories run on physical machines that are multi-vendor, old, and closed. The real bottleneck has never been the algorithms, itâ€™s the lack of reliable, high-quality machine signals.

And this is also the reason why manufacturing holds the largest upside:
- Major increases in uptime
- Higher and more consistent product quality
- Dramatic reductions in waste and energy use
- Stronger competitiveness and supply-chain resilience

Whoever brings reliable, machine-level AI into factories will unlock a global industrial transformation.

157 Filler Words.

That's how many "uhms", "ehms" I say in an average sales call.

Every 17 seconds.

And each one costs me money. ğŸ˜®â€ğŸ’¨

here's the brutal truth after analyzing all my sales calls from last year:

My 3 most expensive filler words:

1. "Uhm" when stating price
- showed that I wasn't sure and people were 28% more likely to ask for a discount

2. "Like" during objection handling
- this one hurts my credibility according to our AI

3. "Ehmm, so..." I did that often before closing
- showed a lack of confidence

So I asked my co-founder & sales genius Gerald Zankl what I could do about it...

he told me the same as our AI did.

The simplest method:

Speak 15% slower.

That's it.

No coaching. No course. Just: Slower speech.

which helped me to get:

- from 157 to 44 filler words
- From 23% to 31% close rate

I hope you guys are better than me. :)

Following the massive architectural updates in our 1.5 series - which brought support for MI350x, Strix-halo, and the unlocking of all architectures in our free tier - we've just rolled out version 1.5.1.

This release delivers a fresh batch of under-the-hood optimizations, enhanced NVCC emulation, and runtime stability fixes to make your cross-compilation process smoother than ever.

Because breaking hardware lock-in shouldn't mean breaking your workflow.
Your original CUDA codebase, natively compiled for AMD GPUs. Zero rewrites.

We love open source. That's why we're at #FOSDEM ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡ª this weekend!

At Spectral, we build ğ—¼ğ—» ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ˜€ğ—µğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ ğ—¼ğ—³ ğ—´ğ—¶ğ—®ğ—»ğ˜ğ˜€. Our toolkit is built on #LLVM and compiles CUDA codebases to target AMD GPUs - with more vendors to come. CUDA is the standard. The hardware should be a choice.

Last night, our CTO Chris Kitching joined the HPC Amsterdam meetup at SURF to demonstrate how we are decoupling the software from the hardware - allowing developers to run their existing #CUDA codebases on any #GPU architecture, not just the one they started with.

A massive thank you to HPC Amsterdam for organizing the event and to SURF for hosting us in such a fantastic location. Nothing better than gathering so many brilliant minds in one room to discuss the future of our industry.

#HPC #Supercomputing #HardwareAgnostic #OpenEcosystem

We're thrilled to share that Spectral is partnering with the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign!

NCSA has been at the forefront of computing innovation since its founding as one of the original five NSF Supercomputer Centers. They've shaped how we use the internet today - creating the Mosaic web browser and NCSA HTTPd, which evolved into Apache HTTP Server. Their infrastructure includes Delta, a supercomputer housing impressive resources with hundreds of GPU nodes powered by NVIDIA A100s, A40s, H200s, and AMD MI100s.

Through this collaboration, ğ—¡ğ—–ğ—¦ğ—” ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—¹ ğ—µğ—®ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ—³ğ—¿ğ—²ğ—² ğ—®ğ—°ğ—°ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜€ ğ˜ğ—¼ ğ—¦ğ—–ğ—”ğ—Ÿğ—˜ (scale-lang.com) for non-commercial research and educational use.

This enables researchers and students to run their CUDA codebases on AMD GPUs without vendor lock-in or code rewrites, confidently diversifying their GPU infrastructure and choosing the best hardware for each project - with support for additional vendors coming soon.

As researchers ourselves, we love this community and stand by our decision to make SCALE freely available to academics. We're delighted that NCSA sees the opportunities this opens up - freeing resources that can go toward new and exciting research instead of wrestling with vendor constraints.

Ethical AI in recruitment is not about policies or checklists, itâ€™s about one core principle: AI must serve humans.

That means every candidate should be treated consistently, not differently based on noise, proxies, or randomness in the system.

It also means transparency. If AI influences whether you move forward in a hiring process, you have the right to understand why. Decisions that affect peopleâ€™s access to work cannot be black boxes!

And finally, it has to be robust and repeatable. If AI recommends you for the next step today, it should do the same tomorrow under the exact same conditions. Fairness breaks the moment outcomes become unpredictable.

This is where much of the conversation about AI still falls short. Explainability, consistency, and trust are foundational.

The rise of lawsuits in the US relating to candidates challenging the use of AI in hiring continues to put some important topics firmly in the spotlight. Iâ€™m not aiming to predict the outcome of any specific case, thatâ€™s for the courts to decide - but the questions being raised truly matter.

At the heart of our industry are the concerns many candidates are increasingly asking:
- How was AI used in this decision?
- What data was used and where did it come from?
- Can the outcome be explained clearly and credibly?

These are fair questions. And they highlight that candidate-centric AI starts with a simple principle: 
If a hiring decision canâ€™t be explained clearly the technology isnâ€™t doing its job. Over-dependence on black-boxes in critical parts of the candidate assessment and feedback lead to unacceptable levels of risk to enterprises and the fundamental rights of candidates.

At Hubert, we are obsessed about candidate experience, accuracy and explainability - and we are committed to doing AI hiring the right way. 
Thatâ€™s why we believe:
- New technologies should always put the experience and rights of the candidates first.
- AI should support human decisions, not automate decisions.
- Candidates deserve to know when AI is involved and how itâ€™s used (a future regulatory requirement)
- Assessments should be structured and repeatable, and grounded in scientifically proven methodologies, in order to be accurate, consistent and fair.

As AI becomes more embedded in hiring, scrutiny will increase - from candidates, regulators, and the market. Thatâ€™s not something to fear, itâ€™s healthy but it is something to prepare for.

Over the coming weeks, here at Hubert weâ€™ll be sharing more on:
- What explainable hiring really looks like in practice
- How to spot and mitigate risks before they become a problem
- How to implement AI in hiring in a safe way for both the candidate and the enterprise
- And the questions every TA leader should be able to answer with confidence

Because trust in hiring doesnâ€™t come from avoiding hard conversations.
Itâ€™s built by leading them â€“ clearly, responsibly, and with candidates at the core.

Freeing humans to do human-work, like spending time on building relationships, assessing culture, and making better final hiring decisions.

The companies that win in hiring will not be the ones that automate the most, they will be the ones that use AI to become fairer, more human, and more consistent.

That is what weâ€™re all about at Hubert.

Gap analysis is our HERO product that delivers the "aha" moment everytime we demo the product to compliance officers. 

Regulatory monitoring is necessary. But on its own, it doesnâ€™t move the organisation forward.

The real value lies in understanding the impact:

- If we move from MLR to FSMA, what actually needs to change?
- In light of AMLA, what needs updating in our AML policy?
- Which processes or controls are no longer sufficient?

Compliance teams donâ€™t need more alerts. They need clarity on gaps across policies, processes, and controls and a clear view of where to focus.

Thatâ€™s where gap analysis consistently proves its worth.

Itâ€™s unreal to think that almost 500 compliance officers have signed up for our workshop next week.

What started as a thesis back in November has now grown into one of the most in-demand AI workshops in compliance.

The goal with the workshop has always been simple for us at Zango:

Give non-technical professionals practical, hands-on AI skills they can immediately use with the AI tools already at their disposal to do their jobs better.

Because thereâ€™s a real gap.

In large organisations, the lack of AI training in functions like legal, risk, and compliance is becoming a serious issue. And itâ€™s leading to three patterns:

- Decision-makers who donâ€™t fully understand AI so they avoid adopting it in their teams.

- Leaders who donâ€™t understand it but feel pressured to act like they do resulting in sub-optimal decisions.

- A small group of ambitious professionals spending Â£30,000 â€“ Â£50,000 out of their own pockets on university diplomas and executive AI programmes.

None of this is sustainable.

And seeing 500 compliance professionals lean in tells me this problem is very real.

I've been thinking a lot about the dynamic between tech vendors, consultants, and lawyers.

Traditionally, lawyers handled the high-value work. Financial institutions wouldn't use them for everything because of the cost, but they needed them for critical matters. Consultants did the grunt work, and software played only a minor role esp in risk and compliance.

How will this balance evolve?

AI will certainly play a larger role, but the question is: will lawyers and financial institutions partner directly with tech firms (that will displace consultants) or will consultants find ways to integrate AI themselves and protect their business?

Which scenario is going to play out?

Scenarios 1 and 2 seem highly probable in my opinion.

Recently, weâ€™ve been helping a bank launch in a new country.

Zangoâ€™s AI agents turn regulatory complexity into obligations, compliance and product teams can actually work with.

We start by identifying all relevant laws, decrees, regulations, and guidelines for a given product and country.

We then use AI to extract and normalize the obligations (KYC requirements, onboarding rules, risk checks).

These obligations are organized into a clear, readable view by topic, tagged as prescriptive or risk-based, and mapped to the relevant product flows.

Product and compliance teams can review, verify, and track progress in one place.

The result is a shared roadmap that keeps both teams aligned from regulation to user journey.

Verdict: Very happy. And slightly smug.

- Quick answers? Great.
- Pushing someone to the right support article? Lovely.

At ğŸŒ± Rightcharge weâ€™ve gone for the best of both, with Jeeves, our AI support butler (doing an amazing job, solving 35% of incoming tickets instantly, although his Q4 KPI is 40%!) but also a real human team on both chat, emails and phone.
