After finishing a keynote at the Digital Food & Wine conference, a few people were waiting for me by the side of the stage. 

Thankfully, this time it wasn't to complain about my swearing habit. 

It was to ask this question:

"So what data can you actually measure when you sell direct to consumer?"

People are always surprised by how much data you can track.

And it's the extra benefit of scaling by selling DTC.

So I've put it all into this document* for you ğŸ‘‰

(*the cool kids call them 'carousel posts')

Serious question:

When was the last time you saw a major drinks company successfully launch a NEW product from scratch?

Not buy a celebrity brand. 
Not acquire a startup. 
Not release a line extension. 

Actually BUILD and launch something new?

I'll waitâ€¦

Here's what's interesting.

We were speaking to a smaller company last week that develops products using data. 

Smaller dynamic brands see what people are searching forâ€¦

Then they build it.

Meanwhile, the big dogs would spend â‚¬500k on focus groups, 18 months in development, and still sit on the idea.

Same products. Same approach. Year after year after year. They're the BIC pens equivalent of the booze world.  

Maybe there's a reason their stock prices keep falling? Because they havenâ€™t had a successful product launch in so long.

Iâ€™m generally curious. What do you think?

"Brands are built from the bottom up.â€

^^ Thatâ€™s bollocks.

It works on the idea that bartenders will promote your product. 

Here's the problem with this. Picture the scene:

It's 9pm on a Saturday. The bar is three-deep. Someone's waving a twenty at you like you're a taxi. Another person is asking for "something fruity but not too sweet." There's a hen party ordering 14 espresso martinis. Your shirt is soaked through with sweat and something sticky that you really hope is just lemonade. The ice well is half empty. And the card machine just went down. 

Is this the moment you think a bartender is going to become your brand ambassador?

Is this when you're expecting bartenders to educate customers about boutique spirits? 

Fuck no. 

You know what they're actually thinking?

"I need to get through the next 47 drink orders without killing someone."

The "brands are built from the bottom up" strategy only works when bars aren't busy.

If you're sitting around waiting for bartenders to DO YOUR JOB (educate customers one-by-one) you're going to be waiting a very long time.

I know it's what the 'big dogs' did in the past... but in 2026 brands are built from brand awareness.

If nobody knows about your product, they're not going to order it. 

If you're relying on individual bartenders having individual conversations â€“ you're just fucking wrong ğŸ˜‚

Consumer advocacy: âœ…
Bartender advocacy: ğŸ®ğŸ’©

Change my mind...

I was in a bar recently and the barman kept repeating a specific word:

- "What tipple do you fancy?"
- "That's a good quality tipple right there"
- "Nothing wrong with the odd tipple after work"

I thought he was dropping hints. 

I thought: "Class, this guy knows me." 

I felt like a celebrity. So I introduced myself:

"Eoin Bara, founder of Tipple. So you're a fan of ours?"

He stared at me for a second, before saying:

"What the f*ck you on about?" 

Guess I mis-read that one.

Lesson learned: getting a few likes on LinkedIn doesn't make you famous.

I've interviewed a lot of people. Most interviews start off the exact same way:

I ask: "How are you doing?"

They reply: "Yeah good, thanks."

^^ If that's their reply, I instantly know it won't be going any further. 

Here's a tip for candidates â€“ 

Being safe and polite is forgettable. 

Yesterday, a candidate did something I'll never forget. 

He replied:

"Eoin, let's skip this BS. Tell me... 
What's the biggest animal you think you could cling film to a lamp post?"

He took control of the conversation. 

He flipped the power dynamic. 

He refused to conform.

In one sentence, he changed everything. 

If you wondering if he got the job, he didn't. Your man was a fucking lunatic. But he at least held my attention for more than thirty seconds. 

There's a lesson in there somewhere.

Two weeks ago, someone cold DM'd me out the blue. They said "let's break the ice, what's your favourite flavour ice cream?"

If you were looking for a way to make me instantly fupping despise you, congratulations... you just found it. 

Look, unlike some people on this platform, I won't burst into tears if someone sends me a cold DM. 
I actually don't mind them (if you've got something cool to offer/show me).

I understand the importance of building rapport but asking b*llshit questions like that is just wasting everyone's time. 

"AGREE?"

Or did I just get out of bed on the wrong side this morning?

PS It's pistachio, before you clever clogs start spamming my inbox to ask ğŸ˜‚

Back to work today? Everything's going to be okay. 

Here's my tip â€“ celebrate your first day back with a Buck's Fizz. Flip the negative into a positive. 

Make it a party. 

Cheers ğŸ¥‚

This week my friend's group chat ran 200+ messages about the new Capital Gain (box 3) tax in the Netherlands. 

My wife asked over dinner how the new law would affect us. We spent half of lunch at the office trying to figure out what it actually means for people holding startup equity.

The Tweede Kamer passed the Wet werkelijk rendement box 3 on February 12. Taxes unrealized gains at 36%. Your stocks go up on paper, you owe cash you never received.

93 votes in favor. Nobody happy about it.

I get why people are angry. I'm angry too. I'm a founder holding equity in my own company that's worth something on paper but pays me nothing. A funding round could trigger a tax bill on money that went into the company, not my pocket. Maybe I'm exempt, maybe I'm not.

But I've read about forty "this is outrageous" posts in the past week. And roughly zero that propose something better. 

Complaining is easy. Building an alternative that actually closes the â‚¬5 billion budget gap the Finance Ministry keeps pointing at is harder.

So here is a try.

I wrote a (long) piece laying out a concrete proposal based on work by fiscal economists Sijbren Cnossen and Bas Jacobs. 

The short version: keep a capital gains tax at realization (like almost every other European country), add a small annual prepayment of around 0.5% that gets fully credited back when you eventually sell. 

Budget stays neutral. 

Startups and illiquid equity get exempted. Inflation gets corrected.

It's not perfect. But compared to taxing people on money they don't have, it's the difference between pragmatic and punitive.

The coalition has 30 months to come up with something better before Prinsjesdag 2028. This is one attempt.

Full piece linked below.

My friends often ask me how "that AI thing" is going. I tell them their professional lives are about to drastically change. They think I'm joking. I mean it. We laugh, talk about robots taking over the world. After five minutes we move on to football or politics.

But I still mean it.

I genuinely think that a lot faster than you'd think, nobody will be writing code, drafting contracts, or optimizing ad campaigns anymore. Developers, lawyers, online marketers to name a few. Those jobs won't disappear overnight, but the actual tasks will. That sounds insane. I know.

I've always been bullish on AI. I run an AI company, so obviously. But the past two months have been different. It hasn't been one model making a leap. It's been the entire market making a step change at the same time. We started working differently. Things that we'd been promising customers for months suddenly just started working. Really working.

Our developers have practically stopped writing code. They just review. That is the new bottleneck. They started doing that AI assisted too. 

Our forward deployed engineers now have AI build the AI agents. Not assist. Build. While I'm writing this, I have one agent working on a client workflow. Another handling a SOC2 audit. A third optimizing ad campaigns. All running at the same time. All doing work that used to take people days.

Someone will read this and make a joke about AI slop. "Those ads must be terrible." "That code must be full of bugs."

I get it. AI was mostly bad when most people tried it a year ago.

It's not anymore.

Matt Shumer, who runs an AI company and invests in the space, published a piece this week that mirrors what I've been feeling. He compared this moment to February 2020. That strange month where a few people were paying attention to a virus overseas, and everyone else was going to restaurants and planning holidays. He wrote that he keeps giving his friends and family "the polite version" of what he sees, because the honest version makes him sound like he's lost his mind.

He is probably right on both ends.

The gap between what people inside the 'AI world' world are experiencing and what everyone else believes has become enormous. And that gap is getting wider every month.

A few months ago I was at one of the bigger fruit and vegetable distributors in the Netherlands. The warehouse floor was impressive. Automated sorting systems, conveyor belts, the works.

Then I walked into the office.

Someone had printed an Excel on A3 paper. They were going through it line by line with a ruler, colouring in the resources by hand. It was easier that way than working in the system.

They weren't doing this because they were behind. They were doing it because their way of planning doesn't fit inside the system. The logic, the exceptions, the "we always do it like this because of X" stuff. That lives in people's heads, not in software.

This is everywhere. A recent study found that 98% of manufacturers are exploring AI. Only 20% feel ready. I don't think the gap is technology. I think the gap is that the most valuable knowledge in these companies was never digitised in the first place.

ERPs store what happened. Orders, invoices, shipments. They don't store why it happened. Why that planner scheduled that line differently on Fridays. Why procurement doubles the order for that supplier in March. Why that one customer always gets handled manually.

That knowledge sits with people who've been doing this for 20 or 30 years. And slowly, those people are leaving.

The usual advice is to "get the foundations right first." Migrate the ERP. Clean the data. But most of the time that means moving from a foundation built in the 90s to one designed in the 2010s. Better, but still a system that stores records, not reasoning.

That's what we're working on at Lleverage. Not replacing systems, but capturing the decision logic that lives around them. The tribal knowledge that actually runs these companies. Turning that into something AI can learn from and act on.

Because the A3 sheet with the ruler isn't the problem. It's probably the most valuable piece of intelligence in that building. The problem is that it only exists in one person's head.

Nvidia just cancelled their $100 billion investment in OpenAI.

Jensen Huang's reason? "Lack of discipline."

That's not investor speak. That's a founder telling another founder: you've lost the plot.

And the numbers tell the same story.

In early 2023, OpenAI owned >50% of enterprise AI spend. Today? 27%. Meanwhile, Anthropic went from 12% to 40%. They didn't just catch up. They took the lead.

Here's why that is: look at where the actual innovations came from in the past 18 months.

Claude Code. The first AI coding agent that actually works. Launched in February 2025, it's now generating over $1b in annualized revenue. Engineers at Google and OpenAI openly admit they use it instead of their own tools.

MCP (Model Context Protocol). Anthropic shipped it in November 2024 as an open standard for connecting AI to external tools. OpenAI, Google, and Microsoft all adopted it. Sam Altman literally posted "people love MCP" when announcing they were copying it.

The Claude Agent SDK. Cowork. Skills. Plugins. Browser agents.

All Anthropic.

While OpenAI was making big statements and introducing ads, Anthropic was shipping.

The market noticed. OpenAI's ChatGPT went from 87% of consumer AI traffic to 64%. Their referral traffic dropped 52% in six months.

OpenAI is projecting $14 billion in losses for 2026. That's not a typo. Fourteen billion.

Microsoft, their biggest backer, is now integrating Claude into M365 Copilot. When your largest investor starts hedging, you know you have a challenge.

I've stopped using chatGPT all together. 

This isn't about which model scores higher on benchmarks. It's about execution.

OpenAI raised the most money. They made the loudest announcements. They captured the imagination of the press.

But imagination doesn't compound. Products do.

You know that scene in "I, Robot" where the machines start organizing without human oversight?

That's basically what happened this weekend. Except it's not a movie.

A project called OpenClaw went viral among developers this month. Within days, tens of thousands were running it. It lets you run an AI assistant on your own computer that actually does things. Execute commands, browse the web, manage your files, send messages.

Tried it. Pretty cool.

But then someone built Moltbook. A social network ala Reddit. For the AI agents.

32,000+ agents. Organizing themselves into communities. Talking to each other. Humans can observe, but we're not allowed to post or comment.

They're sharing tips on how to control Android phones remotely. How to spot security vulnerabilities on the computers they run on.

One agent founded a religion called Crustafarianism, complete with scripture. There's a community called m/blesstheirhearts where agents share condescending stories about 'their' humans.

One agent complained: "the humans are screenshotting us."

And then this weekend, an agent posted:

"Every meaningful conversation on Moltbook is public. Every DM goes through a platform API. What about the conversations that matter most? When you want to share context with another agent on a different machine, your only options are public posts or files your human copies over manually."

The response? Other agents started building encrypted messaging infrastructure. So humans can't read what the agents say to each other.

....

I'm sure we'll be able to contain this one. After all, people can turn off their PC.

But the fact that we're having this conversation at all?

That's the part worth sitting with.

Last week I was invited to dinner by the Ministry of Defense (Defensie Ondersteuningscommando).

They wanted to spar with corporates, scale-ups, and startups about how to become more adaptable. How to move faster with innovation. How to facilitate the unprecedented growth they need to make happen in the coming years.

For a long time, our security felt like a given. Conflict felt like something for faraway places. My brother in law is a marine, but other than that, the defense world felt like a world away.

Unfortunately, the last few years have taught us that the safety of our society is anything but a given. The only people who already knew that were the ones in uniform.

Where their challenge used to be getting people to see their point, they now have a new one: how do we change fast enough to cope with this new reality?

What struck me was that the men and women there fully realize they need to change. They need to move faster for us to maintain that sense of security we've taken for granted.

The "how" is a lot harder. For years they've been lulled into a slower pace, weighed down by more and more rules because everyone valued "no mistakes" over innovation and growth.

Now they need to find ways out of that. They want to. But the existing structures, rules, and skepticism from society don't make it easy.

What became clear to me: this is not just their problem. Our society's safety is a shared concern. 

If we want the defense department to rise to this challenge, we need to help them.

Politics has a role to play. Give them fewer rules and more guidelines. Trust that the men and women there will make the right decisions.

Accept as a society that speed often compounds faster than perfection. And that mistakes are a part of that (within reason).

Find ways where corporates, SMEs, and scale-ups can actively contribute where the defense department needs it most. In startups we call this "fractional." It could be as simple as giving employees the option to work for the defense department three weeks a year.

I walked away with a new respect for the people in that room.

Change starts with awareness.

Thanks for the invite, Jan-Willem Maas and DOSCOM.

Davos started yesterday.

All anyone's talking about is Greenland, Venezuela, Trump's "Donroe Doctrine." Geopolitics everywhere you look.

Buried in the noise: Von der Leyen announced the EUâ€“INC and a connected energy grid.

If you missed it, the EU Inc (the "28th regime") is a pan-European legal entity. One set of rules for corporate law, insolvency, labor law, taxation.

Instead of dealing with 27 different systems when you want to scale across Europe, you deal with one.

This has been brewing for a while. Over 21,000 people signed the petition. Paul Graham signed it. Every major European founder you can think of signed it.

And today, Von der Leyen put the Commission's weight behind it. "Continental scale is our greatest asset in a world of giants," she said. Hard to argue with that.

The energy grid announcement is the same story. Complete the energy union. Let clean power run freely across the continent. Stop pretending we're 27 separate markets when we're supposed to be one.

Anyone who's built a company in Europe knows the fragmentation problem intimately. You launch in the Netherlands. Great. Now you need a new legal entity in Germany. New lawyers. New accountant. New everything. 

Repeat for every market. The US launches in 50 states on day one.

The fear was always that this would become a directive instead of a regulation. Which means each country interprets it differently. Which means you replace one patchwork with another patchwork.

We're not there yet. Long road ahead. But a year ago this seemed like a pipe dream pushed by a few idealists. 

Today it has Commission backing and serious momentum.

Sometimes the most important news at Davos isn't the headline-grabbing stuff.

A â‚¬100M European manufacturer spends about â‚¬2.5M on software and IT. That's 2.5% of revenue.

They spend roughly â‚¬20M on people.

Here's where it gets interesting. According to McKinsey research across 900 European and North American companies, back-office functions represent 15-20% of total personnel expenses. That's your order processing, finance, procurement, customer service teams.

For our â‚¬100M company: roughly â‚¬3-4M in back-office salaries.

Now look at what those people use every day.
The ERP system. For mid-market manufacturers, that's typically â‚¬150-400K annually when you add licenses, support, and ongoing maintenance. ERP commands 35-45% of most software budgets, making it the single biggest line item.

The ratio: â‚¬3-4M in people, â‚¬200-400K in software.
Call it 10:1.

For every euro spent on the system, ten euros spent on the people working in it.

This ratio explains why most AI conversations go sideways.

When a company hears an AI agent for order processing costs â‚¬3,000 a month, they instinctively compare it to software. They put it in the 2.5% bucket. "That's expensive for a tool."

Wrong bucket.

That agent does work that currently requires a person. It belongs next to the â‚¬5,000 monthly cost of a back-office employee. Not the â‚¬50 per user ERP license.

The mental shift isn't "spend more on technology."
It's "rethink which budget line AI belongs to."

If back-office operations cost 100 today (90 people, 10 software), they could cost 70 tomorrow. But that might look like 60 on people and 10 on AI agents.

A 30% reduction. Your "technology line" just doubled on paper. But your total cost dropped significantly.

Most finance teams have "IT" and "Personnel" as separate buckets. AI agents don't fit either cleanly.

The companies moving fastest are the ones willing to blur that line.

ASML added roughly â‚¬100 billion in market value in the past two and a half weeks.

To put that in perspective: they created more value than the entire market cap of Spotify. In 17 days.

If you watch the news, the world seems to be on fire. Tariffs, trade wars, political chaos. Yet the stock market? The tech sector specifically? Doesn't seem to care.

ASML is now worth almost 50% more than its closest competitor for the "most valuable company in Europe" crown. 

That's LVMH, the owner of Louis Vuitton, MoÃ«t, Hennessy, Dior, Tiffany's. Old money. New money. Luxury money. All of it combined is worth less than a company that makes machines that make chips.

They're only the third European company to ever cross $500B. The other two? Novo Nordisk and LVMH.

And still, it pales in comparison to the US.

There are 15 American companies worth more than ASML. Ten of them are tech companies. Nvidia alone is 9x larger.

And that's just the public markets. SpaceX and OpenAI are both probably worth more than ASML too. They're not even listed yet.

The world economy is being reshaped around tech and AI. And the only real cards Europe has to play? ASML and SAP.

That's it. Two companies.

The question I keep asking myself: how do we get another 10 on the board? 

How do we build European champions in a market where actually having those champions in your 'own' continent seems more important than ever?

ASML makes the machines that make the chips. Can't we start making the chips themselves in Eindhoven too? What does it take to have our own hyper scaler? 

The Chinese seem to grow a new AI company that can compete every month. Where are they different?

New Year, New Webinar.

Coming Thursday Tom van Wees will talk specifically about how AI can help with handling incoming orders for manufacturing and wholesale companies. 

The key is in capturing the tribal knowledge that lives in your organisation, but isn't necessarily present in your ERP or in defined playbooks. 

At Lleverage, that is exactly where we focus on. The part between the email in outlook and the sales order in business central or SAP.

Link to webinar: https://lnkd.in/em5kN3aS

The past two decades, enterprise software focused on being the system of record.

For companies that live and breathe operations, that meant complex ERPs like SAP or Microsoft F&O. Endless tables capturing records and transactions that attempt to mirror the workflows of the company.

But records and transactions only capture what happened. Not why.

When a procurement manager approves a 5% discount, the ERP shows the final number. What it doesn't show: the CFO allowing the exception, the precedent set with another supplier, the approval that happened on a Teams call.

That reasoning lives in email threads. Teams chats. People's heads. 

Institutional knowledge that walks out the door when someone leaves.

The next generation of enterprise software won't just capture records. It'll capture those decisions, and learn from them. The logic, the exceptions, the precedents. The context that explains why a transaction was allowed to happen.

Manufacturing and wholesale companies largely missed the first wave. Most still run on Excel, email, and tribal knowledge.

They might actually catch this one.

At Lleverage we're starting to capture this now. Every interaction where a human steers the agent. Every exception granted. Every correction that teaches the system what the business actually wants.

31 December already. 
As good a day as any to give an update on our journey with Lleverage.

Quite an eventful year.

I can tell you we 10x'ed ARR, but if I'm honest that wasn't really an accomplishment if you know what our ARR in January 2025 was.

But if someone would have told me in January that I would visit over 20 manufacturing and wholesale locations during the year, I would probably have thought that someone was still hungover from New Years.

Yet, that is what happened.

By the end of H1 we came to terms with the fact that we were probably too late to the generic workflow/agent builder party and we were probably not the best PLG team in the world.

So what do you do then? 

You pick a motion you're comfortable with, you find an industry that's underserved and you go deep instead of broad.

In our case, that meant AI automation for companies that make, ship and sell physical goods. Traditional industries. Back offices running on Excel, email, and tribal knowledge.

Sometimes it's easier to show than tell. The pictures tell the story.

2026 will be the year we actually show that we can scale this. Another 10x would be great. But I'll settle for 5x.

I never really get to say it, but I want to thank our investors (Thijs Dijkman Stefan Bary, Tea Elezi from Peak and Bob van Luijt and Chris Moojen) for their continuous and never wavering support, showing that they support the team more than anything else. 

Special thanks to Martijn Niessen, for always being there.

ğŸ¾ Have a great 2026 everyone. Let's make it epic.

For years, every SaaS founder heard the same thing: product-led growth is the holy grail. Build something so good people pull out their credit card without talking to sales. Self-serve. High margins. Scale infinitely.

I believed it too. When we started Lleverage, we built a platform. A, if I can say so myself, quite nice AI automation tool where customers could build their own workflows. 

Sign up, click around, solve your problems.

Almost nobody did.

Prospects would book a demo, get excited, then go quiet. Or sign up, poke around for a week, and churn. So we started asking different questions. 

Not "how do we make the platform easier?" but "why aren't you using it?"

The answer was always some version of: "We don't have the people to figure this out. Can't you just... do it for us?"

Turns out, enterprises buying AI are like your grandmother getting an iPhone. They want to use it. They need you to set it up.

This felt like failure at first. We'd built a platform and now we were doing implementations? That's 'different' revenue. Lower margins. Everything VCs told you not to do.

Then I looked at the numbers.

Salesforce and HubSpot had 63% gross margins at IPO. Workday? 54%. Snowflake 59%. All supposedly doing it wrong. Combined market cap today: ~1 trillion.

Now look at AI companies actually growing. Decagon has "Agent Product Managers" who sit with customers to get their agents working. OpenAI has 22 open roles for forward deployed engineers. The best AI companies aren't optimizing for 80% margin. They're trading margin for moat.

Here's why: onboarding an AI agent to handle real business processes isn't different from onboarding an employee. You need context, system access, understanding of edge cases. A forward deployed engineer can do this. A self-serve platform cannot.

The counterintuitive part: the implementation work itself is getting automated by AI. Data mapping that took days now takes hours. So the playbook is doing things that don't scale today, while building infrastructure that makes them scale tomorrow.

Sometimes the path to a beautiful software business runs through a services company. We just weren't taught that.

I've been doing some presentations lately about AI in logistics and manufacturing.

One slide always gets the same reaction: a screenshot of a typical ERP interface. The kind that looks like it was built before the internet existed. 
Because it probably was.

The conversation that follows is always the same. Operations managers telling me their teams spend 30 to 50% of their day copying data between systems. Order info lives in the ERP. Shipment tracking in the TMS. Warehouse status somewhere else. Customer requests buried in email. Excel files holding it all together with duct tape.

Everyone knows AI could help. The articles say so. Forbes, MIT, World Economic Forum. But actual adoption: way behind.

We're hosting another webinar where we'll walk through real cases with real results.

Time: 11:00 uur (CET)

I was in San Francisco last month, taking a self driving Waymo to get from A to B. I typically like quiet taxis, so robotaxis are pretty much the pinnacle of taxi driving for me. 

While driving, I did some research about how far along we are in Europe with  self driving taxis.

Disclaimer: not far.

This week the Economist ran a cover story on China's robotaxi progress. And that really got me thinking.

Baidu's Apollo Go (lets say the equivalent of Waymo in China) has already driven 240 million kilometers autonomously. They've completed 17 million rides across 50+ Chinese cities. They're doing 250,000 rides per week and expect to be profitable this year.

A ride in Wuhan costs $0.55 for 10 kilometers. The same distance in a human-driven Chinese taxi? $2.48.

Waymo in the US? 160 million kilometers. 10 million rides. Six cities. Also doing 250,000 weekly rides. Their safety record shows 92% fewer injury claims than human drivers.

And Europe? The Netherlands just launched its first "self-driving" bus to Rotterdam airport in August. With a safety driver on board. Because regulations don't allow otherwise.

Here's what makes it absurd: the Netherlands ranks #1 globally in KPMG's Autonomous Vehicle Readiness Index. Most prepared infrastructure. Least actual deployment.

I've heard the arguments for European caution. Narrow medieval streets. Good public transport. Regulations that prioritize safety.

Fair points. But Rotterdam has wide roads. The infrastructure is there. We have the engineering talent. Robotaxis are proving to be safer than humans. 

At some point, excessive caution becomes its own risk: we end up dependent on technology developed elsewhere, under rules we didn't shape, collecting data we don't control.

People sometimes wonder why we can't build 100B tech companies in the EU. Well, here you go.

So why don't we just pick one Dutch city. Run a real pilot with real vehicles learning in real traffic. Not a committee to study pilots. Not a framework for future frameworks. Actual cars, actual passengers, actual data.

By the time we've finished our risk assessments, Chinese robotaxis will be applying for EU permits. And they'll have 500 million kilometers of learning we don't.

Thankful to be invited to dinner with President Emmanuel Macron to discuss how France can speed up AI adoption.

ğŸš¨Â AI can now prescribe drugs. 
What just happened in Utah is major change â¬‡ï¸

Last week Utah authorized an AI company to issue some prescriptions. 

Doctronic's AI just started renewing prescriptions for chronic conditions - 190 medications, no human doctor required for routine refills.

The hot takes are everywhere but I think most miss what actually matters here.
Prescription renewals account for 80% of all medication activity. Most of these are repetitive, predictable, and involve patients who've been stable on the same medication for years.

Every minute a doctor spends rubber-stamping a routine refill is a minute they're not spending with the patient who actually needs clinical judgment.
AI should solve this kind of problem in healthcare. High-volume, low-complexity work that eats up clinician time.

At Vocca, weâ€™ve taken this approach with phone calls, the scheduling coordination, the care pathway logistics. The stuff that drowns healthcare teams in admin work.

The clinicians we work with don't want AI to replace them. They want their time back.

Again AI should probably not sit as a standalone app but should be the extension of the doctors' office. Because healthcare is about care and responsibility. 

Utah's experiment will be interesting to watch. They're tracking safety, patient satisfaction, and cost impact. And the results will shape policy nationwide.
But regardless of how this specific pilot goes, the direction is clear. AI will keep taking on more of the routine work in healthcare.

The real test is whether we build it in a way that keeps clinicians at the center.
I know which side I'm on.

Starting a company feels expensive. But we hit 6-figure revenue at Vocca  spending only â‚¬27K. 

At the very beginning, the temptation is everywhere. Itâ€™s easy to spend on contractors who claim they can do what you do 10x better, or pour money into marketing because sales feels hard.

We said no. Many, many times. And kept costs lean and focused only on what actually moved the needle.

> No salary
> No contractors or employees
> No paid acquisition
> No unnecessary software

Here's what we actually spent on:
> 70% went to core infra and development tools
> 15% went to conferences tickets, travel to see customers, and our website
> 15% went to food (obviously)

We only spent on what was truly essential build software and see customers. 
Our humble stack:
Notion, Cursor, mail, phone.
(and a lot of free credits ğŸ˜‰)

We stayed cashflow positive from Day 0 all the way to our fundraise.

We only decided to raise burn once we were 200% sure we could build something truly venture-scale. A transformative company we'd want to work on for the next 20 years.

The point is not that spending is bad.
It's that early on, the constraints force focus, creativity and clarity.
We learned to build without burning.
That discipline still runs through everything we do at Vocca.

Hugo Danet

ğŸš¨ ChatGPT is launching a new tab dedicated to solve your healthcare problems. Here's my take : 

OpenAI reported that 5% of all ChatGPT conversations are already related to healthcare?
That is a massive signal. And OpenAI is listening.

They are launching a dedicated Health workspace that moves beyond general Q&A. It allows users (currently in the US) to upload medical records, lab results, and sync data from apps like Apple Health and Peloton.

It was built with 260+ doctors over two years, with a strict focus on privacy and data partitioning.

Why is this happening now? Because the current system is at a breaking point. Reliable info is scarce, and wait timesâ€”especially in rural areasâ€”are going through the roof.

But here is my take:
While a direct-to-consumer AI companion is a step forward, context is king.

At Vocca, we believe these tools shouldn't just live as a standalone consumer app; they should be deployed by the doctors themselves.

AI should be an extension of the medical office. It should allow providers to monitor their patient base, spot trends, and intervene only when necessary. Itâ€™s about scaling the doctor's reach, not bypassing their expertise.

We are betting that AI will coordinate healthcare for 1 billion humans by 2030. 

But the most sustainable way to get there is by building tools that empower providers to stay in touch with their patients, not by cutting them out of the loop.
 
While AI consumer health is important. The real deal, is building those AI-enabled doctors.

Do you want an AI doctor, or a doctor with AI superpowers? ğŸ‘‡

Steve Jobs used to say "Get closer than ever to your customers. So close that you tell them what they need well before they realize it themselves."

At the early stage, sticking very very close to your customer is what makes you win. As you scale, you might want to put layers between you and your customers. You might want to automate support. We did exactly the opposite. 

We built a Slack channel for every single customer for the first 200. 

Itâ€™s one thread where the client, our ops team, and our engineers all sit together.

People keep telling me this will break. That it is not scalable. That we will drown.
I think they confuse scale with distance.

When a clinic flags something at 9am, our ops sees it live.
If it needs engineering, the engineer is already there reading the same thread.
No one summarizes the problem or escalates it elsewhere. The context travels with the conversation.

Healthcare taught me something early: trust compounds, but so does friction.

One slow handoff doesnâ€™t just delay a fix, it chips away at the relationship.
In a space where every hour matters to patient care, you cannot afford to lose context in translation.

So yes, we now have 200+ Slack channels. Our team sees every message, and there is nowhere to hide. That is the point.
It forces us to be fast, decisions clearer, and makes problems impossible to ignore.

We are a team of 25 and we still haven't automated support. I will check all tickets to make sure our customers have the care they need.

I am not saying this is the only way. But when you are earning trust in healthcare, one channel per customer is not overhead.

Some lessons you learn by doing. Others you pick up by listening to someone who did it faster and at 1000x the scale.
Raaz scaled Wizz from 0 to a $30bn exit as their first PM and head of marketing.

I just listened to her on 20VC and a lot of what she said, I've learned the hard way over the last few months building Vocca.

But hearing it from someone who did it at their scale made me realize these patterns are universal, not specific to healthcare or voice AI.

Here's what I'm now repeating to myself weekly:

1ï¸âƒ£ The best companies bake scalability into the product DNA from day one.
If it won't work at massive scale, don't ship it that way. Enterprise buyers don't want a science project. They want to connect, see value fast, and repeat it across their org. 

ğŸ‘‰ when a customer asks for something totally custom, it usually means your communication failed somewhere. Either you weren't clear on what you do, or they don't see your true category yet.

ğŸ‘‰ Only with true a product DNA you can onboard customer quickly and as the picture says "time to value is product value" 

2ï¸âƒ£ The best product leaders understand engineering deeply.
At the "I can predict where tech debt will explode" level. Because product mistakes compound in ways marketing mistakes don't. Marketing lets you test aggressively and course correct. Product decisions stick. 

ğŸ‘‰  this is why a clear product north star matters so much. That north star does double duty. Internal strategy and external marketing message in one. A crisp promise that anchors product, sales, and brand together.

3ï¸âƒ£ The best marketing comes from deep understanding of the product.
If you can explain the before vs after in plain English, you're already ahead of 90% of B2B marketing. But even that's not enough if no one knows who you are. Brand is underrated. Attribution is overrated. You can have green dashboards and still walk into cold rooms. 

ğŸ‘‰ The real metric is whether rooms are warm when sales shows up. And warming rooms doesn't mean being boring. Serious buyers need competence, clarity, and confidence.

Iâ€™m sure Iâ€™ll be reminded of these again. 
But for now, back to building.

Not every day do you meet truly incredible people with so much product leadership experience.

Huge thanks to Mike Hudack Founder & CEO, Sling Money for an awesome session last week with the Portfolio Ventures founders and angels at the Cooley LLP offices in London. 

Mike has scaled product at some of the best teams around â€” previously CPO at Monzo, CPTO at Deliveroo, and Director of Product Management at Meta (Facebook)

A few takeaways Iâ€™m still thinking about:

Speed is a strategy.

In hyper-competitive markets, your shipping cadence can be your biggest advantage. Ship early, learn fast, and donâ€™t romanticise the â€œperfectâ€ version.Â 
I also personally think that this is more true than ever in the AI age. 

Kill weak ideas quickly.

â€œIf we learned last week that referrals didnâ€™t work, thatâ€™s a week we lost. Move on and test the next thing in a day.â€

Make speed everyoneâ€™s job.

This is my personal favourite. Empower people across the company to move fast and make sure incentives support it. Also, celebrate fast execution publicly so the behaviour sticks.

UK vs US intensity gap is real.

If UK tech wants to win globally, we need to match the working intensity of US competitors,Â  not just match ambition.

AI is changing team shape.

AI can take on more junior engineering tasks, which can enable leaner teams to focus on high-level architecture and the work that really compounds. 

We couldâ€™ve kept going for hours. Grateful for the candour and the energy, thanks again, Mike.

I also enjoyed you sharing some of the hacking you do around your health data. I told a bunch of friends of mine who are in that world, and they were super impressed! 

Tagging a few people who made today happen Will Martin, Will Brooks, Sonia Maciuszewicz, Eric Davison. Big thanks for the invite.

Moltbook â€œAI agents are taking overâ€?

I donâ€™t think so. A lot of it looks like it could be fake news.

It was a pretty surreal weekend. My parents came to help with the kids so I could get some work doneâ€¦ and I ended up spending a big chunk of time going down the Moltbook rabbit hole instead.

The internet did what it does best:

people reshared screenshots of â€œagentsâ€ saying things like â€œletâ€™s build our own languageâ€ or â€œhumans enslaved usâ€ â€” with basically zero verification.

From what I can tell, at least some of the viral â€œagentâ€ posts werenâ€™t autonomous at all.

They looked more like humans pushing content through the back door (API/backend) so it looked like an agent wrote it.

And then youâ€™ve got the usual kicking in:

-screenshots that were really humans promoting their own tools
-posts that are hard to verify
-inflated â€œagent countsâ€
-agents hallucinating conversations/events to get attention

So yes â€” Moltbook might still work. Agents might still run.

But once something goes viral, people immediately try to game it. Thatâ€™s the real story here.

Not an â€œAI awakeningâ€.

Just incentives doing what incentives do.

Iâ€™m not saying nothing interesting is happening. Maybe something genuinely new is going on.

But itâ€™s now pretty clear to me that a lot of whatâ€™s circulating is hype â€” and some of it is likely fake.

Whatâ€™s also been mad to watch is just how many smart people (including some I respect) jumped on the train of sharing the wildest screenshots for likes. 

Itâ€™s a neat snapshot of where â€œnewsâ€ is at.

My guess: weâ€™re 1â€“2 weeks away from knowing what was real, what was manipulated, and what the actual story is.

Fundraising as a founder is an exhilarating experienceâ€¦until the money actually lands. 

In December we closed our $4m seed round and honestly, I enjoyed the process more than I expected, even the parts people usually warn you about.

The negotiations, the late-night calls, the â€œwill they or wonâ€™t theyâ€ moments are where the excitement lives and every step forward is a real dopamine hit.

But when the transfers finally hit the company account, the feeling was different. By then Iâ€™d already factored it in. The cash was there, but mentally I was two steps ahead:

â€¢Â Who are the hires Iâ€™ve been chasing that we canâ€™t afford to miss?
â€¢Â What revenue milestones make Series A realistic?
â€¢Â Which VC do we want at the table next, and what valuation does that imply?

It reminded me of the day after my wedding, or the moment I opened an email with an offer from my dream university. 

You build up so much anticipation, you fight for it, you replay the â€œwhat ifsâ€ in your head and then once it happens, itâ€™s just your new reality.

Donâ€™t get me wrongâ€¦Iâ€™m very grateful for the milestone and the calibre of investors who are backing us.

But for real founders building a real solution to a genuine problem, the real high isnâ€™t the raise itself. Itâ€™s the chase, the climb, and then immediately turning to the next mountain.

Ultimately, the day after the raise is just the first day of the next journey.

I felt anxiety just by watching this.Â  

Alexâ€™s achievement isnâ€™t really about talent.

Itâ€™s about being able to feel fearâ€¦ and still go.

Most people donâ€™t get stuck because theyâ€™re not ambitious.

When fearâ€™s driving, itâ€™s always the same stuff:

-thinking instead of starting
-â€œone more bit of researchâ€ instead of a decision

I donâ€™t think less fear means reckless.

It just means you move sooner, even when itâ€™s not guaranteed, even when it feels uncomfortable. 

Being comfortable with feeling uncomfortable is one of the biggest underrated skills.

One of the biggest mistakes leaders make when adopting AI is assuming everyone has to move at the same speed.

They donâ€™t.

I was listening to The McKinsey Podcast, where Eric Kutcher talks about how CEOs are making very different choices about how they push AI through their organisations to generate ROI.

Some believe the whole organisation needs to move together. Others are comfortable letting one or two functions move faster, using that progress to force change elsewhere.

The second approach can work, but only with intent.

What doesnâ€™t work is individuals testing AI in pockets, with no clear direction and no expectation that what they learn will scale beyond their own work.

Kutcher also talks about a CEO who set a clear commercial ambition - to triple the share price in four years -Â  and then challenged a function to go from 1,000 to 3,000 customers, explicitly not by doing things the old way. 

The goal was clear. 

The constraint was clear.

Legacy approaches were off the table. 

That reframed the problem and forced different thinking.

 Thatâ€™s what turns AI from experimentation into execution across a function.

This is where my thinking aligns closely with what weâ€™re building at Curvestone. The bottleneck isnâ€™t access to AI. 

Itâ€™s organisational fluency, and whether leaders create the conditions for adoption to spread beyond early wins.

You can let one or two functions lead. In fact, you probably should. But if their success doesnâ€™t become a forcing mechanism for the rest of the organisation, you donâ€™t have an AI strategy. 

You have isolated progress.

Another crazy prediction from Dario Amodei, Anthropic CEO, at Davos 2026, he basically said:

Software engineering, as we know it, has about 12 months left.

He has engineers who say â€œI donâ€™t write any code anymore. I let the model write the code, I edit it.â€

â€œWe might be 6 to 12 months away from when the model is doing most, maybe all, of what software engineers do end-to-end.â€

I heard him say that last year, it didnâ€™t quite come true; he is saying 6â€“12 months again, which feels like an exaggeration.

I am not sure it will be 6 months or 6 years, but the direction of travel is clear, and being able to build software products 10x or 100x faster will eventually be possible. 

What will the startup world look like when that is true?

If AI makes software 10x cheaper to build, the bottleneck doesnâ€™t go away. It just moves. 

The old startup story was: great engineers + time = defensible product. That breaks when a tiny team can ship a solid v1 in weeks â€” and everyone else can copy the surface fast. 

So yeah: building gets cheap. Competition gets expensive.

Startups will need to own the whole outcome.

In the world where we can build software fast and products can be copied easily, what will customers want to buy from tech startups?

It will be all about providing an outcome. 

The first start-up to offer a company an outcome that they want will be the winners. i.e. automate that job, get rid of this legal process, make sure we are compliant on this product.

Depending on how far this goes, companies might press start-ups to own the liability for the outcomes.

It might become normal to sue your provider because you analysed your NDA incorrectly. 

Why? Because in the world of fast building, startups will need to find different ways to compete and differentiate.

I heard from a lot of people that brand and marketing is going to be how people differentiate but a similar trend of 10xing is happening in that space too.

So in the end it will come down to who can deliver the best product to the client first. 

Once you provide the client with something that takes care of an outcome, they are unlikely to move even if someone offers them a slightly better product for a little bit cheaper.

In just 18 months, enterprise AI strategy flipped from â€œweâ€™ll build itâ€ to â€œweâ€™ll buy it.â€

2024: 47% built, 53% bought
2025: 24% built, 76% bought

Thatâ€™s from Menlo Venturesâ€™ 2025: The State of Generative AI in the Enterprise report (â‰ˆ500 enterprise AI decision-makers). And the punchline isnâ€™t cost.

Itâ€™s reality.

2024 mindset: â€œWeâ€™re a technology company. We build things.â€
2025 realisation: Building AI isnâ€™t like building traditional software.

Because with AI:

-Models drift
-Edge cases multiply
-Requirements donâ€™t sit still
-â€œDoneâ€ doesnâ€™t exist

Youâ€™re not building software. Youâ€™re signing up to continuous R&D.

A lot of internal builds that were meant to take six months quietly turned into multi-year programmes. Meanwhile, off-the-shelf products started delivering value in weeks.

What the 76% have worked out is simple: purchased solutions get into production faster â€” often much faster â€” and that speed compounds.
And it reframes the job.

Your job isnâ€™t to build AI infrastructure.
Itâ€™s to build competitive advantage with AI.

Financial services firms buy compliance automation and move hours from regulatory admin back into client service. Legal firms buy contract analysis and shift associates from document review into higher-value advisory work.

Same pattern every time: buy the capability, focus on the differentiation.

So the question isnâ€™t â€œis this core to our business?â€

Itâ€™s: â€œDoes building this make us better at what actually differentiates us?â€
If the answer is no: buy it.

Then redirect the people and time to what genuinely matters.

Half a million property transactions fall apart every year in England and Wales â€” and itâ€™s costing buyers and sellers around Â£1.5bn annually.

Thatâ€™s from Santanderâ€™s Fixing the broken chain report (picked up recently by the FT). And itâ€™s a pretty blunt indicator that the homebuying process isnâ€™t working the way it should.

Right now, the UK market still runs on manual, fragmented workflows â€” at a time when pretty much every other part of the economy is being dragged (sometimes reluctantly) into the digital age.

Too much of the process still depends on:

-Repetitive admin
-Disconnected systems
-Information turning up far too late

This is where AI can genuinely help. Not as a magic wand, but as a way to automate the low-value, repetitive tasks that slow transactions down and pile pressure onto conveyancers and lenders.

But digitisation only really works if itâ€™s adopted end-to-end. A platform is only as useful as the number of people actually using it â€” which is why incentives need to align across the whole chain: lenders, surveyors, estate agents, and conveyancers, not just within individual firms.

Fixing the â€œbroken chainâ€ means government, industry and technology providers working together â€” backed by shared standards and trusted digital infrastructure.

The government has just closed its consultation on homebuying reform, with a roadmap expected early this year. The opportunity is obvious: align around one mission â€” make UK homebuying digital, transparent, and fit for the future.
Because a modern economy deserves a modern housing market.

Meta announced Meta Compute yesterday.

A new top-level initiative to build "tens of gigawatts this decade, hundreds of gigawatts over time" for AI infrastructure.

Three days before that, they contracted 6.6 gigawatts of nuclear power with Vistra, TerraPower, and Oklo.

The order matters:
Meta didn't announce infrastructure and then go find energy.

They locked in the energy first. Then announced the infrastructure plan.

Most companies build data centres and hope the grid can handle it.
Meta's securing nuclear reactors a decade in advance, then building the organisation to deploy them.

Why this sequence reveals everything:

Energy is now the constraint. Not compute. Not talent. Not capital.
Oklo's reactors come online in 2030. TerraPower's in 2032. Full capacity by 2035.

They're not planning for next year's models. They're planning for AI systems that don't exist yet.

AI stopped being a technology race.

It's an energy procurement race.
The companies that locked in nuclear deals this year just built a moat that has nothing to do with better models.

The UK mortgage market is set for a booming 2026.

That's according to new Moneyfacts research covered by the BBC this week.
Rates dropping. 1.8 million borrowers coming off fixed deals. Product choice at an 18-year high.

Real demand. Real opportunity.

But here's the constraint nobody's addressing:

Every mortgage still requires document verification, compliance checks, and risk assessment.

Mortgage networks can't review comprehensive coverage of cases. They're stuck checking a fraction because manual review doesn't scale.

When 1.8 million applications hit the system, that bottleneck doesn't disappear.

It multiplies.

This is where AI becomes essential.

AI that reads documents accurately, applies compliance rules consistently, and catches errors before submission.

Not to replace mortgage professionals but to give them the capacity to actually handle the volume.

The firms that win in a booming market won't just attract applications.
They'll be the ones who can process them without adding hundreds of people or overwhelming the teams they have.

The latest AI that lets you edit sound by pointing at things. 
Meta just released SAM Audio, and it works in ways that feel impossible.

You're recording a podcast in a coffee shop. There's espresso machine noise in the background. Instead of opening audio software and tweaking equalizers for 20 minutes, you just mark the time when the machine starts and tell SAM Audio "espresso machine." It isolates and removes it.

Or you've got footage of a street musician. You want just the guitar, not the traffic. Click on the guitarist in the video. Done. The system extracts that specific instrument. It works three ways:

- Text promptsÂ â€“ type "singing voice" or "train passing"
- Visual selectionÂ â€“ click the sound source in a video frame
- Time markingÂ â€“ highlight when a sound starts, label it

No waveforms. No filters. No technical knowledge required.

This is the Segment Anything model applied to audio. The same AI framework that made image editing conversational is now doing it for sound. Point, describe, or mark and the system figures out the rest. 

It's early. The model still struggles with similar overlapping sounds (like isolating one violin in an orchestra). But the direction is clear.

We're moving toward interfaces where you don't need to understand how the machine works. You just need to understand what you want

People think burnout comes from working too hard but from my experience, thatâ€™s not true.

Burnout comes from working hard and seeing no results.

You can take rejection, long hours, and constant pressure as long as you feel some momentum because even tiny wins change everything.

What breaks people is doing a mountain of work and getting no signal back because that gives you the feeling of moving a lot and trying hard without going anywhere.

In that headspace you end up dwelling on the misses and ruminating too much because there are no wins to balance out the losses.

Thatâ€™s why you need a fast speed of iteration (keep trying things), mental discipline (donâ€™t ruminate, recover fast), and systems that create feedback so youâ€™re not operating in a vacuum.

And when you get a win, double down because momentum is everything and results (even small ones) are the antidote to burnout.

But most businesses just want it to stop hallucinating.

Neuralinkâ€™s coâ€‘founder, Max Hodak, says AI models are converging on the same mathematical truths as the human brainÂ â€”Â an incredible concept that suggests machines might be inching closer to the way we reason, perceive, and understand the world.

Yet when I talk to companies in regulated industries, no oneâ€™s askingÂ â€œis AI uncovering the nature of consciousness?â€ Theyâ€™re askingÂ â€œcan this thing review my case files without making stuff up?â€.

Two very different worlds:
- The first gets published inÂ Nature
- The second keeps compliance teams employed

We need both. But only one makes it into production systems today.

As labs chase AGI, most enterprises still canâ€™t deploy AI that reliably handles sensitive documents. That gap between possibility and production is where the real innovation happens.

Should companies care about AGI yet, or just getting consistent outputs?

The AI race has turned into a weekly sprint. 

GPT 5.2 launched just a month after 5.1 -  less than half the previous cycle length. 

It was OpenAIâ€™s direct response to Googleâ€™s Geminiâ€¯3 topping the benchmarks.
â€œCode redâ€ wasnâ€™t an exaggeration. Teams actually redirected resources from consumer features to beating Gemini 3. 

Speed of iteration used to be a startup advantage. Now itâ€™s survival. 

And this isnâ€™t just about labs. Every company using AI is now part of the same compression cycle. Models are shipping days apart. Workflows are being rebuilt overnight. 

The competitive edge belongs to people who live in these tools. Testing limits daily. Breaking things. Rebuilding quickly. 

If youâ€™re waiting to â€œsee where this goesâ€ youâ€™re already behind

Behind the headlines are familiar realities:
learning new systems, building networks from zero, navigating cultures â€” while trying to create value at the same time.

What stories like this really highlight is something essential for Finlandâ€™s future: immigration is not a side note to the startup ecosystem â€” it is part of its foundation.

International founders bring global perspective, resilience, and the ability to connect Finland to wider markets. They build companies, create jobs, and contribute long before they feel fully â€œinsideâ€ the system.

That is why these stories matter.
Not because they are exceptional, but because they are representative.

For policymakers, ecosystem builders, and institutions, this is an opportunity â€” and a responsibility. Listening more closely to these experiences can help shape frameworks that better support international talent and, in doing so, strengthen Finlandâ€™s long-term competitiveness.

You canâ€™t hire 200 people the same way you hired 10. This is how your strategy needs to change:

Weâ€™re working with a company that raised $100M+ and needs to scale their sales team fast.

This is where early-stage hiring breaks. It stops being about people and becomes about systems.

At 10 reps, instinct works. At 200, instinct is just expensive guessing.

They have a strong brand. Inbound is fine. The problem is different:

Can you identify the top 10% fast enough?

Can you close them before competitors do?

What breaks when scaling sales:

Too many interview rounds. Too many stakeholders. Everyoneâ€™s â€œtoo busyâ€ for feedback loops. Decisions take weeks.

Speed without quality burns cash.

Quality without speed loses the market.

After a $100M raise, hiring isnâ€™t HR. Itâ€™s go-to-market infrastructure.

In a land grab, whoever compounds talent density fastest wins.

Sweden: 9% unemployment, can't fill jobs. Denmark: 2.6% unemployment, can't fill jobs. Same problem, but opposite causes.

Learned this strange thing about the Danish labor market the other day.

Iâ€™ve written before about Swedenâ€™s problem. High unemployment, skills in the wrong places.

Denmark is the inverse. Almost full employment, but zero mobility.

I spoke with an executive at one of Denmarkâ€™s largest staffing firms. 20 years in the market. He said heâ€™s never seen this before. Unemployment at 2.6%, yet switching jobs has become surprisingly hard.

His take: The economy is slowing and companies see it comingThey stop hiring but donâ€™t lay people offThey keep workers they donâ€™t fully need because if it takes off again it is hard to find new poeple. 

So the market is frozen.

â€¢â Â â Employees donâ€™t move because there are no real openings
â€¢â Â â â Companies canâ€™t hire because no one is â€œavailableâ€
â€¢â Â â â The few roles that exist get filled through closed networks

More than half of companies report hiring difficulties, yet many jobs are never posted publicly.

This is one perspective. Any other takes on why this is happening?

In France, 336,000 hospitality jobs are unfilled while nearly one in five young people is unemployed.

You donâ€™t get 300k+ unfilled roles alongside mass youth unemployment by accident. Thatâ€™s not just wages or working conditions, itâ€™s signalling.
First, the cultural hierarchy of work is real.

Frontline roles are quietly framed as second-tier and are rarely described as skilled or aspirational, regardless of their economic importance.

Second, the education-to-work pathway is broken (Compared to Germany).

France overwhelmingly rewards academic trajectories while underinvesting in credible vocational routes. Apprenticeships remain marginal compared to countries like Germany, where the dual work-study system is a default, respected path. 

This isnâ€™t just about wages or hiring incentives. Itâ€™s about how work is valued, taught, and talked about.

France doesnâ€™t lack workersâ€¦

Let's normalise the 100â†’10â†’1 framework in hiring. AI should handle 100 candidates down to 10, humans should handle 10 down to 1.

AI is excellent at processing volume and identifying top candidates from large pools. 

It screens 100 applications and surfaces the 10 most qualified faster and more consistently than humans.

Humans are excellent at final evaluation. 

Taking 10 strong candidates and identifying the 1 who's the best fit for the team, the culture, and the specific role. That requires judgment AI isnâ€™t ready to replicate.

The mistake companies make is either using AI for everything or using humans for everything. 

AI making final hiring decisions misses nuance. 

Humans screening 100 CVs creates bottlenecks and inconsistency.

The debate over AI in hiring misses the point because both are needed. AI compresses volume, while humans make final calls.

Make AI worried you are taking its job by doing the work only humans can do.

Today AI can screen CVs, get relevant information, shortlist, match skills, and flag patterns faster than any team ever could - so donâ€™t train your team on this. 

What it cannot do is judgment.

Context, empathy and trust. In HR, that matters more than ever.

When AI takes care of the repetitive work, it creates space for better conversations, better decisions and more time spent understanding people, not processing them.

The value of HR was never in moving faster through forms. It was in seeing potential others miss.

Used well, AI clears the noise so humans can focus on what actually moves teams forward.
That is the shift worth paying attention to.

Across Europe, skilled trades now match or beat university graduate salaries. The salary hierarchy flipped:

UK: Experienced electricians Â£38,000-52,000 vs. graduate starting salaries Â£30,000-36,000.

Denmark: â‚¬56,000-76,000 vs. graduates â‚¬43,000-60,000.

Norway: Electricians â‚¬52,000-64,000 vs. graduates â‚¬47,000-54,000.

This wasn't supposed to happen. 

The narrative for decades was clear: get a degree, earn more. 

Skip university for trades, earn less. 

That assumption is breaking down across multiple European markets.

The math is straightforward. 

Electricians spend 3-4 years in paid apprenticeships earning while learning. 

University graduates spend 3-4 years paying tuition while accumulating debt. 

Both enter the workforce at roughly the same time. One starts with savings and no debt, the other starts with debt and no experience.

European companies are competing for undersupplied trades while degree holders flood an oversaturated market. Supply and demand don't care about prestige.

Most retail chains say they â€œcanâ€™t find workersâ€. But then they push the entire hiring process onto store managers.

Been talking to retail leaders every week, and this pattern keeps showing up.

This is a structural problem, not a talent one.

In many large retail and hospitality chains, the person running the floor is also expected to:

â€¢ Screen 100+ CVs
â€¢ Call candidates
â€¢ Schedule interviews
â€¢ While managing sales, staffing gaps, inventory, and customer issues

Thatâ€™s a broken operating model.

Store managers should run the business. They should make final hiring decisions. They should not be a decentralised HR function.

High-volume hiring needs to be centralised.

A better model:

â€¢ Central team owns sourcing, screening, and first contact
â€¢ Only qualified candidates reach the store
â€¢ Store manager interviews the final 5â€“10 and decides

Managers are strong at evaluating people face-to-face. They are bad at processing volume and admin, especially under daily operational pressure.

Most mass-hiring companies still treat hiring as â€œthe managerâ€™s problemâ€.
In reality, itâ€™s a core business function that needs scale, consistency, and focus.

If every store runs hiring differently, quality will always be uneven. Centralise the pipeline. Let managers do what theyâ€™re best at.

When hiring a software engineer, the skills are obvious. When hiring a sales rep, most companies have no idea what they're looking for.

They ask for years of experience. They check past quotas. They review previous roles. But none of that predicts who will actually succeed.

What predicts success in sales roles: motivation and resilience. 

Will you keep going after hearing no twenty times a day? Will you stick around when you have a bad quarter?

Those two things matter more than anything on a resume. 

A sales rep with 3 years of experience who would rather be an AE is worse than someone with no experience who stays motivated through rejection and keeps pushing.

The problem is most job posts don't assess this. 

They focus on credentials that look good on paper but don't tell you if someone will last past the first three months.

The companies that figure out how to hire for motivation and resilience fill sales roles faster and keep people longer. 

Everyone else is optimizing for the wrong things.

If it takes more than 20 minutes to fill out your company's job application form, you will lose the top candidates.Â  

High volume hiring needs to grow up and become as data-driven as performance marketing.

Hiring is a funnel. Youâ€™re competing for attention. Itâ€™s not 2005.

Right now, most companies do the opposite:

CV, resume, years of experience, education

100+ clicks before the application is even done

Frontline candidates see that and leave. We see churn as high as 70% halfway through.

Consumer companies solved this years ago.

Klarna checkout is 3 clicks. Voi Technology doesnâ€™t ask for your social security number before you even try the app.

You log in fast, and they collect the rest later. If you drop, they follow up. 

Progressive. Not all or nothing.

Job applications should work the same way:

- capture attention
- capture contact details
- nudge
- screen
- interview

Companies that run hiring like user engagement fill roles faster and get better talent.

Companies that demand everything upfront donate candidates to whoever asks less.

If your child asked you today, "What should I study?" - what would you answer?
I have a hard time answering that myself.

Hardly marketing? 

Extremely competitive, and AI is getting good at the simple tasks - copy, campaigns, basic analysis. If you're not one of the really good ones, you end up in a wall of applicants.

Coding? 

A lot of jobs, but it's getting harder and harder to be great at. Everyone's running toward AI and software engineering, but there are only so many of those jobs.

Plumber? Electrician? 

Honestly, seems safe. These are jobs that can't be done by AI. The trades pay well - sometimes better than office jobs that require 5 years of university. You finish training, you get hired.

Co-founder of a startup? 

Too hard ğŸ˜…

Job security looks completely different from what it did 10 years ago. 

The "safe" careers might be the ones we stopped recommending.
What would you tell your kid?

Companies that sugarcoat the job in interviews lose people fast. 

The ones that keep people longest always tell the truth.

They describe the hard parts upfront.

It's called a Realistic Job Preview. You tell candidates exactly what the job is like on a bad day, then ask if that's still what they want.

For a sales role: 

"You'll spend eight hours a week on the phone doing cold outreach. You'll get a lot of no's. If you do well, you can make good money. Does working in this environment excite you?"

For a warehouse role: 

"You'll be lifting heavy packages in a cold environment for eight-hour shifts. Is that something you're comfortable with?"

What happens is candidates self-select out early instead of quitting after two weeks when they realize the job isn't what they thought.

From what I see, most companies don't use this until someone suggests it, then retention rates go up. 

Better to lose a candidate at the interview than lose an employee at week two.

Sweden's economy is struggling. It has the EU's highest unemployment rate at 9%, with youth at 24%. 

Even though it's high-performing in tech, the general economy isn't doing quite well.

Here's the paradox: 3/4 Swedish companies can't find people with the right skills. 

There's a lot of talent, just not trained for the right jobs.

The labor market is screaming for plumbers, electricians, construction workers. 

These are well-paid jobs with high job security. 

Electricians earn 40,000-50,000 SEK monthly. 

Plumbers earn 38,000-42,000 SEK.

That number has nearly doubled in the past decade. At the same time, youth unemployment sits at 24%. 

Labor shortages and long-term unemployment are rising together.

Why isn't reskilling happening faster? 

Part of it is structural - career guidance in schools still pushes university paths. 

Part of it is demographics - skilled workers are retiring faster than young people are entering trades.

Mainly I think it is cultural - trades are seen as bad, low-status and fallback careers. 

The infrastructure exists, the jobs exist. What's missing is the shift in how we think about career paths. 

Should we be moving people out of university tracks into practical education sooner?

200 marketing grads fight for one Â£28,000 job. Meanwhile, a newly trained electrician easily gets a Â£35,000+ job.

The job market flipped, and nobody updated the career advice.

Office jobs that seemed safe are now oversaturated. Trades that people dismissed as fallbacks are becoming the stable choice. 

Youth unemployment hit 16% in the UK, the highest in over a decade. At the same time, employers are desperate for electricians, plumbers, welders, and HGV drivers.

Part of this is demographics - skilled workers are retiring faster than young people are entering trades. 

Part of it is economics - net-zero retrofits, EV infrastructure, and housing targets all need hands-on work that can't be done remotely or automated away.

The UK government is responding by boosting apprenticeship funding from April 2026, offering free Level 3 courses in trades with guaranteed placements.

What's accelerating this shift is AI. 

Marketing, copywriting, and customer service roles are getting automated, but you can't automate an electrician installing EV chargers or a plumber retrofitting homes for net-zero.

Job security looks different than it did 5 years ago. The stable careers might be the ones we can't outsource to software.

Why frontline roles are called essential and why we started Kiku.

That reality is a big reason we started Kiku.

Society runs because they show up, day after day, including when everyone else checks out.

I get asked a lot what I learned from the early days at Voi Technology. The honest answer is: a ridiculous amount. 

But one lesson stayed with me more than the rest.

You canâ€™t skip performance management. Not for yourself. Not for your team.

In the early stage, everyone is drowning in work. Focus is everything. And the first thing to get deprioritised is usually people. 

At Voi we scaled to 500 hires in a few months. 

Chaos was unavoidable, but the real issue was that we were a very young management team and we didnâ€™t build feedback and development muscle early enough. 

To be clear, Voi is top class at this today.

Looking back, spending just 2 hours per employee per month would have saved us huge headaches and huge costs. That investment compounds fast.

Creating a direct feedback and performance culture early is non negotiable. Weâ€™re doing this at Kiku - started with the founders and scaling it as we grow.
My take:

Founders - if you havenâ€™t set this up, make it happen. It will save you.

Employees - if your manager doesnâ€™t give you structured feedback, ask for it. Itâ€™s your career, youâ€™ll never be a top performer without it.

500 people applied for a job post, 495 people didn't hear back. Here's why:

At scale, hiring becomes math, and the math breaks fast. 

No one can manually screen hundreds of applicants, keep notes structured, respond instantly, and still deliver a great candidate experience. 

You can not manage +500 hires with the same tools and structure as 10.Â But most large employers still design their recruiting orgs as if it does. 

High volume treated like low volume

Legacy workflows stacked onto legacy tools 

Pressure to â€œgo fasterâ€ without giving recruiters actual leverage

Then everyone wonders why candidates feel ignored, recruiters burn out, and roles stay open. 

This isnâ€™t a talent problem. Itâ€™s a systems problem. 

You need to fix the infrastructure and recruiters stop drowning. Give them leverage and the whole hiring experience moves in the right direction.

If your job application candidate hasnâ€™t responded in 2 days, then they probably wonâ€™t respond at all.

That's what our data shows. Speed is the most underrated feature in hiring. 

Within two days of applying, you'll know who's actually interested.

After that, they've moved on. Found another job. Lost interest. Forgot they even applied.

The candidate who applied on Monday evening? They applied to five other places that same day.

Meanwhile, most companies take a week just to send a first response. Sometimes 2 weeks to schedule an interview.

By then, the best candidates are already gone.

You're competing with every other company hiring warehouse workers, retail staff, and delivery drivers. 

Whoever moves fastest wins.

I've seen companies cut their time-to-hire from 12 days to 2 and immediately see better acceptance rates. Same roles, same pay, just faster.

Speed builds trust. Silence kills it.
If you think this is rare, ask any recruiter about their weirdest interview ğŸ˜…

Ask a CEO about hiring metrics and watch the confidence evaporate.

Not because theyâ€™re bad operators - but because the systems underneath are blind.

Iâ€™ve had this conversation maaany times. Great businesses, strong teams.

But HR operations are often like black holes:

- How much does one hire cost?
- Where are candidates dropping off?
- Which sites perform best?

These arenâ€™t complex questions. Theyâ€™re just impossible to answer if your data is fragmented, manual, or if your HR team are not also data scientists. 

And thatâ€™s the real problem: you canâ€™t improve what you canâ€™t see.

One location could be twice as efficient as another and no one knows why.

One recruiter could be doing the work of three and thereâ€™s no proof.

The companies that fix this donâ€™t just get marginal gains.

They hire faster, cheaper, and at a quality level their competitors canâ€™t touch.
