How to Do LinkedIn Outreach the Right Way

Losing a LinkedIn account hurts more than losing a domain. You can buy a new domain and keep going. But a profile â€” that's your network, reputation, and trust. Losing it sets you back.

LinkedIn has become less pleasant in recent years because of spam, but if a decision-maker has a LinkedIn and no email â€” why not use this channel?

Here are three rules I use in practice ğŸ‘‡

1. A warmed-up account

1) No more than 20 connects per day and 100 per week. Raise the limit gradually â€” by +2 per day.
2) Get Premium: paying users generate more trust.
3) The account should look "alive": About section, experience, skills, certifications, photo, posts.

â•The more complete the profile, the higher the connection acceptance rate.

2. Messages under 100 words
In a connection request it's better to write nothing â€” it almost always kills conversion. The exception is if you have a real shared touchpoint (like meeting at a conference).

First message:

- short,
- clear,
- no fluff.

One thought, one value, one action.

3. "Show up" before connecting
We don't send an invite cold. We run a sequence:

1) Visited their profile â€” the person sees a notification.
2) The next day, liked a post.
3) Endorsed 1â€“2 skills.
Only then sent the connect.

This creates a recognition effect: "I've seen this person before."
Conversion is higher than with mass campaigns.

LinkedIn outreach isn't about "spray invites and forget." Everything matters: limits, warm-up, profile, message structure.

Need help setting it up? DM me âœŒï¸

You wonâ€™t be profitable if you canâ€™t answer the â€œchicken or eggâ€ question.

In our case: scripts or database - what comes first, and what matters more?

Let me explain with an example.

Imagine we sell premium Cuban cigars - top-tier product. The goal is to sell.

We have two business development managers.

One is responsible for *who we sell to*. He studies the ideal customer profile, identifies relevant communities and clubs, negotiates with specialty tobacco shops - but doesnâ€™t dive deep into sales psychology.

The other focuses on *how we sell*. He crafts the perfect pitch, polishes the offer down to the smallest detail, incorporates every psychological trigger - so sharp that even Robert Cialdini would be impressed. And then he goes out and tries to sell to fitness enthusiasts, pregnant women, and people with asthma.

Who will actually make sales?

Even the most personalized, research-backed script is completely useless if we miss our buyer profile.

If thereâ€™s no need - not even an indirect one. The best script in the world wonâ€™t help.

Are we saying scripts donâ€™t matter? Not at all.

Scripts increase conversion.
But a well-built database gives conversion its foundation.

All the other tactics and growth hacks - like optimizing the number of touchpoints per contact are secondary.

First, build your database around your ICP.
Then refine your PMF inside your scripts.

Thatâ€™s when sales start to scale.

Gold-standard outreach script structure

Tens (and hundreds) of thousands of scripts have passed through my hands over 4+ years in sales - hereâ€™s a sane structure that helps you build solid email cadences/sequences.

1) Subject line
Goal: get the email opened
Desired outcome: the reader opens because something struck a chord

2) Preview line / Opening paragraph
Goal: hook them, spark curiosity, stick in their head
Desired outcome: â€œAlrightâ€¦ what is this person offering me?â€

3) Paragraph 2
Goal: quickly explain the value, qualify relevance
Desired outcome:
â€œInteresting - we donâ€™t have this right now / we do, but itâ€™s not working well,â€ or
â€œNo pain here becauseâ€¦â€

4) Paragraph 3
Goal: move to the target action
Desired outcome: they agree to get extra materials, or they say no (with a clear reason)

Example
{Hi|Hello|Hey} {{first_name}},

We had a booth at Web Summit, Iâ€™m with*company*. I was hoping to connect with {{company_name}}, but looks like we didnâ€™t get a chance to meet.

We help businesses simplify their global payments by letting them accept stablecoins and crypto, automate mass payouts and instantly convert it to fiat. Companies like *1*, *2*, and *3* use our fully licensed (VASP, MSB, MiCA) platform to cut banking fees by up to 70% and process over $2B annually.

{Worth a quick chat?|Should I share a short one-pager?|Would it be a bad idea to connect?|Is this something youâ€™d be open to exploring?}

{Cheers|Best|Kind regards|Sincerely|Take care|Looking forward},
*Name*

Recommendations
- Donâ€™t ask for a call right away - first validate interest
- Use spintax / variations - do everything you can to improve deliverability
- Remove spam-trigger words (â€œfreeâ€, â€œ!!!â€, etc.) - they wonâ€™t help your conversions
- Read your script 10+ times - and again the next day; youâ€™ll always find something to improve
- Donâ€™t blame the script for low conversions - build a relevant list first

Framework for outreach

Lately I have started diving more actively into frameworks, of which there are a million thousand billion. Digging into each one is very tedious and does not make much sense, so I will show a kind of base that can be used to build a structure.

1. Value Proposition Matrix.
This is a list of VPs that we test in hypotheses. Essentially, this is what we sell, our product and its key features. Without a VP there is no point in doing anything further, so it is critically important to find PMF (otherwise why do active outreach at this stage).

A VP consists of 3 points:
Job to be Done: what task the client is trying to accomplish
Pain/Friction: what gets in the way (expensive, risky, unstable)
Outcome/Metric: what â€œbetterâ€ looks like (in measurable terms)

2. ICP.
This includes everything except vertical and sub-vertical: role (primary, influencer, economic buyer), revenue, size, etc. Here we define our audience, who we are writing to, and specify all the criteria we need.

Important: 1 ICP = 1 hypothesis.

3. Vertical & Sub-Vertical. Everything is simple here, we define the target vertical and sub-vertical, in other words, the industry.

4. Forming a hypothesis.
Â Â We specify everything defined above, plus:

Pain: what exactly hurts (specifically)
Signal: how we will understand that the hypothesis is alive (measurable, for example â€œready to give access to the admin panelâ€)

5. TAL (Target Account List).
Â Â Our list of accounts that fully match our ICP. Important: if you cannot explain which hypothesis it is testing, it is just a lead list.

6. Scripts. Everything is simple here. The script should contain the VP and be oriented toward the ICP and its pain. More details about scripts can be found in this post.

7. Calls. Each call is tied to a hypothesis and an account from the TAL.

8. Metrics. Metrics are needed to answer: â€œvalidate, kill, or refine?â€. How to use them: look at metrics by hypothesis, not â€œoverall salesâ€.

Typical signals:

* pain confirmation rate (share of conversations where the person confirms the pain themselves, not just politely nods)
* interest rate (percentage of conversations where the person showed proactive interest, not just listened)
* opportunities / follow-ups (share of conversations where a next step appeared)
* speed of signal acquisition (how many conversations it took to first hear confirmed pain, get the first follow-up, see pattern repetition)

If pain confirmation is low or absent, the hypothesis is not valid. If there is interest but no next steps, the VP needs fixing. If the speed of signal acquisition is low, we are pulling SQL out of thin air.

As a result, we either discard the hypothesis, or expand our TAL for a fuller picture, or recognize the hypothesis as valid and scale it.

For aviation operators, regulators and safety teams, this is a powerful example of how high-fidelity flight data can improve situational awareness and post-event analysis.

Last nightâ€™s viral â€œflight pathâ€ over Florida is a good reminder of a growing issue in aviation data: spoofing.

An aircraft labeled â€œVANCE 1â€ appeared onÂ at least oneÂ public flight-tracking platform and seemed to trace a carefully choreographed pattern over Mar-a-Lago. The image was reportedly created by injecting false ADS-B data and manipulating reported altitudes to â€œdrawâ€ a picture over time â€” even making it appear as if Air Force One was involved.

It looked real.
But it wasnâ€™t.

This kind of spoofing highlights a fundamental challenge in aviation data today: traditional flight tracking networks rely on unauthenticated broadcasts that can be injected, replayed, or manipulated.

GPS spoofing at the satellite level is a threat no system can fully stop â€” but with Wingbitsâ€™ secure, high-precision devices, attempts to feed false positions into the network become far more difficult.

Aviation data only works when it can be trusted.

Did Wingbits capture an aircraft above Crimea?
Yes, but no.

Pilots have experienced it firsthand: GPS interference forcing crews onto backup navigation systems, disrupting runway operations and straining air traffic control. 

Over the past two years, GPS interference has increased in both frequency and scale, affecting thousands of flights worldwide. What was once a rare technical issue is becoming a recurring operational risk driven by interference, jamming, and spoofing.

The implications go far beyond aviation. GPS underpins power grids, financial systems, telecommunications, and emergency services. Yet the system was never designed to withstand sustained disruption. When positioning data becomes unreliable, the impact is immediate and widespread.

Spoofing in action:Â one Wingbits screenshot shows an airplane seemingly â€œjumpingâ€ from Romania to the Black Sea, a clear example of satellite signal spoofing that could confuse operators relying only on GPS.

For aviation, the takeaway is clear: resilience depends on visibility, verification, and redundancy.

While no network can prevent sophisticated GPS spoofing at the satellite source, Wingbitsâ€™ highly accurate, tamper-resistant receivers make it significantly harder for bad actors to inject false positions into the network.

If your data comes from networks without safeguards at the ground-station level, what other blind spots and integrity risks are already baked into that data?

For a long time, the moat in data businesses was software. Thatâ€™s changing fast.

Today, software is cheap, fast, and easy to copy. The harder part â€” and the real advantage â€” is building physical infrastructure and pairing it with a data layer that actually gets smarter over time.

Weâ€™ve seen this play out before:

-Weather data mattered once sensors were everywhere

-Waze worked because drivers became live sensors

-AIS, ADS-B, seismic networks all follow the same rule: coverage first, software second

-Thatâ€™s how Wingbits is built.

We operate a decentralized network of modular ground stations that capture data others simply canâ€™t replicateâ€” in traditional terrestrial blindspots and in low level environments. 

On top of it, weâ€™re building an AI-driven data layer that keeps evolving:

Continuously enriching and validating raw data

Surfacing patterns, anomalies, and context

Improving as the network grows, not just when code ships

The edge isnâ€™t just â€œbetter software.â€
Itâ€™s intelligence built on trusted, real-world data that most networks donâ€™t have.

When data really matters, it becomes physical first â€” and intelligent on top of it.

Positioning the value of AI is easy. âœ… 
Positioning the deployment path is easy. âœ… 

The hard part. Driving adoption. ğŸ¤¯  And AI is different. Workers are now being asked to engage with technology in a very different way. 

This is behavioural change. Here is how we think about it at Covecta â© 

1. We build champions, not users
2. We shift the way you work, not just the tools
3. We measure what the business actually cares about

Horizontal players won't do this for you. They don't understand the way you work. And quite frankly they get their scale through low penetration across a big market. They don't need you either.

Tanaya Jasubhai is completely transforming the deployment and adoption of AI across Financial Services Teams with Covecta

Here is the challenge we have identified: 

1ï¸âƒ£ Most businesses started off by deploying AI offered from an existing incumbent provider. This was typically a generic/horizontal solution. The dream was sold, the reality very different

2ï¸âƒ£ Deep domain activities and tasks were not executed with the right precision or context

3ï¸âƒ£ Adoption was low and value wasn't delivered

4ï¸âƒ£ But it wasn't just the technology, it was also the fact that behaviours didn't change

5ï¸âƒ£ Teams hit a roadblock

What next?

The companies seeing real ROI are not the ones with the most AI. They are the ones with the most focused AI. Vertical. Workflow-specific. With intentional change baked in from day one.

The question is not only "are you using AI?" and "what AI?"

It is also "have you actually changed how people work?"

Banks are calling 2026 "the year of agentic AI."

But only 8.6% of enterprises have AI agents in production.

The headlines paint a different picture. JPMorgan has 400+ use cases. BNY is building "digital employees."

McKinsey now has 60,000 employees - 25,000 are AI Agents.

So where's the disconnect?

Most institutions are trapped in what I call "pilot purgatory" - endless experimentation, limited production value.

The technology isn't the blocker. Agentic AI can genuinely reason through multi-step workflows, handle exceptions and adapt to context.

Integration is.

60% of AI leaders cite legacy systems as their primary barrier. In financial services, those systems aren't just outdated - they're woven into regulatory processes, risk frameworks and compliance workflows built over decades.

Generic AI platforms stumble on this complexity. They can't distinguish why a flagged transaction needs different handling in AML vs fraud contexts. They miss the nuance between jurisdictional requirements.

The institutions breaking through aren't throwing more compute at the problem.

They're selecting platforms purpose-built for financial services - tools that understand the domain, not just the data.

What's been the biggest barrier for your team moving AI from pilot to production?

#AgenticAI #Covecta

The reason we feel friction when using AI is that weâ€™re still approaching it like traditional software. Seamless adoption requires three changes in how we work:

1/ Get comfortable working conversationally. Instead of asking a question and getting an answer, we need to complete tasks through dialogue. That means letting the AI ask questions back to refine and improve the output. Treat it like a colleague, not a search engine.

2/ Learn how to communicate intent. Prompting isnâ€™t that different from managing a team. You have to get better at expressing what you want so you get the outcome youâ€™re looking for. With AI, the key is context: your prompt needs enough information for the model to produce a complete answer. The challenge with out-of-the-box solutions is they donâ€™t know your world, so you compensate with more direction. The more specialised the system, the more context is baked in, and the less you need to explain yourself.

3/ Accept that most AI systems arenâ€™t deterministic. Ask the same thing twice and you wonâ€™t always get the same result. To trust the outcome, you need to understand how it was produced and what it was based on. That means putting guardrails in place so the AI can surface the sources and reasoning behind its answer.

None of this is particularly complicated, but it is a different way of using software than most of us are used to.

Like every meaningful technology shift before it, the organisations that get value arenâ€™t the ones chasing features. Theyâ€™re the ones that take the time to learn how to work with it properly.

Thereâ€™s a lot of energy being spent on timelines for AGI. The arguments are interesting, but theyâ€™re not especially useful.

What is useful is what people building AI systems are actually focusing on right now.

For most organisations, especially in financial services, the real problem is a lack of systems that can reason through messy, day-to-day work - exceptions, judgement calls, incomplete data sets, and non-standard processes.

Thatâ€™s where existing SaaS tools struggle. Not because theyâ€™re bad products, but because they were never designed for that kind of work.

On the other hand, agentic systems are. They operate inside defined domains, reason in context, and handle variation without everything breaking.

Thatâ€™s why this phase of AI is likely to last. Itâ€™s not a stepping stone people rush through to reach AGI but solving the real operational challenges where businesses see value.

Some firms are already investing in foundations, data, and operating models that assume agents will be part of the workflow. 

For those who havenâ€™t, you probably still have time. But waiting doesnâ€™t freeze the field, it just means others are learning faster.

In most industries, the next decade wonâ€™t be defined by who â€œcrackedâ€ AGI. Itâ€™ll be defined by who figured out how to use agents well.

Bill of Lading. Air Waybill. Import Documents. Health Certificates. Orders. Invoices.

Each shipment generates 5-8 documents that need to match each other perfectly. 

Every company that makes, moves, or sells physical goods is still manually checking and matching these documents with each other and their ERP data.

Why does this still happen in 2026?

Because these documents arrive in different formats (PDFs, scans, emails), from different parties (suppliers, freight forwarders, customs), at different times. And they never match perfectly - same product, different descriptions.

Companies have tried to automate this for years. It failed because traditional systems can't handle the variation. Rules-based software needs exact matches. Reality doesn't work that way.

Someone (often an entire team) has to verify they all match. Line by line. 

Delays due to discrepancies. 

AI finally solves this. 

It understands context and variation. It matches documents intelligently, flags genuine exceptions, and auto-resolves the large volume. 

Your people focus on the genuine exceptions that need judgment.

Bad data quality is killing growth in manufacturing and logistics.

Wrong order quantities. Outdated inventory. Typos in addresses. All because someone's typing it in by hand.

I see this constantly. Company's growing, orders picking up. Then it falls apart. Wrong shipments. Lost customers. Costs spiral.

Walk into any warehouse and ask what slows them down. They'll tell you - half their day is correcting upstream mistakes or re-entering information that already exists somewhere else.

This isn't a people problem. They're copying from an email into the ERP, then a spreadsheet, then the WMS or TMS. Five formats, three naming conventions. Of course mistakes happen.

When you're small, you brute force it. Someone catches errors, you reconcile manually. Painful but manageable.

Growth multiplies the problem faster than you can hire. 50 orders to 500, and that annoying error rate becomes existential.

This is what AI should solve. Not replacing people - automating tedious work nobody should do manually. Reading orders, pulling data, checking everything matches.

Fix the data quality and you can actually grow.

2026 is going to test a few assumptions we all made last year.

Across the industry, 2025 was full of big macro bets, particularly from the hyperscalers. Some of those investments will start to pay off and others may look more questionable with hindsight. But watching those outcomes unfold will be one of the defining themes of the year ahead.

At the enterprise level, I see two priorities rising to the top:

1/ Pushing agent autonomy further.

We made real progress in 2025, but the heavy lifting is still ahead. Teams are only just starting to break away from manual workflows. The gap between a helpful assistant and a genuinely autonomous agent is wider than the headlines suggest, and that journey will continue right through 2026.

2/ The growing weight of financial crime.

Every institution I speak to is feeling the same pressure: higher regulatory expectations, more complex cases, and rising operational burden. Itâ€™s a space where spend, scrutiny and urgency are all increasing. That trend wonâ€™t slow down.

Innovation in our sector is moving quickly. New capabilities are coming to market faster than most institutions expected. And every year brings surprises - usually in the places we werenâ€™t forecasting.

2026 wonâ€™t be straightforward, but it will be a year where the industry learns a lot very quickly and weâ€™ll be leading the charge at Covecta. Looking forward to the meaningful progress ahead. 

#Covecta #FinancialServices #AgenticAI
Great perspective from Harry Powell, and a clear example of how Covecta brings deep industry expertise and experience to bear alongside our agentic capabilities.

For years, enterprise software has been sold the same way.

Count the users > Buy the licences > Hope adoption catches up.

Iâ€™ve sat in more steering committees than I can remember where the conversation drifted from value to utilisation. Not because the product was bad, but because the commercial model assumed people would change how they work simply because access had been paid for.

When we started building Covectaâ€™s agents, it was obvious that a traditional SaaS pricing model didnâ€™t fit what we were asking the technology to do. Agents arenâ€™t passive tools. They donâ€™t sit on a shelf waiting to be clicked. 

So we flipped the model.

Instead of charging for seats or licences, we price based on consumption. On what the agents actually do and on the value they deliver.

That changes adoption because teams donâ€™t need a big upfront commitment just to get started. Thereâ€™s no anxiety about â€œwho gets a licenceâ€ or whether adoption justifies the spend. Anyone can use the agents, and usage finds its own level.

The impact is that you can see where the agents have real pull, like which workflows are really being used. Then those areas can be doubled down on. Others quietly fall away.

The commercial side aligns as well. Customers only pay more when the agents are doing more work, rather than for packaged features that they never use.

As usage increases the cost rises, but always in proportion to value created.

And that feels like the right direction for this next phase of enterprise technology. Less focus on access. More focus on outcomes. 

It also forces discipline on our side. If our agents arenâ€™t delivering, we donâ€™t get paid more. Thereâ€™s nowhere to hide behind shelfware or long contracts.

As agents become a common part of how work gets done in financial services and elsewhere, the old commercial assumptions from the SaaS industry will start to look increasingly out of place.

Paying for software made sense when software just sat there.
Paying for work being done feels like the future.

We often get asked how Covecta compares to something a bank could assemble in-house.

On paper, the DIY route looks tempting. The AI tooling ecosystem is powerful: models, orchestration layers, and workflow builders are all readily available.

But the constraint isnâ€™t tools. Itâ€™s time and focus.

Building means sourcing scarce engineering talent, aligning them to lending-specific workflows, and maintaining the system as the business evolves. The effort compounds quickly.

Alternatively, you can save yourself the stress and work with a provider with domain expertise, like Covecta.

Our agents come with decades of context and understanding already built in. They understand credit and lending workflows straight out of the box, which means customers can go live faster than a bespoke build would allow, with the kind of knowledge youâ€™d normally expect from a team of seasoned bankers.

And while engineering time and talent are one of the biggest constraints on building in-house, theyâ€™re one of the biggest advantages of buying. Our engineering effort compounds across customers, not within a single institution. The more we grow, the more we can invest in the product, and the better it becomes for customers, without extra time or effort required on their side.

These factors fundamentally change the cost equation.

Building has its place, and we advocate it in the right areas. But for specialist agents in lending and credit, buying isnâ€™t a shortcut. Itâ€™s usually the more rational decision.

The Super Bowl really is the advertising event of the year ğŸˆ

But with 60+ ads, how do brands know if their ad stood out?

Last night, we ran interviews as the game aired, bringing us into the living rooms of US viewers to capture real, in-the-moment reactions.

After the game, we wanted to know which ads had stuck and sparked conversation.

A clear pattern emerged.
Memorability was closely linked to entertainment and nostalgia.

Viewers remembered stories, celebrities, jokes, and moments far more than brand names. Ads tapping into 90s and 2000s culture and familiar faces dominated recall and conversation.

In some cases, though, brands using these tactics still missed the mark. When the message drifted too far from the brand, people could vividly recount the ad but struggled to name who it was for.

Dunkin'â€‹, Budweiser Brewing Group (AB InBev), Uber Eats, and Pringles all benefited by making the brand inseparable from the idea.

More insights in the carousel ğŸ‘‡
 #SuperBowlAds #MarketingInsights #AudienceInsights

When I met Rt Hon Rachel Reeves recently, I shared a few ideas on how digital, data and AI can help square the circle of fairness and fiscal reality in public services.

Todayâ€™s Budget brings that tension into focus again: frozen tax thresholds, a possible shift on the two-child cap, a levy on international student fees, tweaks to business taxes. The choices are hard.

From where I sit â€“ Scrumconnect Consulting working across key central govt departments one thing is obvious:

If we donâ€™t modernise how services are designed and delivered, every Budget will feel like this.

We should be:

-killing wasteful legacy and manual processes
-using data and AI to target support, not just cut or add spend
-building shared platforms that drive down cost-to-serve every year
-investing in skills so departments own their futures, not just their suppliers

A few changes that (in my view) really matter in practice:

- No more â‚¬150 duty exemption for low-value e-commerce parcels
- CBAM moving into its operational phase for carbon-intensive imports
- A fully electronic customs environment (ICS2, AES, NCTS, Single Window, unified datasets)
- AEO as the core trusted-trader status, with â€œtrust & checkâ€ as the next level
- CN 2026 + evolving FTAs, sanctions and Ukraine measures reshaping tariffs and origin

The companies that will be fine in 2026 are the ones that treat customs as a product: clean data, solid processes, and systems that donâ€™t fall over when the rules change.

At Digicust, this is exactly what weâ€™re working on: bringing agentic AI into customs - systems that donâ€™t just â€œassistâ€ but actively take over repetitive customs work within clear guardrails, while staying transparent and auditable.

Btw: We analyzed and identified 53 items, anyone in customs should be aware of now. Comment if you want to get access!

This isnâ€™t a demo environment or a concept video â€“ itâ€™s the same setup thatâ€™s running in production at several large forwarding companies, customs service providers and industrial companies.

The nice part: it doesnâ€™t really matter what you throw at it â€“ invoices, waybills, delivery notes, packing lists, etc. as PDFs, images, Excel files or structured XML / JSON / CSV. And it doesnâ€™t matter whether you need a German import declaration, a Dutch transit declaration or a Philippine export declaration on the other side.

If youâ€™re curious how this might fit into your own process, have a look at the video and feel free to reach out or drop your questions in the comments.

still feeling left out with Claude Code?

here's how to go from zero to intermediate...

some people haven't even started with Claude Code (usually a bit lost or haven't dedicated the time to get set up.) Most people use maybe 20% of what it can actually do. they run one task at a time. research? wait 5 minutes. audit a page? wait again. draft emails? more waiting.

one thread. one bottleneck. painfully slow. what you need is multi-agent orchestration. it's basically running claude code like a small team where everyone works in parallel.

there are 3 layers to this:

â†’ sub-agents: fire off 3 tasks simultaneously. each gets its own context window. results come back while you keep working. like hiring freelancers for specific jobs.
â†’ skills: reusable workflows you write once in .claude/commands/. think /commit, /review, /audit. write once, invoke forever. consistent quality every time.
â†’ agent teams: multiple claude instances collaborating. a lead agent breaks down the work, then frontend, backend and tests all run at the same time. like having a PM + 3 developers.

(the trick is starting simple. sub-agents in week 1. your first skill in week 2. combine them in week 3. agent teams only when you actually need true parallelism.)

By the way, one thing people often missÂ : token usage. sub-agents use 300-500% more tokens. agent teams can be 7x. so use haiku for simple tasks, set max_turns limits, restrict tools per agent.

the carousel above gives you the overview. but i also wrote a really detailed playbook that takes you from literally nothing to running multi-agent setups:
â†’ how to install claude code and authenticate (5 min setup)
â†’ picking your interface: terminal vs IDE extension
â†’ the best adoption strategy (pick one use case a day, not a grand plan)
â†’ all 3 orchestration layers broken down with real examples
â†’ building custom agents in .claude/agents/ with restricted tools
â†’ writing your first skill in .claude/commands/
â†’ chaining skills together for compound workflows
â†’ hooks: auto-linting, guardrails, automation glue
â†’ cost management (because multi-agent burns tokens fast)
â†’ real community setups from members running this daily
â†’ a 4 week roadmap from zero to intermediate

basically the guide i wish i had when i started.

Iâ€™ve noticed something over time.
People who come from financially unstable or challenging backgrounds often prioritize stability so much that their dreams quietly get postponed, sometimes indefinitely.
That stability feels responsible. Necessary. Safe.
But it can also become a ceiling.
One hard lesson I can share, and watched others learn slowly, is that meaningful improvement almost always requires risking some form of security. Growth rarely happens while everything stays comfortable.
The second lesson is even harder to accept.
If you are not doing as well in a field or role as you expected, staying put out of fear does not fix it. Pivoting does.
Progress comes from admitting this is not working and giving yourself permission to explore something else, even when the path is unclear.
Dreams are not figured out by waiting for certainty.
They are shaped by moving, testing, failing, and adjusting despite uncertainty.
Stability matters.
But sometimes choosing uncertainty is the most practical decision you can make.

Soâ€¦ should we just wait?

Thatâ€™s the question we keep hearing since the draft simplified ESRS was published.

Wait for the final adoption. Wait another year before our publication in 2028.

Hereâ€™s a simple truth: postponing the inevitable is never a great idea. 
Simplified ESRS doesnâ€™t mean â€œdo nothing.â€ It means start in a simpler way.
If youâ€™re unsure what to do, this is the path that makes sense:

This year
- Do your materiality assessment. Not a massive checklist anymore. More pragmatic.
- Prepare your ESRS report in the new format. Immediately see the gaps you have and prioritise which ones require your attention. Some clients also do a pre-assurance.

Next year
Finalise, update w the latest data & audit your report. With full confidence.

Companies who postpone will be in a rush later. It will be like climbing up that skyscraper - but not Alex Honnold-style. 
Companies who start now, take incremental steps and stay in control.

And no, starting now doesnâ€™t mean doing things twice. 
Karomia already works with todayâ€™s simplified ESRS, so you can on the spot transpose your data into the new format and identify any remaining gaps.

ğŸ’¥ Your Finance team is accidentally sabotaging your Sales territories ğŸ’¥ 

Ask a CFO who owns the JW Marriott Venice and theyâ€™ll point to KSL Capital Partners (the Private Equity firm). They care about liability and credit risk.

But ask a Sales Rep who they need to sell to? Itâ€™s Marriott International.

This is the "Account Hierarchy Dilemma." 

Standard data providers (like Dun & Bradstreet) follow the money, rolling everything up to the "Ultimate Legal Parent."

The result? 
âŒ Reps are assigned massive PE conglomerates they can't actually sell to. 
âŒ "Shadow CRMs" emerge as reps create duplicates to bypass rigid hierarchies.
âŒ Total loss of a 360Â° customer view.

At Delpha, we believe in Brand Supremacy. 

If it carries the brand, it should roll up to the brandâ€”regardless of who owns the deed to the building.

We help revenue teams find the "Commercial Truth" by snapping hierarchies to the buying center, not the financial landlord.

Stop selling to the landlord. Start selling to the decision-maker.

Link to article on how we solve the Finance vs. Sales conflict in the comments.

#SalesOps #AccountHierarchy #RevenueOperations

ğŸ¥Š It started with a tense Slack from my top AE:

This isnâ€™t a people problem.

âš ï¸ Your CRM is lying to you.

Weâ€™ve been taught that data quality = correct spelling. 

If a rep or AI-Agent enters "Bolt," we check if "Bolt" exists. If yes â†’ actions.

But weâ€™ve entered the "Homonym Era" of B2B.

In San Francisco, Bolt is a $11B Fintech giant. ğŸ’¸ 

In Estonia, Bolt is a generic ride-hailing app. ğŸš—

If you match by name, you just merged a bank with a taxi company. Your territory reporting is broken. Your revenue attribution is a mess. Your enrichments or signals are wrong. And your reps are fighting over accounts that shouldn't even be linked.

Itâ€™s time to stop trusting Company Names. The only unique ID that matters in 2026 is the Website.

I broke down exactly how the "Homonym Trap" destroys hierarchies (and how to fix it) in my latest article.

In 2025, we all realized something: AI isnâ€™t the hard part anymore.
Reliable data is.

In 2026, the winners wonâ€™t be the teams with the most prompts.
Theyâ€™ll be the teams with agents that can plan â†’ act â†’ update safely because the CRM is clean, unified, and complete.

Letâ€™s build an agentic year â€” with guardrails.

AI Agents will fail without an Anti-Entropy Engine.

Jennifer Li from Andreessen Horowitz just nailed the biggest bottleneck for 2025: Data Entropy.

We are entering a world of Multimodal AI: where models need to ingest PDFs, emails, logs, and videos to take action. 

But here is the reality check: You cannot build a stable Multimodal future on a crumbling Structured foundation.

If your core Commercial Data (the "Who," "What," and "Where" of your customers) is decaying, your fancy new AI Agents will hallucinate. They will attach that contract PDF to the wrong "Acme Corp" or merge two different CEOs because the email addresses looked similar.

At Delpha, we see this every day. 
Data isnâ€™t static. 
It decays. 
It creates chaos. 
It has high entropy.

To make AI work, you don't need a one-time "cleanup." You need continuous infrastructure that: 
1ï¸âƒ£ Reconciles conflicts in real-time. 
2ï¸âƒ£ Validates truth with human context. 
3ï¸âƒ£ Provides a clean "skeleton" for your multimodal data to hang onto.

Data Entropy is the silent killer of Enterprise AI. Itâ€™s time we treated Data Ops as a continuous battle against chaos.

Big transitions donâ€™t wait for political goodwill. They wait for a cost curve to cross a threshold. Chamath sums it up well: the electrification trends are simply unstoppable.

Thatâ€™s also how we think at ENAPI.

One nuance, though: inevitability doesnâ€™t guarantee a smooth rollout. Charging is still too fragmented, too full of bespoke integrations, and too heavy on reconciliation. If the future is electric, the plumbing has to become boringly reliable.

Iâ€™ll drop a blog post in the comments from my co-founder Leo, who makes the same point from another angle: â€œWhy EVs Will Win: Itâ€™s About Costs, Not Climate.â€

A year ago, I published an end-of-year reflection called â€œRevolutionizing EV Charging: ENAPIâ€™s Vision for the Future.â€ Today we dropped this yearâ€™s one: â€œENAPI 2025: From idea to execution.â€

The title is basically the story. Less â€œcouldâ€, more â€œisâ€. We turned vision into rapid growth, and messy data into something partners can actually trust.

Super grateful for the team and for all partners who donâ€™t just nod on calls, but move real production traffic through ENAPI.

See you next year. Still plenty of ideas left that deserve to become reality.

The multi-million dollar problem with Super Bowl ads
We studied 147 viewers watching Super Bowl ads in real-time (not out of context, not the day after, and not after the internet had its say)

The finding that stood out: Almost 3x more people recalled the entertainment than the brand

Viewers could describe celebrity moments, jokes, and storylines in vivid detail, but couldn't name who paid for it

Only 1 in 3 participants clearly recalled both the ad AND the brand

The biggest risk isn't creating a bad ad - it's creating a memorable short film with a missing sponsor

Twenty years ago, if your business hit a cash squeeze, you dipped into your overdraft. It was familiar. It was flexible. And for most businesses, it worked.

That product has become much harder to access. Bank of England data shows that overdrafts once represented a significant share of SME finance. Today, that share has reduced considerably.

We put together a short breakdown of how this happened, what it means for UK SMEs, and why the landscape is starting to change.

Great evening at Drummonds Bank last night with Grow London and NatWest exploring the Future of the Customer. ğŸ¦

Lot's of talk of how agentic AI could help to create more personalised experiences for consumers; breaking down traditional product silos in financial services and resulting in better outcomes. ğŸ¯

At the Financial Conduct Authorityâ€™s SME Finance TechSprint today. 

Some great examples of technology platformâ€™s using open data to help small businesses get access to credit. 

2026 could be the breakout year for embedded SME finance & working capital.

Looking forward to joining the first Fintech Club of 2026 this Thursday (12th Feb), hosted by Grow London and NatWest.

Iâ€™ll be alongside a great panel of experts, Michelle He, PhD, CFA, Emily Fallon and Sam Brown, to discuss a topic that couldn't be more timely: how do we build the customer relationships of the future in financial services?

For SMEs, the opportunity is huge. They need flexible funding that moves at the speed of business - something that combines the trust and capital strength of established banks with the modern experience fintechs have pioneered.

If you're thinking about the future of SME finance, embedded lending, or how partnerships can unlock growth for underserved businesses, come along. Would be great to see you there.

Fantastic recognition for our small but mighty team at Bourn and all of our partners! Keeping the fingers crossed for this one!

Big news from the Bourn team ğŸ‰ğŸ‰ğŸ‰

We've just announced our Â£3.5m funding round, which includes a strategic investment by NatWest Group, alongside a brilliant group of other investors.

This builds on a brilliant first year piloting our solution with Investec, all focused on reinventing the business overdraft for SMEs.

What's super exciting is what this represents: two of the UK's most respected banks backing a different, real problem-solving approach to flexible business finance.

For the last 20 years, banks have been pulling away from business overdrafts.

They went from 30% of SME working capital down to about 5%. And itâ€™s understandable - unsecured lending is capital intensive, the fraud risk is real, and the operational overhead is significant.

But that left millions of businesses stuck between a rock and a hard place.

Either go to your bank and get told no, or opt for an unsecured loan and pay through the nose, ultimately adding to the cash flow problem.

Neither option was good enough and everything else seemed too complex or confusing!

So we built something different ğŸ’¡

And now NatWest is coming on board to pilot the solution with their business customers. Given 1 in 5 business bank with Natwest, this partnership provides us the opportunity to make a real dent in the working capital gap and help UK businesses grow.

How did this happen?

The approach we've taken is different from most software vendors to banks and fintechs. We built a regulated payments company for businesses in conjunction with a software platform for banks - a true hybrid model.

Banks bring the balance sheet, and own have the customer relationships. Bourn brings the technology, payments and channels!

We call it â€˜embedded fintechâ€™ and we're just getting started! 

Fun Fact - Royal Bank of Scotland provided the world's first overdraft to merchant William Hog in 1728. Whilst a great working capital solution, we thought it was about time to reimagine it, in partnership with the same bank!

Meanwhile my brain tried to come up with a deep parallel between running in mediocre weather conditions and AI....

I really tried to come up with something brilliant for a little over 1.5 hours. Spoiler: nothing really crossed my mind ğŸ«  

But in case you do want something rewarding after reading this: coming Thursday Tom van Wees will talk about how AI can help with handling incoming orders for manufacturing and wholesale companies.

The key is in capturing the tribal knowledge that lives in your organization, but isn't necessarily present in your ERP or in defined playbooks. 

At Lleverage, that is exactly where we focus on. The part between the email in outlook and the sales order in Business Central or SAP.

If you're dealing with manual order processing, this one's for you. I've put the link to the webinar in the comments.

Ik kwam gisteren een interessant artikel tegen in MT/Sprout, waarin Joseph Inzerillo, de eerste Chief Digital Officer bij Salesforce, uitlegt hoe hij aankijkt tegen de implementatie van AI binnen bedrijven. 

**Spoiler** - maar raadt je zeker aan verder te lezen - 'begin klein en versnel daarna pas'. Hij komt tot deze conclusie omdat hij ziet dat veel bedrijven blijven hangen in pilots die ze niet opgeschaald krijgen of ze zijn overweldigd en weten niet waar te starten.

Enorm 'on point', al zeg ik het zelf. 

Ik beperk me voor het gemak tot bedrijven in de maakindustrie, het gros van onze klanten. Zonder uitzondering is men ontevreden over de inrichting van ERP-systemen. Neem daarbij in ogenschouw dat dit soort (familie)bedrijven van oudsher gegroeid zijn door meer mensen aan te nemen en voornamelijk een hebben gehouden op hun product(en); niet zozeer op slimme techniek in de backend of operationele processen. 

Gevolg: een gedeelte van hun werknemers richt zich voornamelijk op het in goede banen leiden van o.a. het verwerken van binnenkomende orders: e-mails in de gaten houden, order interpreteren en opzoeken in systemen, kopieer - en plakwerk verrichten, orderbevestiging eruit sturen, vragen beantwoorden cq. stellen en admin doen in het ERP etc. 

En dit is nog een eenvoudige schets van wat vaak uren of meerdere FTEs in 'beslag' neemt bij dit soort bedrijven. 

Lleverage kan dit soort 'workflows' volledig automatiseren. En vaak is dit ook laaghangend fruit: geen fouten meer, beter bedienen van klanten en mensen werk laten doen dat impact maakt. Echter, als we in gesprek gaan, komen we er vaak achter dat niet alleen orderverwerking een stuk efficiÃ«nter kan maar dat er talloze onnodige repetitieve, tijdrovende processen zijn die ook geautomatiseerd kunnen worden (eg. invoice verwerking, capacity planning, chatbot om intern direct informatie op te kunnen halen etc.).

In het begin van ons bestaan hebben we als een soort bulldozer direct dit soort processen opgepakt. Hierdoor ontstond er een aardverschuiving binnen het bedrijf, omdat mensen opeens 80/90% van hun werk anders moesten gaan inrichten omdat dit werd overgenomen door AI. Dat werkte niet echt zeg maar.

Learning: start met 1 of 2 workflows die de meeste ROI opleveren om zo focus te houden en bedrijven te laten wennen aan de impact die het kan maken. Hiermee ben ik het dus eens met de CDO van Salesforce. Ik wil hier alleen nog aan toevoegen dat AI alleen goed kan werken met 'humans in the loop', waardoor mensen de controle kunnen houden, terwijl AI het 'domme werk' doet.

De vraag aller vragen, wie is er niet deze maandagochtend mee opgestaan, is 'hoe AI-automatiseringen ERP-problemen kunnen oplossen'?

Deze vraag lijkt zo'n vraag waarbij je een lastig antwoord verwacht. Zo'n vraag waarbij je overvallen kan worden tijdens een spelletje waarbij je kennis getest wordt. En misschien heb je stiekem al wat Trivial Pursuit kaartjes gelezen, ter voorbereiding om tijdens de kerst dit keer wÃ©l van je naaste(n) te winnen, maar zo'n vaart loopt het gelukkig niet om hier een goed antwoord op te formuleren. 

Het antwoord is namelijk vrij simpel, voor ons althans. Sterker nog, we zijn nieyt alleen bereid om dat antwoord te delen maar geven het graag een presenteerblaadje. Niet ik dit keer, maar onze eigen Tom van Wees van Lleverage doet z'n witte handschoenen aan, zodat je zorgeloos de feestdagen in kan. 

Hier heb je in ieder geval alvast een voorproefje, ofwel de amuse van de oplossing die we in onze webinar gaan behandelen:

We gaan het hebben over ERP-systemen (in de kern enorm verouderd en niet schaalbaar), handmatige data-invoer en gefragmenteerde IT-landschappen. Elke wijziging om het ERP heen vraagt consultants, tijd en budget. Migratie voelt te risicovol en te duur. Dat is wat we zien bij bedrijven in de maakindustrie, logistiek en groothandels.

Maarrrr, AI kan hierbij helpen. Bijvoorbeeld via een intelligente tussenlaag die je systemen verbindt, data begrijpt in elk format, en zo medewerkers een hoop tijd teruggeeft.

Ontdek hoe bedrijven hun operatie transformeren zonder migratie, zonder maanden training, en met meetbare ROI binnen weken.

We gaan het hebben over waarom traditionele oplossingen niet werken en AI wÃ©l het verschil maakt. We behandelen daarnaast concrete use cases vanuit ons portfolio. Denk hierbij aan het automatiseren van orderverwerking (spoiler alert: besparing van 7 FTE en 50% van additionele administratieve rompslomp). Verder zullen we wat dieper ingaan op hoe je via AI je gemakkelijk je data kan mappen vanuit elk format, slimme communicatie tussen al je interne data kan optuigen (60-80% minder handmatig werk als resultaat) en hoe je andere processen kan automatiseren.

Als dit niet als muziek in de oren klinkt, zo net voor de feestdagen, weet ik het ook niet meer. 

Dus, 'kick off your shoes and relax' en registreer je via de link in de comments.

Somewhere between meetings and the ride home, something clicked for me.
I think experience is massively overrated in sales.

Yesterday I had a conversation with a former AE of mine. We talked about career paths and deals won, deals lost, promotions, setbacks.

And somewhere in that conversation, something clicked again for me: most people accumulate experience. Very few accumulate insight ("Erkenntnis" in german, hard to translate it correctly).
In philosophy, thereâ€™s this idea that knowledge doesnâ€™t come from events themselves, but it comes from examining the assumptions behind them.

Iâ€™ve carried that thought with me for years.

Because Iâ€™ve seen reps with â€œ5 years of enterprise experienceâ€ who essentially repeated the same year five times. And Iâ€™ve seen others who lost one meaningful deal and completely changed how they think.

The difference isnâ€™t intelligence, instead itâ€™s reflection. Reflection is sometimes hard, the more easy/lazy way seems to not reflect permanently.

After almost every meaningful discussion I try to ask my team one question:
â€œIf this happens again, what do we now see differently?â€

Not: "What went well?", or "What went wrong?", or "Who dropped the ball?"
But: "What belief failed?", "What pattern did we misread?", "What does this permanently change in how we behave?"

And from my point of view I see the uncomfortable truth: Most sales organizations scale activity. Very few scale learning.

Revenue grows because your mental models improve and it doesnÂ´t because you run more calls. If after 50 deals your thinking hasnâ€™t evolved, your results eventually wonâ€™t either.

Experience doesnâ€™t compound. Corrected assumptions do.

And as a leader, my job isnâ€™t to provide answers. Itâ€™s to create an environment where beliefs get challenged and sharper thinking becomes the norm.
Thatâ€™s what actually scales.

Low conversion rates trigger a very predictable reflex. Pipeline is weak. So the answer becomes: add more.

This means: More meetings, more demos, more deals in the CRM. On paper (or digital), this looks like progress, but in reality, it usually isnâ€™t.

Because the problem is rarely pipeline.
What I see instead: AEs juggling 40, 50, sometimes 60 opportunities at the same time.
Not because thatâ€™s a strategy, but because prioritization quietly disappears.

At that point, conversion doesnâ€™t drop because people suddenly forgot how to sell. Instead it drops because attention gets diluted.

Thereâ€™s a limit to how many deals you can actually move forward well. From experience, that number is around 25â€“30.

Above that:
- deal progression becomes sloppy
- next steps lose clarity
- stakeholders arenâ€™t really mapped
- momentum fades, slowly and unnoticed

Low conversion doesnâ€™t automatically mean â€œwe need more pipelineâ€. More often it means: weâ€™re working the wrong deals, or too many of them, without actively managing the middle of the funnel.

More pipeline wonâ€™t fix that, but more focus will.

So you should master the middle and protect it from overload.

#salesleadership

My first 30 days as VP Sales.

The biggest insight surprised even me:
It wasnâ€™t motivation, more pressure or even â€œasking for more pipelineâ€.

What was missing was one simple, repeatable structure.

Before: Everyone was selling. Smart people. Good intent.
But everyone in their own way.

What we changed wasnâ€™t dramatic:
- A clear, repeatable sales process
- Fewer priorities
- Less noise
- More focus on doing the right things consistently

And very consciously, I decided not to do what many expect in the first month: 
- No push for â€œmore dealsâ€
- No demand for â€œmore pipelineâ€
- No pressure disguised as ambition

Instead:
Less, but done properly. Fewer deals, better qualified. Fewer motions, clearer ownership.

Scale doesnâ€™t start with intensity. It starts with clarity.

Especially in Series A / B environments, leadership often isnâ€™t about adding more and more. It is about removing what doesnâ€™t matter.

#salesleadership

In fast-growing sales teams, presence becomes a strategy.
Over the last weeks Iâ€™ve been reminded what that really means.

Some days itâ€™s about standing in front of C-level executives and partners, pressure-testing the story and the market pull.
Other days itâ€™s about being inside the team: rolling out processes, tightening forecasting, coaching AEs and SDRs so clarity replaces noise.

And then there are the days on the ground: on-site with customers, seeing where products are actually used and where assumptions quietly fall apart.

Somewhere in between, the role shifts again: enabling team leads, creating cadence, and making sure momentum doesnâ€™t depend on heroics.

Scaling doesnâ€™t mean stepping away from the field. It means choosing deliberately when to lead from the front, when to coach from the side, and when to get out of the way.

That balance is messy. But itâ€™s where real growth starts.

Why do I love quarter-end? 
Because quarter-end creates pressure and pressure reveals truth.
On the buyer side, things suddenly move. Decisions that were on hold start to unblock. Topics that felt complex or unpredictable become concrete.

On the sales side, quarter-end is a stress test. Not for effort but for deal qualification and deal quality.

What tends to show up:
Deals that were hope-based suddenly need miracles.
â€œChampionsâ€ who sounded supportive become silent.
Value that felt obvious turns out to be poorly understood or unproven.
More escalation on prospect side but less ownership.

None of these problems start in the last two weeks of the quarter. They donâ€™t appear out of nowhere.
They are built or avoided in the middle of the funnel.

Thatâ€™s why strong quarter-ends feel boring. Because clarity, ownership and proof were handled long before urgency arrived.

And before anyone asks: yes - this is a theoretical, meta-level post. An ideal scenario.
But in my experience, the closer reality gets to this model, the calmer and more predictable quarter-end becomes.

Where do you see quarter-end pressure revealing the most friction in your deals?

#salesenablement #salesleadership #enterprisesales

I used to think great leaders remove every blocker. Turns outâ€¦ sometimes I was the blocker.

Someone had a problem? I fixed it. Fast. It felt good, but it made everything worse.

Because the more problems I solved, the more problems came back to me.

So I changed my approach. In my weekly 1:1s we started using a simple scale:

ğŸŸ¢ Level 1 â€œIâ€™m annoyed.â€ â†’ You just want me to listen.
ğŸŸ¡ Level 2 â€œIâ€™m stuck.â€ â†’ You want a sparring partner.
ğŸ”´ Level 3 â€œI canâ€™t move forward.â€ â†’ Thatâ€™s when I unblock.

This one shift changed everything.

Most people donâ€™t need a fixer. They need a leader who listens first and steps in only when it truly matters.

Fixing is easy. Enabling is leadership.

Are you more of a Fixer or an Enabler (or something in between)?

#coachingculture #peopledevelopment #leadershipgrowth

Most deals donâ€™t die in Discovery or Negotiation. They die where almost no one is looking: the Middle.

Thereâ€™s a surprisingly naive assumption in many sales teams, even seasoned ones: â€œIf we get the meeting and nail the demo, the rest will take care of itself.â€

This belief is responsible for more lost enterprise deals than any objection ever spoken. 

Because the middle of the funnel is not a step: itâ€™s the enterprise playground.

Hereâ€™s what actually happens there:
Stakeholders surface (and disappear)
Political dynamics shift
Champions are tested
Risk becomes visible
Priorities change
The business case gets challenged
Internal narratives form with or without you

This is the part where sellers who rely on â€œproduct strengthâ€ lose, and sellers who understand organizational behavior win.

Enterprise buyers donâ€™t buy features. They buy alignment, predictability and low internal risk.

The teams who understand this win bigger and faster. The teams who donâ€™tâ€¦ confuse movement with progress.

Master the middle. Itâ€™s where everything actually happens.

Most sellers don't lose deals in Discovery. They lose them in the Follow-Up.

After mondays post and all the messages, one theme stuck with me again: how much seller growth shows up in the smallest moments and especially in how they follow up.

Not because they donâ€™t try hard enough, but because they donâ€™t see enough.
Follow-Ups arenâ€™t reminders, they are cognition. They reveal the developmental stage a seller is operating from. 

Those are the same stages we covered in the Dreyfus Sales Maturity Model.

STAGE 1: NOVICE "The Rule Follower"
â†’ Follow-Up = checking the box
â€œJust following up if thereâ€™s an update?â€
Outcome: no momentum, low authority, easy to ignore
Why? They treat a follow-up like a task, not a value moment

STAGE 2: ADVANCED BEGINNER "The Pattern Spotter"
â†’ Follow-Up = staying â€œtop of mindâ€
â€œJust keeping us on your radar.â€
Outcome: polite, empty, forgettable.
Why? They sense something is stuck, but canâ€™t yet see why.

STAGE 3: COMPETENT "The Model Builder"
â†’ Follow-Up = structured value drop
â€œI attached a similar project that might help you align internally.â€
Outcome: relevant, adds context, slight movement
Why? They understand relevance, not dynamics.

STAGE 4: PROFICIENT "The Pattern Interpreter"
â†’ Follow-Up = reducing internal friction
â€œI mapped the 3 biggest risks teams your size face and how others solved them.â€
Outcome: mentoring, derisking, political clarity
Why? They donâ€™t ask for updates instead they make updates possible.

STAGE 5: EXPERT "The Decision Shaper"
â†’ Follow-Up = shaping the narrative
â€œBased on your internal dynamics, there are two likely blockers. Hereâ€™s the fastest path to alignment.â€
Outcome: clarity, direction, urgency
Why? Experts shift decision logic and donâ€™t chase status.

THE RULE OF FOLLOW-UPS AT ANY LEVEL:
Every touchpoint must contain real value:

Process Value
(next steps, decision clarity, buying-center alignment)
Context Value
(insights, benchmarks, risk patterns, political dynamics)
Relationship Value
(trust, rapport, understanding the buyerâ€™s world)

A follow-up without value is noise; a follow-up with value is leadership.
Most sellers donâ€™t need better templates. What they actually need is deeper perception.

Whatâ€™s the most common follow-up mistake you see AEs make?

#salesleadership #valueselling #salesenablement

4 years at Flip. Same shirt. More beard.
And a version of me that only exists because of the people around me.

When I joined Flip four years ago, I had already worked in the frontline-communication space. But these four years changed the way I work, the way I lead, and the way I think.
Not overnight, but step by step - with a lot of people shaping that journey.

Hereâ€™s what defined those steps:
- building a frontline-first, value-based, use-case-driven sales play (again and again)
- understanding the difference between selling software and changing work
- leading the enterprise team and stepping into RVP role
- hiring and developing Flipsters who became absolute weapons
- coaching people into wins that mattered more to me than my own
- winning deals through pattern recognition, not pressure
- learning how to stay human while being accountable
- figuring out how to grow a team and yourself at the same time

And yes: I grew in experience, perspective, and leadership. But I didnâ€™t grow alone.

I grew because I had founders who trusted me, teammates who challenged me, AEs (Yasmine TrÃ¶ndle, Kristina Nietzsch, Amelie Wernick, Robin Guttenberger, Domenic W., Maximilian GÃ¼nzl, Maximilian Paetsch, Georgia Born, Sarafina Lichtenberg, and many more) who pushed me to be sharper, CSMs who made me reconsider assumptions, and colleagues who made the work better than the plan.

All while staying curious, absorbing everything, and trying to make myself, my team, and Flip better every single quarter.

And the funniest part? I only kept the shirt for the picture. The rest happened organically (the beard included).

Looking back, these 4 years shaped me professionally and personally. Not because everything went smoothly, but because so many people helped turn the hard parts into growth.

And Iâ€™m genuinely proud of the version of myself standing on the right side of that image.

Whatâ€™s one thing you learned in the last years that changed how you work?

I donâ€™t hire people who canâ€™t handle being wrong.


Early in my career I tried to understand whether someone would thrive in a coaching-heavy, high-feedback sales environment. Experience and achievements never answered that.

One simple question did: â€œWhat if youâ€™re wrong?â€

I first ask for their assessment: â€œHow would you evaluate this deal?â€ or â€œWhy did it stall?â€ or â€œWhatâ€™s your take?â€

Then I follow up with: â€œWhat if youâ€™re wrong?â€

The reaction tells me everything:
ğŸ›‘ Defensiveness or Justifying or Doubling down = low coachability

But when someone pauses, reflects, and says smth like:
âœ… â€œInteresting. Let me reconsider.â€; or "I would need to understand another perspective" = Thatâ€™s where growth happens.

In modern sales, the most underrated skill isnâ€™t confidence. Itâ€™s intellectual humility - the ability to adjust your thinking without feeling attacked.

How do you test for true coachability?

Detectie aan het front is fataal en Ã©Ã©n van de oorzaken van detectie is het gebruik van de radio. De vijand detecteert het radiosignaal en weet direct de locatie van de soldaat en/of eenheid. Een oplossing om toch te kunnen blijven communiceren zonder gedetecteerd te worden is LiveDrop; geen wondermiddel, maar in de mix of means een relevante technologie en oplossing die de kans op detectie minimaliseert en daardoor de overlevingskans maximaliseert. 

Dank Marnix Felius voor deze post en het agenderen van detectie; jouw post laat zien waarom wij onze schouders eronder blijven zetten onze oplossingen breed beschikbaar te krijgen binnen het Ministerie van Defensie en andere NATO landen. Niet volgend jaar, niet volgende maand, maar nu!
Van startup naar scaleupâ€¦ LiveDrop gaat vol gas en de samenwerking met CGI Nederland is hierin een geweldige stap.

Twee van onze kinderen werken bij Jumbo Supermarkten; vullen vakken, spiegelen en zorgen ervoor dat de winkel er piekfijn uitziet. Ze hebben het er naar hun zin en hun inzet werd beloond met een goed gevuld kerstpakket. Het krijgen, openen en uitpakken van het kerstpakket en het gevoel van waardering was een hoogtepunt en wat zijn ze er blij mee! Dank je wel Jumbo Supermarkten namens onze mannen.

Dit brengt ook prachtige herinneringen naar boven aan mijn eerste bedrijf Tintelingen, inmiddels onderdeel van Sligro Food Group, dat ik samen met Rik Klinkhamer opzette samen met oprecht een geweldig team. Jarenlang kregen wij het vertrouwen van werkgevers om hun kerstpakketten te verzorgen en miljoenen Tintelingen werden en worden nog altijd uitgereikt. Het kerstpakket als blijk van waardering en vaak het enige moment waarbij je als werkgever bij hele gezinnen een goede indruk kunt maken.

We zaten met Tintelingen echt in the winning mood en nu, 22 jaar na de oprichting, zit ik weer in deze zelfde energie. Met LiveDrop hebben we een relevante technologie ontwikkeld en doen we ertoe in kritische markten. Dit gevoel is onbeschrijfelijk lekker en proeft zoet na wederom een aantal jaren met de poten in de modder om het allemaal maar weer voor elkaar te krijgen. 

Niets zo leuk als ondernemen, eigenlijk voelt het als iedere dag een kerstpakket krijgen!

Two of our children work at Jumbo Supermarkets; they stock shelves, tidy up, and make sure the store looks spick and span. They enjoy their work, and their efforts were rewarded with a well-stocked Christmas hamper. Receiving, opening, and unpacking the Christmas hamper and feeling appreciated was a highlight, and they are so happy with it! Thank you, Jumbo Supermarkets, on behalf of our men.

This also brings back wonderful memories of my first company, Tintelingen, now part of Sligro Food Group, which I set up together with Rik Klinkhamer and a truly amazing team. For years, employers trusted us to provide their Christmas hampers, and millions of Tintelingen were and still are being handed out. The Christmas hamper is a token of appreciation and often the only time when you, as an employer, can make a good impression on entire families.

We were really in the winning mood with Tintelingen, and now, 22 years after its founding, I am back in that same energy. With LiveDrop, we have developed relevant technology and are making a difference in critical markets. This feeling is indescribably wonderful and tastes sweet after another few years with our feet in the mud to get it all done again. 

Nothing beats entrepreneurship; it actually feels like getting a Christmas hamper every day!

Our work requires us to think about the worst-case scenarios.
What happens if something collapses, floods, burns?
But since the very beginning of Eoliannâ€™s story, weâ€™ve madeÂ hopeÂ a rule. ğŸŒ±

Yes, they are opposites: the worst and hope. And people often ask us how we avoid being overwhelmed by climate doomism. Our first answer is always that thereâ€™s no real alternative.

The second is:Â by staying together. By exchanging energy and creating moments of inspiration, so we can stay more connected to solutions than to problems - within and around us.

Thatâ€™s exactly what we did over these three days in Alagna Valsesia, during our annual retreat. A moment to come together from the many places we usually work from, to take stock, to slow down, and to look at things from a different perspective. In this case: from the mountain peaks. â›°ï¸ 

What we saw was a team that practices the resilience it stands for - evolving as circumstances evolve, refusing simple answers to complex problems, and supporting one another on the ski slopes as much as in everything else.

Weâ€™re back recharged. Stay tuned: great things are coming!

Buildings consume 40% of Europe's energy. Most are still treated as static loads instead of flexible grid assets.

Thomas Bajas, Co-founder and Chief Growth Officer at Tilt Energy, explains how AI-powered demand flexibility is turning buildings into grid stabilizers without compromising comfort or usability.

What buildings can do:
Heat pumps, EV charging, and battery storage shift consumption in response to grid signals and electricity prices, cutting costs and integrating more renewables.

Scaling across Europe:
Tilt Energy already manages hundreds of sites in France with customers like Carrefour and Unibail-Rodamco-Westfield. Their goal: 1 gigawatt of flexible capacity by 2030.

As Thomas puts it: "Our vision is to optimize electricity consumption like fitting pieces together in a game of Tetris." This approach stabilizes the grid, cuts costs, and accelerates renewable integration at scale.

Something fundamental is shifting in software architecture. And most people are missing it.

For decades, we've built systems in three layers. Data stores and retrieves. Logic processes and orchestrates. Presentation displays and captures input. Clean boundaries. Clear responsibilities. 

That model is breaking down â€” not because it was wrong, but because every layer is gaining intelligence.

The data layer is becoming conversationalâ€”vector embeddings, semantic search, natural language queries. Your database no longer executes queries. It helps you understand what you mean.

The orchestration layer is embracing human logic. AI agents that reason, handle ambiguity, and make judgments: business logic that isn't just coded rules, but adaptive decision-making.

And the presentation layer â€” where we focus at Mindset AI â€” has gained an entirely new responsibility.

It's no longer enough to render interfaces and capture input. The presentation layer must now determine what the user is actually trying to accomplish and help them do so in the most elegant and optimal way.

This is a profound shift. 

The interface becomes an interpreter of intent, not just a display of options. A guide to optimal paths, not just a menu of choices. A contextual orchestrator that serves the right experience â€” conversation, widget, visual, or hybrid â€” based on what the moment requires.

The recent MCP Apps announcement from Anthropic and OpenAI formalises part of this shift: rich, interactive UI served contextually within conversational AI. 

Conversation as the orchestration layer. Widgets rendered when visual interaction serves the user better than text.

But here's what many are missing:

This isn't about being inside ChatGPT or Claude. It's about who owns the intelligent presentation layer across every surface where your customers interact with you.

Your website. Your app. WhatsApp. Slack. Teams. And yes, the AI platforms too.

The companies that thrive in this new architecture won't be the ones who bolted a chatbot onto their existing UI. They'll be the ones who rebuilt their presentation layer with this new responsibility at its core: Understand intent. Guide optimally. Serve the right experience. Everywhere.

That's the future we're building at Mindset AI.

When we started processing first subscriptions through Juo, we tracked every single notification. We celebrated every new purchase. And a fee too. Today, such volume would only put a slight smile on our faces, as we're now processing thousands of transactions daily without breaking a sweat.

But the goal isnâ€™t thousands a day. Itâ€™s thousands per hour, or even per minute.

People ask if Iâ€™m worried about handling that scale. Iâ€™m not, not even on days like today. As the CTO, and simply as one of the engineers working in a team. Because we've already proven that the team we've built will handle every challenge thrown at them. At us.

This is exactly where our recently announced â‚¬4M seed round led by Market One Capital and Peak, with participation from BADideas.fund, SMOK Ventures, FJ Labs, and Lakestar, comes into play. It provides the fuel to deliver on an ambitious roadmap designed to handle both product and business growth.

So, what exactly are we building?

We're building a platform that lets devs and operators create any custom mission-critical subscription application on top of it. The platform is built on three core principles:

- Control: Developers need control over the entire subscription lifecycle.
- Flexibility: Our platform handles the core logic and guardrails, but never throws obstacles in your path.
- Future-proofing: We are supporting all interfaces, including agentic ones.

We learned through our clients that adoption at this level requires aligning perfectly with business needs. Personally, my observation is that ecommerce developers have never been taken care of properly, the way SaaS developers are. I want to change this.

Our first big step on this roadmap is shipping Blocks, a completely new way to build subscriber interfaces that leverages AI-supported dev environments. Feel free to DM me if youâ€™d like to join our dev team or get access to the Private Beta as a client.

Hats off to the whole Juo team, and a special thank you to my co-founders, Leszek and Alina, who keep us motivated to break through every obstacle!

Yesterday's news? Let's make it about tomorrow then. As you already know, Juo has recently secured â‚¬4M in funding in a seed round led by top European investors â€” Market One Capital and Peak. Today, I want to share why we raised this round and what product vision the money from this round will help us pursue.

Some products and industries feel natural for subscriptions. But our ambition is to make it also natural for those brands who are just discovering the potential of recurring. Subscriptions of physical, or â€” as we call them, non-digital â€” products are evolving beyond the simple "subscribe and save". Now, when acquiring a customer often requires attention to many touchpoints (including many new ones, like AI chats), being able to transition one-time purchases into relationships becomes appealing and more important than ever before.

Good news â€” the possibilities for subscription programs are endless.

And we're here to make sure that the technology enabling them is never the limitation.

Our plan isn't just about catching up with the future. We want to actively shape it. We're all about empowering a brand-new P&L, predictable revenue, higher LTV, and products loved by subscribers that come back on their own. The market doesn't know this is possible yet â€” but we'll show them. We're in the business of going from products to programs.

And the recent financing and the new network's insights will support Juo in this mission.

With our core platform adapting to every business case, dev tooling to build any custom mission-critical subscription application, and agentic commerce-ready modules, we're giving a new tech superpower to any brand who takes customers and products long-term seriously.

And you know what? We'll give access to it and build it together with a community of our clients and partners, so that the platform is not ours â€” itâ€™s yours.

So! If you're an operator, an agency or a dev looking for the access to next-gen subscription layer to shape it to your needs â€” DM me.

I'm looking forward to this mission â€” especially with brilliant people by my side: our investors, team, and most importantly, my invaluable co-founders. Leszek, PaweÅ‚, thank you for the journey so far!

You've already heard about our recent Juo seed round. But if you'd like to learn about the journey that led us here, you can read about it in the December issue of Forbes Polska.

Thank you, Krzysztof, for putting our story into words and giving us the chance to re-experience it. Åukasz, thank you for visiting and capturing us. And Marcin, thank you for coordinating everything.

â€” Ludzie i start-upy

It's time. Today Juo is announcing our â‚¬4M seed round led by Market One Capital and Peak, with participation from BADideas.fund, SMOK Ventures, FJ Labs, and Lakestar. Also, Mark Ransford, Marek Gut, Maciej Zawadzinski, and Louis Pfitzner are officially joining our investor team.

This is an important milestone in our journey to build the default backbone for non-digital subscriptions. At Juo, we believe every great business with an excellent product deserves the superpower to turn a one-time purchase into a relationship. We're not about faster checkouts â€” we're in the business of going from products to programs, from transactions to relationships.

Although the fundraising itself happened quickly and closed with oversubscription, the process of getting there took a while and consisted of a series of product experiments. Along the way, we solved several pseudo-problems, but thanks to that, we found the trail of several real ones, and when we solved those, everything took off.

Since then, we've already gained solid momentum in several EU markets, especially the Netherlands â€” one of the most advanced ecom ecosystems in Europe. We learned a tremendous amount in the process, thanks to the belief and close collaboration of fantastic early clients such as Your KAYA, MOG, Mother's Earth, Polarwise, and Guud.

I'm incredibly proud of my team that throughout this entire time, no one doubted or gave up on the path to finding true product-market fit. It's wonderful to be part of a tribe that doesn't accept compromises â€” not only when it comes to product quality, but also company values and team principles. That's a trait of the best.

And the new investor lineup? Speaks for itself. I'm thrilled that our team is getting support from absolutely top-tier funds, bringing ambition and confidence to the table. And since at Juo we have a habit of working closely with the investors, we'll give the same back. As an entrepreneur-physicist, I call it a very special type of reciprocal force relationship.

In the upcoming months, with the new funding, we'll focus on developing our dev platform for building any subscription offering while separating work contexts for business operators and developers, and the new toolkit ready for the arrival of the agentic commerce era. If you want to join our mission in building the subscription layer that teams can shape into any desired subscription application, reach out to us â€” we're hiring.

Thank you!

As always, a final toast to my best friends, partners, and co-founders â€” Alina and PaweÅ‚. Thank you for making it all possible. Cheers!

Last summer, I moved from being investor in United Manufacturing Hub (UMH) to taking on an operative role. In buzzword terms, you could say: I went all in! 

After our 5m EUR funding round, Jan Thomas from Startup Insider took the chance to grill me on a few topics:
- Why will UMH bring manufacturers into the AI age?
- What did you learn in a "1.5 years due diligence"? 
- Why ist the next funding round NOT our next goal?
- What was it like raising funding as an ex-investor? 
- What was the emotional journey of changing jobs?

#UMH #theindustrialdatacompany #industrialai

Everyone wants AI in factories. The problem: optimization requires a data foundation first. Whether you're building AI or just helping your team make better decisions. That foundation eats 90% of the project. Most teams never get past it.

We spent years as system integrators and consultants. Crawling under conveyors, wiring sensors, building dashboards. Same story everywhere: machine data trapped in silos. Projects shelved before they start because the data work alone takes months.

UMH is the foundation we wished existed. Open-source. Community-centric and product-first.Â We're not building data infrastructure for its own sake. We're cutting the time it takes to actually improve production. In Europe and everywhere else.

Where we are today: thousands of users, dozens of manufacturers, sites across Europe & the world. HiPP, BÃ¶llhoff, Edeka and many more: Edeka for over three years.

What's next: a better experience for OT, IT, and AI agents alike. Wider connectivity. A stronger open-source core. Strategic partnerships to reach more factories worldwide. All to do one thing: cut the time from problem to solution.

â‚¬5M to make this the standard. Led by KOMPAS VC, joined by seed + speed Ventures, Sustainable Future Ventures, and Archimedes New Ventures and Backed by people who've done this: Jan Oberhauser from n8n, Jeff Hammerbacher from Cloudera. And many more great founders and operators.

None of this could have happened without our incredible team. Thank you! We're hiring. Link in the comments.

Is WEF worth it for an early-stage startup?

Short answer: yes and no

I attended WEF in Davos for the first time this year without a conference pass.
Mostly side events. A lot of walking. A lot of coke zero.

Finding the right people is not easy. Many events attract broad audiences. Topics are big. Target groups are not always sharp.

If you go in expecting a classic conference with structured lead generation, youâ€™ll be disappointed.

But.

There is almost no other place with this density of senior decision-makers.
CEOs, board members, investors all within a few streets.

The probability of randomly bumping into someone genuinely interesting is unusually high.

My most important learning: Nowhere is the importance of the network more apparent than in Davos. 

Your calendar matters less than who introduces you to whom.

Would I do it again? Probably yes.
Would I do it differently? Also yes.

Thank you very much for all the great conversations I had.
Maik Taro Wehmeyer Feliciana Canellas Dr. Friederike Hoffmann Nick Lawitzke Eric Anderegg Peter Bertschinger Katka Letzing AnikÃ³ Ivanics Sabine Wildemann ğŸ¤– Ryan Donnell Smith Noemi Alvarez

Reactive hiring used to be enough.

A role opens.
A request comes in.
Recruitment starts.

But today, that model is breaking.
