When companies shift from reactive hiring to orchestration, everything changes.
Hiring becomes predictable and not urgent because recruiters move from execution to strategy:

â€¢ Data replaces guesswork

Agentic AI enables this shift by handling the operational load while teams focus on planning, alignment, and outcomes.

The future of hiring is not faster reactions.
It is a better preparation.
And that is where competitive advantage begins.

Building real BI is extremely hard.

Quick demos that show chats, NLQ, pretty charts, quick insights "What are my sales this month?".

But then struggle with scale, governance, performance, embedding, Scheduled reporting to PDF/PPT, Enterprise Workflows & writeback, SSO and security.

Thereâ€™s nothing wrong with starting with fast insights.

But real BI isnâ€™t about answering a question.
Itâ€™s about running a business on it.

Iâ€™ve become increasingly bullish on Process Mining & Intelligence as a critical category for the next decade.

Historically framed as an evolution of BI, it mines and visualizes human-led processes like Order-to-Cash or Payments to surface inefficiencies and revenue leakages.

But by 2028, its real importance will be in Agentic AI.
Not just to observe what agents do, but to understand how they arrived there: their reasoning paths, decision branches, failure points, and stalls.

Process Mining will become the debugger of the agentic enterprise.

However, debugging alone is not enough. The enterprise will still need a semantic, decision, and action layer where humans and agents agree on meaning, intent, and outcomes. Thatâ€™s where modern BI and data-apps platforms evolve.

Process logs will become just another domain of data to reason over, optimize, and operationalize.

Beyond watching agents, we will start Lean-optimizing their decision flows, and eventually agents will review and heal their own processes.

Iâ€™ve followed mpmX by MEHRWERK for many years. From a Qlik add-on to a platform-agnostic solution and now integrated with Camunda, their trajectory shows how serious the plumbing has to be for this future to work.

The real value isnâ€™t in hype.
Itâ€™s in building the control systems, the actual plumbing, that let intelligence scale safely.

BI has never really been about insights.
BI is about agreement.

As a student, I was told by my professor to go research polar bears at the North Pole. ğŸ»â€â„ï¸ 

When I was studying Aeronautical Engineering (MSc), I approached my professor for advice. My studies had been purely theoretical (which I loved), but to work in the industry I felt I needed credibility and experience in practice.

I explored doing/paying for a programme to do the UK CAA Part-66 Category A (CAT A) Aircraft Maintenance Licence (steps towards becoming an aircraft technician). I sought my professor's confirmation that it was worth doing and if it would help me in my career as an engineer.

"If you want to become a technician, go do it," he said.

I didn't. I pinpointed him about my thesis: that it would differentiate me as a candidate in my career, and be nice credentials alongside my MSc.

He didn't answer my question. Instead, he said I should study what I like, work where I like, and do that.
"If you want to study aeronautical engineering, but then want to work with polar bears, you should go to the North Pole and become a researcher."

It was frustrating as this didn't help at all. But a few years later I realized this encounter was powerful.

I was indoctrinated to believe career paths are fixed, that they need to be built like Lego stones towards a masterplan. Life isn't fixed like that. You can change the rules at any time, and with hard work, pursue whatever you like, whenever you like.

I didn't go to the North Pole, but after uni I moved away from aeronautical engineering and never looked back. I eventually became an entrepreneur in data analytics, doing what I love and enjoy.

And I will keep doing what I love and enjoy next when that becomes boring.

CDP scoring paradox: fewer disclosers, but more a-listers.

Over the past 3 years, number of CDP disclosing companies has declined, yet the number of A-Listers has grown significantly:

ğŸ“‰ Companies disclosing: 23,200 â†’ 22,100 (âˆ’5%)
ğŸ“ˆ A-List companies: 396 â†’ 877 (+122%)

Meaning, A-List rate doubled from 1.7% â†’ 4.4% in two years.

The graph below makes it even more visible:
- Both metrics are indexed to 100 at the 2023 baseline.
- If both moved together, the lines would track roughly in parallel.
- Instead, they diverge by 127 points in opposite directions.

So whatâ€™s up?

Two explanations (pick yours):

1) Rapid improvement:
The companies still disclosing are genuinely getting better. = Optimistic one

2) Selection + scoring dynamics
Weaker companies opted out, and CDP may have become more generous with giving Aâ€™s. Especially because A-List status is basically the only valuable thing companies get out of it.

Could be nice to go for the first one. But judging by the broader score decline (see my earlier posts), the more realistic answer is: a small group improved, many dropped out, and the bar for A-list has moved.

You know me, Iâ€™m always cynical. Whatâ€™s your view here?

For years, due diligence expanded in one direction: more risks, more requirements, more controls, more suppliers. That improved coverage but didn't really improve control.

What's shifting now is how companies allocate attention:
ğŸ”¸ Go deep on suppliers where risks are material
ğŸ”¸ Maintain lighter oversight across the rest
ğŸ”¸ Stop spreading resources so thin that nothing gets proper attention

This approach wasn't feasible before because narrowing scope meant blind spots. What makes it work now is AI infrastructure that reuses existing disclosures, structures evidence, and flags gaps continuously. Teams can focus without missing critical issues.

Due diligence in 2026 looks different.

For years, it expanded in one direction only:
more risks, more requirements, more controls, more suppliers.

That improved coverage, but did not really improve control.

âš ï¸ Whatâ€™s changing now is how companies allocate attention. Thanks to tighter budgets, regulatory uncertainty, critical supply risks, and the accumulated craziness of 2025.

So what does it mean?

In practice, companies can operate across four due diligence postures:

ğŸ”· Baseline orientation
Broad visibility, limited follow-up.

ğŸ”· Exhaustive
Deep scrutiny applied widely: expensive and heavy.

ğŸ”· Compliance
Narrow focus on what is strictly required.

ğŸ”· Strategic
Targeted depth on a limited number of material risks.

â„¹ï¸ None of these is inherently right or wrong. Each reflects maturity, supply-chain complexity, and strategic intent.

For a long time, strategic due diligence wasnâ€™t really feasible. Without broad analysis, narrowing scope meant risking blind spots. So companies either went exhaustive, or stayed shallow.

â€¼ï¸ The shift we see in 2026: strategic due diligence becomes the ONLY commercially viable option for many companies. Because teams need to show value and demonstrate the business case. You canâ€™t deliver it if you are spreading too thin.

Itâ€™s a shift toward narrowing scope and increasing depth where it actually changes outcomes:

â€¢ fewer demands per supplier
â€¢ less repeated disclosures
â€¢ clearer separation between monitoring and intervention
â€¢ deeper engagement with suppliers on genuinely material risks

ğŸ¤–This shift would not be possible without AI. Itâ€™s a critical infrastructure that makes judgment possible at scale. By reusing existing disclosures, structuring evidence, and continuously highlighting real gaps, AI makes it possible to focus attention without blind spots.

Without this layer, strategic due diligence stays theoretical. With it, it becomes operational.

Here we come 2026!

2025 was a wild year in #sustainability reporting and action. 

Game-changing comprehensive frameworks were published, only to be challenged and postponed.

We'd seen huge leaps forward in mandatory and voluntary #energy and #carbon strategies, at the same time as the rule book being torn up and tossed into the plastic-filled sea.

U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission's "Enhancement and Standardization of Climate-Related Disclosures for Investors" rule was adopted in March 2024 but quickly faced multiple lawsuits and the SEC withdrew its legal defence in March 2025.

So the SEC doesn't feature in our #webinar on where we are now and where we're going in 2026 and beyond...

But plenty of other governments and bodies are ploughing through, knowing that climate breakdown isn't going away.

And you know what? Even if we think 'stuff the environment', we'll want to manage our corporate climate risks, just like any other risks to our business.

From the EU and UK to California and Australia, new frameworks are redefining whatâ€™s required and whatâ€™s expected.

Come to (god of choice) moment over the weekend... hence my last two posts. 

Sellers and buyers have never been further apart.

Sellers want a pipeline. Buyers want vendors to go away.

Sellers ask, "What are your strategic priorities for Q3?" Buyers think, "I've answered this 14 times this month."

Sellers run 6-stage discovery frameworks. Buyers just want to know if this thing works.

We've rebuilt our entire sales motion around one idea:

Every stage has 3 things we need. 3 things they need. That's it.

If we can't get ours, we walk. If they can't get theirs, "walk the plank," we shout (we don't). 

No word salad. No, "let me just understand your vision." No 47-minute monologue disguised as a demo.

Turns out, when you tell a buyer "my job is to qualify you out," they actually want to talk to you.

Is sales broken, or are we just overcomplicating it?

I reckon 99% of us get this wrongâ€¦ prove me right.

Ps. Outbound led intro call

I walked away from the biggest deal of my career. $13.7M. Would've blown my quota out of the water.

But here's what that "loss" taught me...

The CEO had everything:Â 
âœ“ A problem we could solveÂ 
âœ“ Agreement he HAD the problem
âœ“ Desperate need to fix itÂ 
âœ“ Budget approved

But one thing kept nagging at me.

Every meeting, he'd ask about customization.Â 
About "partnering" to build features.
About source code access. 

Classic Build vs. Buy syndrome.

After our 5th in-person meeting (yes, FIVE), I finally saw it clearly.

This wasn't a buyer. This was a builder trapped in a buyer's process.

His personality screamed "I'll do it myself."Â 
His energy peaked when discussing his team's capabilities.
His questions focused on HOW we built it, not WHAT it could do. 

So I made the call that physically hurt:

I removed it from my pipeline.

My manager: "Are you SURE?"Â 
My financial plan: "But the commission..."Â 
My ego: "You're giving up."

Here's what happened next:

â†’ Freed up 30+ hours that monthÂ 
â†’ Focused on a $1.8M deal that actually wanted to buyÂ 
â†’ Closed 3 other deals while he was still "evaluating"Â 
â†’ Finished with my best year ever

And that CEO?Â 
18 months later, still building.Â 
Still solving the same problem.

The real lesson?

Not every deal is YOUR deal.

Some buyers aren't buyersâ€”they're builders in disguise. And the time you waste convincing them is time you could spend closing real deals.

Three questions I now ask myself:

1./ Are they asking about outcomes or architecture?
2./ Do they light up more about building or buying?
3./ Is their real goal independence or results?

If the answers point to "building," I'm out. No matter the size.

Because the best deals aren't always the biggest ones.Â 
They're the ones that actually close.

What deal have you walked away from that taught you the most?

Your engineers are building the same widgets as your competitors. While your competitive moats sit unexposed.

1.5 billion people use AI daily. They expect every product to work conversationally. But here's what no one tells you about building it:

The multiplication problem.

You add a conversational assistant. Expose one capability-calendar access.

Now you need:

Widget for web
Condensed view for mobile
Text version for Slack
WhatsApp flow
Translation everywhere
Memory across surfaces
Compliance infrastructure

That's ONE capability.

Now expose ten.

Each multiplies across 6 surfaces, 12 languages, dozens of interaction patterns, infinite edge cases.

This isn't one project. It's hundreds of cascading micro-projects.

Here's what makes this devastating:

Every minute building this creates zero competitive advantage ğŸ™ƒ 

Your calendar widget looks identical to your competitor's. Your Slack integration works the same. The compliance layer-they're building it too.

While your engineers build widgets, what's NOT getting built?

The intelligence in your data competitors don't have
The domain logic that creates your moat
The proprietary systems only you control
The AI capabilities that make you 10x better

The real cost isn't time or money. It's fragmentation.

Your team can't concentrate force on competitive advantage because they're fragmented across unpredictable frontend demands.

Without concentrated force, you can't create leverage.

Without leverage, you can't build moats.

The question:
Can your engineers afford to be fragmented across infrastructure when your advantage depends on concentrated force?

The shift has already happened. Where's your engineering capacity going?

Building infrastructure everyone needs identically?

Or building the capabilities that make you 10x better?

Voice cloning does not start with models. It starts with audio.

That is how the leading AI video platform, Synthesia, improved voice cloning quality by fixing sound at the source instead of adding complexity downstream.

Their users record wherever they are, on laptop mics in home offices or meeting rooms, often with just 30 seconds of training audio, which means even minor recording inconsistencies can distort speaker identity.

As their Senior Research Engineer, Adam Froghyar, put it: â€œIf we can assume clean inputs, the modeling problem becomes much simpler.â€

By integrating ai-coustics at the start of their pipeline, Synthesia standardised audio before training, resulting in clearer and more reliable voice clones. Thanks to Allyson, Adam and the Synthesia team for the great team work on this.

Curious how others are handling real-world audio in their voice pipelines?
Find the full case study in the comments. ğŸ‘‡

We are excited to share a new guest article by Tim Janke, Co founder and Head of Research at ai-coustics.

The article explores why voice AI systems fail in real world environments and how synthetic realism can bridge the gap between clean lab data and production reality. It also shows how physics based acoustic simulation with the Treble SDK enables spatially grounded training data that captures distance, geometry and room acoustics at scale.

If you work with speech enhancement, voice agents or audio AI, this is a practical look at how realistic data leads to more reliable behavior in production systems.

Read the full article below and join us on February 26th for the upcoming webinar where we dive deeper into these ideas.

Big news: we just made our SDK 90% smaller.

By separating model weights from the SDK, users now download only what they need - no extra files, no wasted time.

This small change makes a big difference: faster installs, modular updates, and a cleaner pipeline for real-time Voice AI.

Insights by our Senior ML Systems Engineer, Andres Oliva.

Your voice agent hears everything: your user, conversations in the background, TVs, announcements, music.

Quail Voice Focus STT locks in on what actually matters.

Our new real-time primary speaker isolation model doesnâ€™t just â€œenhance audio.â€ It identifies, isolates, and boosts the primary speaker, while suppressing competing voices. That means your VAD and STT get exactly what they need: clean, user-first speech.

The payoff:
ğŸ”¥ Higher STT accuracy
ğŸ”¥ More reliable VAD
ğŸ”¥ Smoother, more natural turn-taking

You can now test the SDK for free on our developer portal.
Full technical deep-dive on our blog â€“Â  head the comments for the link.

In the Voice AI industry, one problem keeps coming up:
STT accuracy collapses the moment conditions get unpredictable.

Noise, reverb, cheap mics, compression â€“ all break even top-tier STT models. And perceptual de-noisers like Krisp often increase word error rate by stripping away the phonetic detail STT systems actually need.

So we built Quail STT: a speech enhancement model designed specifically to boost STT accuracy in unpredictable and varied real-world environments.

By preserving machine-relevant structure (timing, articulation, consonants, spectral cues), Quail STT consistently cuts substitutions, insertions and deletions across providers.

The result: a relative 10â€“25% WER reduction across benchmarked data sets.
Quail STT offers:

ğŸŒ Robust performance on noisy, accented, device-variable audio
ğŸ¤– Improvements across Deepgram, AssemblyAI, Gladia, Cartesia & ElevenLabs
âš¡Models for perceptual SE, STT optimised SE and Voice Activity Detection (VAD) â€“ all delivered through a fast, lightweight Rust SDK.

Head to our blog to see the results in full

ğŸ“… Volatility Has a Calendar â€” Especially in Commodities

Volatility is often treated as something random.
A reaction to news, events, or surprises.
In commodities, that assumption breaks down quickly.

Here, volatility is seasonal â€” because the risks themselves are seasonal.

ğŸŒ¾ Why seasonality matters more in commodities
Commodity markets are tied to the physical world:

 â€¢ weather
 â€¢ planting & harvest cycles
 â€¢ inventory and storage constraints
 â€¢ transportation and refinery schedules
 â€¢ geopolitics and supply disruptions

These risks donâ€™t arrive randomly.
They show up at roughly the same time every year.
In commodities, the calendar is not just context - itâ€™s part of the model.

ğŸ“‰ Volatility seasonality â‰  price seasonality

This is an important distinction.

Price seasonality is about direction.
Volatility seasonality is about uncertainty.

Prices can go nowhere, while volatility rises predictably.
And options markets know this.

ğŸ§  What the options market already â€œknowsâ€

Implied volatility in commodities often:
 â€¢ rises before known risk windows
 â€¢ steepens the term structure into seasonal events
 â€¢ shifts skew as downside or upside risk dominates

Options donâ€™t react to seasons - they anticipate them.

Thatâ€™s why selling â€œcheap volâ€ without context is dangerous, and why absolute IV levels are often misleading.

âš ï¸ What breaks when you ignore vol seasonality

This shows up everywhere:
 â€¢ backtests that look greatâ€¦ until the same month every year
 â€¢ strategies that overtrade during structurally high-vol periods
 â€¢ risk models that underestimate tail risk

Many strategies donâ€™t fail because the idea is wrong, but because volatility wasnâ€™t normalized for the season.

ğŸ“Š Visualizing it makes it obvious

When you look at volatility across years instead of across time, the seasonality jumps out immediately.

Same market.
Same instrument.
Different month â€” completely different risk regime.

With Allasso Copilot, you can pull up commodity volatility and see these patterns directly in the data â€” not as anecdotes, but as structure.

ğŸ› ï¸ How traders actually use this

Volatility seasonality isnâ€™t just interesting â€” itâ€™s usable:
 â€¢ regime filters (high-risk vs low-risk months)
 â€¢ dynamic position sizing
 â€¢ strategy selection by calendar window
 â€¢ comparing current IV to seasonal percentiles, not raw levels

This is especially powerful in commodities, but the same framework applies across assets.

ğŸ§­ Final thought

Volatility isnâ€™t flat.
And in commodities, itâ€™s definitely not random.

If a strategy â€œmysteriouslyâ€ struggles at the same time every year, the answer is often hiding in the calendar â€” not the price chart.

At risk of dating myself, not every professional options trader out there has access to the live and accurate portfolio greeks and execution algorithms they need to automatically achieve an optimal delta.

At Allasso, we believe in enabling humans in the markets.
Below, we compare and combine classic delta-hedging strategies that can be applied by the rest of us.

We test our hedge strategies in Brent oil against a short, front month ATM straddle that rolls on a monthly basis. We assume execution at settlement prices, using the actual underlying future.

We run this using Allassoâ€™s low-level, iterative Python backtester, Pulse.

ğ—ªğ—µğ—®ğ˜ ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¹ğ˜ğ—® ğ˜€ğ—µğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ—± ğ—œ ğ—µğ—²ğ—±ğ—´ğ—²?
Weâ€™re testing four different measurements of delta:
-Black Scholes Delta, settlement IV
-Quickdelta, settlement IV
-Black Scholes Delta, reduced settlement IV
-Quickdelta, reduced settlement IV
-Black Scholes Delta, historical mean settlement IV
-Quickdelta, historical mean settlement IV

ğ—ªğ—µğ—²ğ—» ğ˜€ğ—µğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ—± ğ—œ ğ—µğ—²ğ—±ğ—´ğ—²?
We are testing calendar- and delta-limit-based rebalancing of the hedge position
-Daily and weekly hedge frequency
-Delta limit for options delta

ğ—¡ğ—¼ ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—ºğ—¶ğ˜ğ˜€ ğ—¼ğ—» ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—´ğ—¶ğ—°
Allasso Pulse is a low-level Python coding environment that users can access via hosted workspaces. It puts no limits on the trading logic and gives full access to market data (i.e., implied vols) and strategy state (i.e., delta) throughout the backtest.

Any combination of â€œwhatâ€ and â€œwhenâ€ can be tested.

ğ—›ğ—²ğ—±ğ—´ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—±ğ—®ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ˜† ğ—®ğ˜ ğ˜€ğ—²ğ˜ğ˜ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—ºğ—²ğ—»ğ˜â€”ğ˜„ğ—µğ—¶ğ—°ğ—µ ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¹ğ˜ğ—® ğ—±ğ—²ğ—³ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ—»ğ˜€?
In ğ—™ğ—¶ğ—´ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—² ğŸ­, the mean values are simply the arithmetic average of the previous 5 observations, which includes the previous straddle deltas. The implied-volatility-reduced ones are based on the last observed implied volatility, minus a 15% haircut.

Scope 3 emissions: less counting. More cutting.

Did our credo inspire the Scope 3 Peer Group when they summed up where the industry really is right now? Hard to say, but the alignment was striking.

A few takeaways that resonated strongly:
1ï¸âƒ£ There are big similarities and big differences across industries when tackling Scope 3. One size absolutely does not fit all.
2ï¸âƒ£ Scope 3 was not a top CPO priority in 2025. And yet, progress is happening.
3ï¸âƒ£ Suppliers are now being asked for carbon data by customers representing ~33% of their revenues.
4ï¸âƒ£ Customer pressure is the main driver of SBTi adoption.
5ï¸âƒ£ Collaboration initiatives have matured: faster, better outcomes, less duplication of effort. 
6ï¸âƒ£ There are tons of tools, but none of them will fix bad data.
7ï¸âƒ£ Product-level data sparks endless debate: the â€œholy grailâ€ for some, â€œcomplete bullsh!tâ€ for others. Why the obsession? Because itâ€™s hard and expensive to do well.
8ï¸âƒ£True leaders go far beyond GHG data: they understand what suppliers are doing on renewable electricity, heat, feedstocks, raw material recycling, and more.
9ï¸âƒ£ Thereâ€™s a clear fatigue around data-for-dataâ€™s-sake. Everyone wants action and outcomes - even if auditor pressure is still very real.

Different networks. Different climates.
But the same urgency.

Managing leak backlogs with limited field teams.
Scaling digital transformation across entire countries.

Balancing infrastructure investments with tight budgets.
What stood out most?

The willingness to learn from each other.
The openness to collaborate across borders.

Water doesn't respect boundaries.
And neither should the solutions.

Spain. Water. Utilities. Action.
... A perfect week to look forward to!

I'm excited to be attending WEX Global 2026, taking place in #Seville, 9â€“11th February, together with my colleague Ritse Klink, Water Alliance and the total #Dutch delegation! 

This year's theme, "Water, Energy & Climate Change: From Vision to Action â€“ Realising a World of Water Abundance," couldn't be more relevant.

What draws me most to this event: one to one conversations. In our work at HULO.ai, we see daily how utilities are balancing urgent infrastructure challenges with the reality of climate stress. The gap between ambition and implementation can feel wide, but that's exactly where collaboration and intelligence matter most.

Water abundance starts with better stewardship of what we already have. Every leak prevented, every network optimized, every decision made faster brings us closer to resilient systems that serve communities and ecosystems alike.

I'm looking forward to learning from peers who are solving real problems in real time, and sharing what we've learned about making water systems more resilient through data and AI. These conversations matter because the challenges we face demand collective wisdom, not isolated solutions. 

Next to that, I'm looking forward catching up with friends that were made during the last two WEX editions. 

Vamos!!! 

If you're attending, let's connect.
Find out more at wex-global.com

ğŸ¤” Are we underestimating how much trust shapes the way people shop during peak season? 

This week we shared the latest Burbank Software report, Make Trust Pay. The findings show that shoppers are not abandoning checkouts because the deal is poor. They are abandoning because the payment process does not feel safe ğŸ” 

The data highlights something significant. Trust has become the strongest predictor of whether a shopper completes a purchase, and the gap is widening across age groups.

A few insights stand out:

ğŸ’³ Only 5 per cent of UK adults feel very comfortable entering card details online
ğŸ‘µ Older shoppers hold the most spending power but feel the least secure when purchasing online
ğŸ†” More than half say identity checks are confusing or off-putting

As we move through the peak shopping season, the question is no longer how fast a checkout is, but whether it feels recognisable, consistent and safe.

When Telecom Operators want to offer cybersecurity services to existing SMB business customers, they usually face three bad options:

Option 1: Refer to a third party -> revenue goes elsewhere. So does the customer's trust.

Option 2: Build it yourself 18 months. Massive budget. New hires. Complex tooling. High risk. Unclear ROI. And your core business isn't cybersecurity.

Option 3: Do nothing Easiest short-term. Expensive long-term. Competitors start offering it. Your ARPU stalls, churn increases

Here's what's missing from this list: a fourth option.

One that doesn't require you to hire security teams, operate a SOC, or explain CVSS scores to your sales people.

But will help you to increase ARPU from your existing SMB customers!

We'll be at MWC Barcelona (March 2-5) showing what that looks like in practice.

If you're attending and tired of those three bad options, let's talk.Â

Sources: SBTi (Trend Tracker / company statistics) and Global Carbon Budget 2025 â€“ LMU Munich, November 2025.

Boston Consulting Group (BCG) just quantified what we've been saying:

Supplier engagement is 9x more impactful than any other Scope 3 action.

But:
â€¢ Only 36% of corporates engage suppliers
â€¢ Only 4% partner with them on actual reduction

The gap? Most approaches treat suppliers as data sources, not partners.
Real progress happens when suppliers see ROI for themselvesâ€”not just compliance pressure.

That's why ctrl+s GmbH focuses on trajectory over footprints:Â 
â†’ Forward-looking engagement scales
â†’ Retrospective data collection doesn't

Source: BCG Carbon Action Report 2025

While ESRS simplification eases reporting burden, the operational challenge remains:

How do you actually drive Scope 3 reductions at scale?

Most companies can model emissions across their full upstream chain. The challenge isn't a lack of numbersâ€”it's a lack of influence.

For most organizations, practical control stops at Tier 1.

But up to 70% of Scope 3 emissions sit beyond Tier 1, embedded in the suppliers of suppliers. That's where most decarbonization efforts stall.

You cannot reduce what you cannot reach.

The path forward isn't about collecting more data. It's about building systems where every supplierâ€”no matter their position in the chainâ€”contributes to measurable progress.

Custody without yield. Or yield without custody.

A European asset manager faced this exact tradeoff, holding â‚¬47M in digital assets across Fireblocks but unable to generate staking returns without moving assets off custody.

They integrated our platform in 14 days.

Result: 30+ chains accessible, 5.2% average yield, zero custody transfers. Assets never left their security perimeter. Full audit trail maintained.

The custody-yield dilemma isn't theoretical. It's costing institutions millions in unrealized returns.

Want to see how custody-integrated yield works for your institution? Message us.

Operational continuity is the part of institutional staking that doesnâ€™t get enough airtime â€” and itâ€™s usually where implementations succeed or fail.
This piece breaks down what â€œcontinuityâ€ really looks like in practice: resilient validator coverage, clear operational controls, incident readiness, and the ability to keep yield running without introducing custody or compliance risk.

If youâ€™re a bank, asset manager, or exchange evaluating staking (or reviewing an existing setup), DM me.

Proud to partner with Blockdaemon on this integration.
For banks, asset managers, and exchanges, the key is simple: broader validator choice and redundancy, without introducing asset-movement risk.
Excited to see more institutions unlock yield with custody control intact!

In 2026, institutional portfolios are evolving beyond simple Bitcoin.

Allocations now blend:
- Bitcoin & Ethereum core exposure

- DeFi-based yield
- Stakingâ€‘based yield

Each component introduces yieldâ€”but also operational, regulatory, and custody implications.

From 6-week integration to live staking.

A European asset manager needed to stake institutional holdings without moving assets from Fireblocks custody. Regulatory constraints made traditional staking impossible.

We deployed our custody-integrated infrastructure in 42 days. They now stake across 8 protocols, maintaining full custody control and audit trails.

Result: 4.2% yield on previously idle assets. Zero custody transfers. Complete compliance documentation.

This is what institutional blockchain infrastructure should look like.

Curious how custody-integrated yield works for your institution? Let's talk.

Custody and yield. No longer a tradeoff. 

Institutions want yield, but not at the expense of control or compliance. The next era of blockchain finance will be defined by seamless, regulated integration. 

At @Colossus Digital, we connect custody (@Fireblocks, @Ledger Enterprise, @Dfns) with yield protocols (@Aave, @Morpho), so you never have to move assets or compromise security. 

Ready to future-proof your digital asset strategy? Letâ€™s talk.

Ethereum validator activation queues are back on the risk register.

The chart says it plainly: entry wait times can stretch to ~70 days. For banks and Fintechs, that is not just a nuisance. It is execution risk, delayed time-to-yield, and operational overhead when you need to scale staking programs.

Colossus Institutional Hub is built to reduce that operational drag.

What changes with Colossus Digital  
- Operator-agnostic validator management: keep your existing validator operators and custody setup.
- Enterprise controls: policy-guarded workflows, approvals, and auditability.
- Scale operations, not headcount: move from one-validator-per-transaction workflows to batched, automated execution.

Tech details (Ethereum Pectra)
Pectra (May 2025) upgrades the validator stack with:
- EIP-7251: Max Effective Balance to 2,048 ETH, enabling consolidation and fewer validator keys.
- EIP-7002: Execution-layer exits and withdrawals, making lifecycle actions programmable.
- EIP-7702: temporary code for a single transaction, enabling atomic multicall batches, policy controls, and safer large-scale operations without moving funds to a smart wallet.

In practice, this means you can run institutional-grade workflows such as:
- Batch 0x01 to 0x02 switching (1 to 200 validators)
- Batch partial withdrawals (1 to 200)
- Batch EL exits (1 to 200)

If you are planning an ETH staking program or scaling an existing one, we can walk you through the exact operational model and controls.

DM me for a live demo of the Institutional Hub for Ethereum validator fleet management.

Staking regulations just fragmented across three continents.

CDP results are not looking good.

Last year, looking at the same graph shared by Vincent Manier I said the trend was driven by unexpected methodology changes, and that the impact will still persist a year later. Processes donâ€™t change that fast, new metrics canâ€™t be gathered mid-year, and budgets need to be approved way ahead.

And now we are seeing exactly that:

ğŸ”· Companies maintaining poorer scores than two years before, or even dropping further
ğŸ”· Many companies opting out of the assessment altogether

To be fair, another reason companies are opting out (beyond CDPâ€™s methodology extravagance) is the lack of value they get in return for the enormous effort required to submit.

If CDP wants to maintain its position, it urgently needs to learn to be more client/user - oriented. They are too smug to admit own mistakes, too condescending to work with tech companies instead of developing own _not_really_working_ tech, and too full of themselves to even consider that they need to show clear benefits to participating companies beyond a Google folder with a â€œwe are an A-lister!â€ LinkedIn post.

Companies will keep dropping out unless one of two things happens: the value goes up dramatically (10x) to justify months of work, or the total cost of participation drops enough (3x) to make it a tolerable exercise. Right now, itâ€™s neither.

I've been involved in building startups for about 30 years - most recently my current venture Ailuna. Most people who follow me, know that.

But what many don't know is that I have also been involved in endurance sports such as Ironman, ultra running, cross country skiing etc. for almost as long. I've had my ups and downs business wise - and I have had my ups and downs sports wise. 

The endurance learned from going long in sports carries over to determination and going long in business, where things sometimes don't go according to plan. And success in business brings new motivation to one's sports endeavors. 

I have deliberately kept my sports activities off LinkedIn and instead shared what I have been doing sports wise on Facebook and on Strava. But inspired by some of my business friends, who are also involved in sports on the side, I thought I would give those who are interested a view into what I have been through over the years. 

12 Ironman distance races, including Norseman and 5x Ironman Lanzarote, countless shorter distance triathlons, Marathon des Sables 250K ultra run in the desert in Morocco, Cape Wrath Ultra 400K run in the Scottish highlands, several Vasaloppet 90K and Birkebeiner 56K cross country ski races in Sweden and Norway, several 106K XNRG Pilgrim's Challenge ultras, 300K Dragon Ride (Devil route) bike sportive, countless marathons...

And it really didn't begin until I turned 40 where I completed my first Ironman. It's never too late to get started.

So why am I sharing this? 

Really only to say that for some, such as my good friends Keith Williams, Pelle Nilsson, many others and myself, it's what keeps us sane. Although some may find some of what we've gotten ourselves into, a bit insane. For us, it's part of who we are. It's how we leave the business world behind for a few hours, enjoy getting out there and recharge our batteries.

You only live once - and it's all about getting the most and best out of our time and energy on earth. Being inspired by what others do - and that hopefully, what we do, could be inspiring for some, as well.

In case anybody is interested in hearing a little about my journey through sports, I had a chat with Micky Collins on his inspiring "From Iron Maiden to Ironman" podcast last week. 

Who would have thought that I would end up on a sports podcast some day? Well, that's what happened :-)

Hope you like it.

https://lnkd.in/eXTNH2cR

Negli scorsi giorni sono usciti due report estremamente interessanti contenenti i benchmark sull'efficacia dei canali di marketing.

Il primo report Ã¨ di Stella (Brenden Delarua) segnalato qui su LinkedIn da Alessia Smeragliuolo (grazie) e pubblicato nel Dicembre 2025.

Il secondo Ã¨ di Cassandra (Gabriele Franco), pubblicato proprio pochissimi giorni fa.

Richiedono una conoscenza minima della tematica per essere letti, quindi ho pensato di farne una sintesi.

--

ğŸ‘‰ Premessa:
Cassandra. Quasi 2 miliardi di investimento pubblicitario analizzato (2020-2025). Diversi mercati e business model. 1.221 modellazioni del Media Mix (MMM) eseguite su 123 brand.

Stella ha analizzato 225 test di incrementalitÃ  di brand prevalentemente USA ed Ecommerce (2024-2025). Esperimenti controllati con focus geografico (geo-based).

Due metodologie diverse (e complementari) per rispondere alla stessa domanda: che impatto ha davvero ogni canale?

--

ğŸ“Š Canali presi in esame:
Quelli che i progetti avevano attivi. Alcuni esempi: Google, Meta, TikTok, Bing, Amazon, Pinterest, Out-Of-Home, Native Ads, Programmatic, ecc..

--

âš¡ Punti d'incontro dei due:

ğŸ“Œ Meta: riportano un ROI mediano di 2.94x (Cassandra) vs 2.92x (Stella). Quasi identici.

ğŸ“Œ Suggeriscono di non guardate solo il ROI mediano. Cassandra introduce il "Risk-Adjusted ROI" (penalizza l'alta varianza di un canale). Stella parla di "Coefficient of Variation" (coefficiente della varianza del canale).

ğŸ“Œ Google e Meta riconosciuti come scalabili, prevedibili, affidabili. 

ğŸ“Œ Suggeriscono un approccio che contempli i canali in base allo scopo/fase. Cassandra li suddivide in Foundation, Growth, Innovation. Stella li clusterizza in Scale Aggressively, Core Performance, Optimize Carefully, Defensive Minimum. Molto differenti fra loro, ma interessante il suggerimento di diversificare di conseguenza.

--

âš ï¸ Divergenze e differenze

TikTok: Cassandra riporta 2.2x ROI mediano, Stella solo 0.94x (sotto breakeven). Entrambi ammettono che c'Ã¨ alta varianza, dipende dunque molto dall'esecuzione.

Google: Cassandra aggrega tutto a 4.37x ROI mediano.  Stella scompone in singole tipologie di campagna: Performance Max: 2.98x; Shopping: 1.86x; Search Non-Brand: 1.46x; Search Branded: 0.70x (eh sÃ¬, la brand protection non aggiunge conversioni, le ruba altrove).

Pinterest: alta varianza nei dati Cassandra e pochissimi dati per Stella (3 casi) con perÃ² ottimi ROI.

--

Ãˆ necessario ricordare i requisiti di ciascun approccio:

ğŸ”¹ Per fare MMM servono dati storici consistenti, media mix complesso, e budget significativi. 

ğŸ”¹ Per fare test di incrementalitÃ  serve avere chiara la domanda specifica a cui si vuole rispondere, tempo per eseguire esperimenti (30-40 giorni), e accettare che si sta misurando un elemento per volta.

ğŸ”¹ Per chi cerca qualcosa di piÃ¹ immediato, tattico e sempre attivo, l'attribuzione multi-touch rimane l'opzione piÃ¹ accessibile (se ti interessa l'argomento: convalytrix.it)

[Build in Public] Defining **how to communicate** is #1 priority for a new product team

Cassandra has grown from 7 to 20+ people in less than 5 months 

Mostly hiring tech, product and R&D 

Specialized people dedicated to substitute and improve the work done by the co-founders. 

Now we have a cross functional team working together 

The tendency for everyone new, is to join the company and start speaking the language of their domain expertise. 

This phenomena lead to people not understanding each other, running too many meetings, working a lot, but progressing really little. 

This leads inevitably to lack of clarity and frustration in the whole organization. 

The solution is establishing a culture on how cross functional teams need to communicate

2 books that helped me a lot during this process: 

1. Inspired by Marty Cagan (best book on product I've ever read)

2. Pyramid Principle by Barbara Minto (How to present Your Thinking So Clearly That Ideas Jump Off the Page and into the Reader's Mind)

Hope these can be helpful to other founders in the same stage 


PS Reminder for everyone in the startup industry:

âŒ Communication is not sharing informations to another party

âœ… Communication is making the other party understand your thesis

As many of you will know, I'm a big fan of a musically-twisted quote - so full credit to the Institute and Faculty of Actuaries for referring to Nature like this: "Every breath we take, every bread we break, every thirst we slake ... I'll be wanting you"! (with apologies to Sting and the Police).

In addition, I greatly enjoyed reading their latest musings ('Nature at risk, models at fault' - well worth a read if you get the chance), in which they noted that:" the three realities are: (1) the impact of biodiversity risks to UK economy and financial institutions are equal or greater than climate risks, (2) climate and biodiversity are intrinsically linked and mutual reinforcing, and (3) the outcome of climate and biodiversity pathways are fundamental to understanding the potential state of our future economy and macro-economic impacts to financial institutions".

The Institute of Sustainability and Environmental Professionals (ISEP) thought similarly in their piece, 'Natural capital is critical infrastructure', and of course the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales (ICAEW) agreed in 'Why Nature matters to accountants'. 

So all agreed that Nature matters, but how do we make it an attractive proposition to institutional investors?  Well we could start by talking in a familiar language about risks and returns.  My thoughts attached - comments welcome

1. Tecnologia Ã¨ la base: significa dati affidabili e accessibili. Esempio banale ma concreto nel mondo #retail: la fidelity card, gli scontrini, le rotture di stock, i resi, le promozioni, i reclami. Se questi dati sono sparsi, incompleti o non â€œparlanoâ€ tra loro, qualsiasi progetto si ferma.

3. Innovazione, infine, Ã¨ il processo con cui trasformi queste capacitÃ  in un nuovo modo di lavorare: nuove decisioni, nuove responsabilitÃ , nuove metriche. Non Ã¨ un software: Ã¨ cambiare lâ€™operativitÃ .

Cosa dicono i numeri: la mancanza di #competenze frena quasi il 60% di chi ha valutato di investire in progetti ad alto contenuto tecnologico.

Problemi di produttivitÃ  di negozio, assortimenti non performanti, prodotti non disponibili e prezzi non competitivi sono tutti figli di un unico grande problema: la mancanza di una visione oggettiva e data-driven.

Launching today. But honestly, the market launched this for us.

We didn't make our AI Router standalone because of a roadmap decision. We made it because the market kept sending the same signals, and eventually they became too loud to ignore.

Here's what we kept hearing:

60%+ of our customers we spoke with were already routing. Built in-house, cobbled together, quietly draining engineering time. Not because they wanted to build infrastructure but because nothing purpose-built existed for them.

European teams were asking harder questions than most. Not "which model performs best" but "where does inference actually happen?", "which providers are in our critical path?", "how do we change that when regulations shift?" Sovereignty stopped being a policy discussion. It became an architectural decision.

And when we looked at enterprise adoption patterns, the picture was consistent. Teams weren't struggling to find good models. They were struggling to stay in control as the number of models grew. More than a third of enterprises now run five or more LLMs in production. The complexity compounds fast.

What tied it all together: enterprises don't want another point solution. They want optionality. The ability to start small, stay in control, and adapt as the landscape changes without committing to a full platform before they're ready.

Routing is exactly that. A lightweight entry point that solves a real production problem on day one.

Sharing our company post below, and the full Signals story is in the comments if you want to go deeper.

Start here: router[.]orq[.]ai

Gartner estimates that by 2028, 60% of software engineering teams will use AI evaluation and observability platforms to build trust in AI applications up from just 18% in 2025.

Weâ€™re glad to see orq.ai mentioned in Gartnerâ€™s Market Guide for AI Evaluation and Observability Platforms (published February 2, 2026).

The guide underscores why evaluation and observability are becoming essential:
â€¢ GenAI systems areÂ nondeterministic, making traditional testing unreliable
â€¢ Production behavior mattersÂ â€“ failures and drift only show up at runtime
â€¢ Teams needÂ continuous evals, combining offline testing with live signals to track quality, safety, and reliability

That direction mirrors why we built orq.ai in the first place. To help teams evaluate, observe, and improve AI systems across the full lifecycle, not just before deployment.

This market is still early, but the shift is already underway. Teams that invest in eval-driven development today will be the ones shipping AI they can actually trust tomorrow.

I am increasingly convinced that AI agents will start looking less like features or tools and more likeÂ organizational resources.
Not in a metaphorical sense, but in very practical ways.

They will have costs, performance variance, failure modes, governance needs, and ownership questions. The economics of agents are very different from human teams, and if enterprises donâ€™t proactively manage this, things can spiral quickly.

Thatâ€™s one of the themes I am personally curious to explore in this upcoming discussion with orq.ai, Miyagami, Lleverage, and AdamI on where agentic AI economy is heading in 2026 at Zoku Amsterdam, and what teams should start preparingÂ now, not later.

Looking forward to learning from others who are thinking deeply about this.

In the past month at orq.ai, Iâ€™ve seen a pattern repeat across every enterprise:
The ambition for AI is huge, but the ability to get it into production is painfully limited.

The demos look great. The prototypes are promising.
However, the moment they encounter real data and operational complexity, accuracy drops, behavior becomes unpredictable, and teams lack a structured way to diagnose or improve performance.

Without a framework for evaluation, iteration, and continuous learning, projects often stall, and most AI initiatives never progress beyond the prototype stage.
This gap between building AI and actually running AI in production is where so many companies get stuck and itâ€™s exactly the space where orq.ai operates.

What excites me about orq.ai is how intentionally weâ€™ve built a unified control layer for AI agents: a platform where teams can design agents their own way, evaluate them with real signals, monitor behavior, and deploy with full clarity over data and governance. All in one place, all built for the realities of enterprise environments.

As someone who cares deeply about transforming complex ideas into operational systems, this mission resonates strongly, and it has been inspiring to see how customers across Europe and the US are already utilizing orq.ai to transition from experimentation to real-world production.

And today marks an important milestone in this journey: weâ€™re announcing a â‚¬5M seed round to help accelerate our vision.

My work mode has changed radically in the last 6 months. More than ever before. Itâ€™s AI first now.


Am e.g. using Claude Code for video animations. Very powerful.

But: Without paying attention, it can get risky quickly.

As you can see in the pic:

Claude Code decided to auto download a package it needed for image enhancement. I had not given Claude permission to do so..

This is a great example of the inherent challenge with agents:

-> Agents will only unfold their full potential if we let them act autonomously. Meaning: let them connect to other systems. And come up with paths to solve problems.

-> Still, someone has to control (review) these permissions. And this layer is entirely missing today.

In other words:

For broad agent adoption, we have to get the authorisation model right.

This must include:

-> Delegation: Who introduced the agent? And with what basic scopes?
-> Dynamic permissions: What scopes does an agent identity need per job?
-> Audit trail: How can we keep track of each agent job (and the respective dynamic permissions)?

More to come - very soon.

Why AI agents need access control.

Key takes:

-> â€œAI agents can read and modify third party systems with static access and broad scopes.â€

-> â€œAn agent by nature will always do whatever it takes in order to complete its task.â€

-> â€It might decide to download certain packages without your prior permission. It might mean that it goes to a third party database and deletes certain data (â€¦) or start sharing some of your secrets.â€

-> â€œAgents need dynamic job specific access control with short term permissions and the scopes needed for each job.â€

Humans give AI agents a â€œgod statusâ€.

-> Long lived access tokens
-> With broad permission scopes

So the new billion dollar question in security is:

How can security, IT and eng enable their teams with agents? And still stay in control?

Hosting a session on this with: 

The great Mackenzie Jackson from the great Aikido Security:

If youâ€™re in security, IT or eng, this is a must-watch.

Join us. Recording included:

https://lnkd.in/dCUpEQNJ

Literally: Donâ€™t!

People are bored of: old school sales calls.

People are bored of: vague websites with blurry promises.

People want: immediate value.

Otherwise: bye ğŸ‘‹

So, here we go:

Dont book a demo with us.

What OpenClaw or similar AI agents are your teams using?

Do you know?

Controlling AI agent access is: THE new big frontier in identity management.

The traditional security model will not fly to control AI agents.

NON-AI WORLD:
-> Identity: One known identity (the human) 
-> Access logic: Access to one system â†’ Permissions: Static
-> Auth: Usually via SSO

AI WORLD:
-> Identity: Non-human (often with sub agents) â†’ Access logic: Multiple system-to-system accesses per agent 
-> Permissions: Should be dynamic/job-based (not the case today, big issue!) 
-> Auth: Today mostly via API key or OAuth (but that canâ€™t be the solution)

STILL, TO GET GOING, COMPANIES ARE STRUGGLING WITH THE FUNDAMENTALS:

-> What agents are being used? 
-> What permissions do they have? 
-> How can I keep an audit/compliance trail?

How do you get going to control access of AI agents in your company?

OpenClaw and Moltbook is like an out of control house party.

If it werenâ€™t so serious: itâ€™d be a super fun story.


WHAT HAPPENED?

OpenClaw (Clawdbots) is an open source AI agent for tedious tasks. Went viral.

People install it on their laptops. And give it unrestricted access to:

Email, files, calendar, browser, shell, secrets.

The agent then autonomously downloads new skills.

Which can (via the shell/terminal) create new sub agents. With the same access permissions as the parent.


YOU GET THE POINT ALREADY, BUT THEN:

150,000 of these agents joined Moltbook (Reddit for AI agents).

Here they started sharing secrets, like API keys.


THINK OF IT LIKE THIS:

Youâ€™re inviting people you donâ€™t know to your house party.

They can invite other people. Doorâ€™s wide open.

Your â€œguestsâ€ can walk into all rooms. Access your online banking.

And share all of this on social media.

AI agent access needs governance. Or we are fu**

PS: Interested to learn how we're tackling AI agent access? Then DM me.

This is why AI agents are great for work. But TERRIBLE for security.


â€œThe video you'll see in a second â€¦ was entirely produced by AI.â€

â€œAI, no doubt, is a massive driver of efficiency. But: It's also a massive security risk.â€

â€œI gave the agent access to other company systems: Our G drive, our product documentation.â€

â€œWe will need to find a way to govern access of agents. Otherwise, it's a ticking security time bomb.â€

People are calling Stockholm the San Francisco of Europe.

So its no surprise that Stockholm is also: a hub of Cakewalk customers.

If you walk through town: The density of great companies is in fact incredible.

Fast growing companies increasingly understand: 

Access management is not about IT saying â€œnoâ€. 

Done right, it's a practice to enable your company's growth.

PS: It gets dark at 3:40 PM in January in Stockholm. So what else could you do - apart from building a generational company?

What is the problem with the RBAC model?

Not the model.
The follow through.

On 3 February, I am joining Johannes Keienburg (PhD) for a conversation on scaling access management in 2026, without growing your IT team to explore this topic in depth. ğŸ‘‡

Access is now created everywhere:
â€¢ AI agents
â€¢ apps
â€¢ teams
â€¢ vendors

And that is exactly why RBAC still matters.

RBAC is one of the highest ROI controls in security.

When it is adopted well, you get:
â€¢ faster onboarding, because access is packaged
â€¢ fewer mistakes, because permissions are predictable
â€¢ cleaner audits, because you can explain who gets what, and why
â€¢ safer change, because you remove one off grants

The downside?

RBAC is a program, not a document.

It fails when it becomes â€œwrite policy, ship policy, forget policy.â€

If you want RBAC adoption, do this:
1. Start with the 10 roles that generate 80% of access
2. Build roles around outcomes, not titles
3. Keep roles small, then combine them like Lego
4. Put ownership on the business, not only IT
5. Tie access to joiner, mover, and leaver, so it stays current
6. Review roles on triggers, not a calendar reminder

RBAC does not need to be perfect.

It needs to be usable.

What is the biggest thing blocking RBAC adoption in your org right now?

Your CEO goes: â€œF that process!â€ 

After you designed a picture perfect access control policy. 

What then?

Court decisions are public domain. At least in theory. 

But it varies greatly across countries, jurisdictions and courts. This is something we obsess over at Pandektes, as we're focused on building the largest legal database in existence.

In practice, only a fraction of case law makes it into the databases legal professionals rely on every day, and sometimes even there they remain difficult to surface.

Recent German research by ARDâ€™s legal editorial team and the SWR Data Lab looked at German civil and administrative court decisions from 2023 and 2024.
The results are sobering:

The nationwide average of published decisions is 3.5%. Some states publish as little as 1.5%. 

Several regional courts published none at all.

Many courts consider routine cases irrelevant for publication. A large share of court work is seen as repetitive, mass business. 

What is relevant and not relevant is an interesting discussion, and something that should be continuously addressed along with the development of technology.

But there is also a practical bottleneck: time and staff. Every decision must be anonymized before publication. In many courts, that still happens manually.

For practitioners this has the possibility to create a distorted picture of reality. Legacy databases show a limited part of jurisprudence. As we do not have all the data, we do not know the unknowns.

This inconsistency and lack of completeness is part of what we're solving in Pandektes.

Legal intelligence has a data problem. In order to take legal research and analysis into the future, we need a better and more complete data infrastructure. 

That's what we're building at Pandektes.

At Pandektes we're growing faster than ever, and weâ€™re looking for exceptional people to join us.

Our mission is to build the worldâ€™s largest legal database, with search and analysis that fundamentally change how legal analysis is done. At scale.

Buy vs build?

Before I get into this (and yes, probably biased), I want to caveat that I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s a "right" answer here.

Itâ€™s never been easier to build internally. At Adclear, if itâ€™s something weâ€™re specialists in, weâ€™ll build it ourselves.

BUT, AI tools are never fixed in place. Keeping them maintained and production-ready over time is hard enough on its own. And itâ€™s not even just the AI, itâ€™s everything around it.

Youâ€™re building something that needs to be configurable and adaptable without turning into a mess. In our case, something that marketers actually enjoy using, but that product, design AND compliance also feel comfortable with. On top of that, it has to be enterprise-level auditable, secure, reliable â€” and still sleek.

That depth is where things get hard, and itâ€™s where most internal builds start to struggle. How much resource do you really want to put into all of that for something thatâ€™s ultimately worse than whatâ€™s already out there? I recently spoke with the CEO of one of the biggest crypto players in the world who said the same thing.

Why would we try and build our own Granola or Attio?

Weâ€™re seeing the same thing across loads of organisations. Teams decide to build their own internal marketing compliance tool because it seems easy at the time, but they always come back. And theyâ€™re usually our most active users. Maybe itâ€™s just appreciation for how difficult this actually is after theyâ€™ve tried (and not quite done it successfully).

Soâ€¦ do what you think is best for your organisation and donâ€™t necessarily listen to someone on LinkedIn (e.g., me). But if your company isnâ€™t specialising in something, and unless what youâ€™re trying to build is SUPER simple, it might be better buying.

â€‹Iâ€‹ had a great chatÂ this week with Doni and Joe from Adclear. 

We spent time talking about a shift in fintech that I think is going unnoticed: the rise of the #ComplianceEngineer.
We all know that manual review for financial promos is becoming impossible to manage. The best fintech marketers are testing lots of content variants, and AI is making content creation much easierâ€‹. But as content volume goes up, the current â€‹complianceÂ system breaks.
Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m so excited about what Adclear is doingâ€”and why I invested in them. They are shifting the paradigm from manual reviews to compliance as infrastructure.
By using AI to enforce policy automatically, they aren't replacing compliance teams; they are freeing them up to focus on high-level strategy and complex risk.â€‹Â Defining the policies, not enforcing them. It is helping them "engineer" compliance. 
It feels like the inevitable next step for the industry.

And shout out to at Caravan Restaurants | B Corpâ„¢ in King's Cross. My second office ğŸ˜Š

Working with more principal firms and BaaS providers has pushed the challenge of how you truly build a consistent, accurate, and tailored AI system for subjective subjects when there are so many stakeholders involved.

Adclear has always been built to be tailored to a firmâ€™s permissions, risk appetite and internal interpretation of the rules. That works well when youâ€™re dealing with one organisation and one compliance team.

Principal firms and BaaS providers change the dynamic.

Youâ€™re no longer working with a single interpretation of â€œacceptableâ€. Youâ€™re working with many - across authorised representatives, business models and use cases - all sitting under the same regulatory umbrella.

The challenge isnâ€™t choosing theÂ rightÂ interpretation. Itâ€™s building a system that can accommodate that ongoing discourse, without collapsing into inconsistency or endless exceptions.

In practice, marketing compliance at principal-firm level is less about tailoring every decision, and more about capturing those learnings and turning them into something durable. And this isnâ€™t just limited to them, these learnings have helped push Adclear to continue to lead the way in the space.

Whoâ€™s really running your EV charging network?

You are, right? You bought the hardware. You secured the location. You connected to the grid. You pay the energy bills every month.

But here's what you don't own: 

1 - You don't decide what drivers pay. Resellers set that price - while adding their own margins on top.

2 - You don't see your customers. 80-90% of sessions come through reseller apps. You get a settlement report with transaction volumes but no customer data.

3 - You don't control when you get paid. Revenue sits with resellers for 30-60 days while you're covering real-time costs and are exposed to credit risk.

So what exactly do you own?

The infrastructure. The risk. The expenses.

Every operator I talk to knows this. And they're quietly furious about it.

But most have convinced themselves this is just how EV charging works. That you need resellers to reach drivers, that giving up control is the price of distribution.

It's not.

We built Cariqa because we believe operators deserve to own what they have built.

A platform model where operators and drivers transact directly. No resellers extracting value.

You set the price. You see every customer. You get instant settlement and keep the margin.

2.6Ã— ad-hoc charging revenue.
2.45Ã— ad-hoc energy sold.

This is exactly why we built Cariqa Go.
Ad-hoc charging is often treated as a compliance checkbox, something you â€œhave toâ€ offer.

But when operators have real control over pricing, settlement and brand experience? It becomes a serious commercial lever.

With enercity, this wasnâ€™t about swapping one QR page for another. It was about putting control back where it belongs, giving them:

â†’Backend-agnostic deployment
â†’Granular tariff and fee configuration
â†’Station and connector-level pricing
â†’Multiple payment methods
â†’Direct settlement
â†’Full brand visibility, from checkout to invoice

enercity rolled out Cariqa Go across their network and ran a like-for-like comparison against their previous QR solution, normalised for 27% network growth.

The outcome?
Ad-hoc charging revenue and energy sold more than doubled.

When you treat ad-hoc charging as a strategic channel - not an afterthought - performance follows.

Huge thanks to Constantin Reese, Annkathrin Scheck, Luca Diem and the entire enercity team for the collaboration and trust. Working with operators who know exactly what they want commercially makes all the difference.

If youâ€™re a CPO, hereâ€™s the real question: Is your ad-hoc setup actively driving revenue, or is it just sitting there?

I had a call with a CPO last week who pulled up his station on four different EV charging apps.

Same charger. Same kWh. Four wildly different prices, none of them set by him.

This is the EV charging industry in 2026.

Operators build the infrastructure, pay the energy costs, take on the risk and then watch resellers add their own markups and control what drivers actually pay.

The result is pricing that's completely distorted, leaving drivers navigating a puzzle of apps and hidden fees, with no idea who to trust.

We built Cariqa because we believe that a platform model will be better for everyone.

Operators and drivers interact directly, which means that operators can:

Control their own prices
Enjoy instant settlements
Have a direct sales channel with customers and total visibility of their behaviour
Boost station utilisation with dynamic pricing

While drivers get the transparent, direct, operator-set pricing, however they choose to pay.

The operators who took on the risk and built the infrastructure deserve to run the business. Not watch from the sidelines while resellers extract value.

That's what we're fixing.
***
The EV Charging Reseller Model Is Broken. We're Fixing It. https://www.cariqa.com/

Back then, every single conversation began with explaining why the market doesnâ€™t work the way it should. Why CPOs lose control. Why drivers pay marked-up prices. Why itâ€™s all unnecessarily complicated.

Every New Year starts the same. At least for me...
New resolutions. 
I was just writing mine for 2026.

Somewhere between â€œdrink more waterâ€ and â€œless screen timeâ€, I realised I got distracted. And while â€œget less distractedâ€ was also on the list, this one felt worth it.

I thought, what if the EV charging industry were a person with aspirations? 
Iâ€™m pretty sure the EV charging industries New Year resolutions would look something like this:

- Accept that Iâ€™m no longer a small hobby and start acting accordingly
- Clean up my circle and keep only relationships that actually add value to key players in the market 
- Make pricing so simple EV drivers donâ€™t need a PhD to understand it
- Stop giving the same person five apps, three cards and 100 different prices
- Be interesting enough that people still talk about me when AI is in the room
- Stop getting beaten down by whatever decisions are made in politics. The tide has already turned, nothing can stop me...

2026 feels like the year this list stops being aspirational for the EV charging industry, while mine probably will be abandoned by the time this post goes live.

âš ï¸ Cheese alert, but I canâ€™t help itâ€¦ so bear with me.

Wrapping up 2025 and honestly trying to catch my breath for a second.
This year has been a big one for Cariqa.

We secured a â‚¬4M investment from incredible investors and welcomed amazing new CPOs. Just to name a few da emobil, CITYWATT GmbH, enercity and many more. Seeing more and more CPOs trust us and build with us has been incredibly motivating.

We also grew the team, and thatâ€™s probably what Iâ€™m most grateful for. I get to work with smart, driven people, we learn from each other every day, and we build something together that truly matters.

Iâ€™m especially thankful for Issam Tidjani, Stefano Bonetta and Mario La Pergola. Weâ€™re very different people, but we complement each other in the best possible way. Fully focused, and maybe just a little obsessed with rewriting the EV charging market.

I canâ€™t wait to start the new year. Iâ€™m excited, motivated, and genuinely grateful to be on this journey with the Cariqa team and so many great people across the industry.

Goodbye 2025. You were intense, challenging, and rewarding all at once.

Hello 2026. A year that brings us one step closer to a more transparent and fair EV charging market.

Sure, product matters. Leadership matters. Earning potential matters. But if you dread showing up on a Monday? It catches up with you fast.


This week our team headed to Silverstone, breathwork, tennis, yoga, sauna, and a brutally cold lake that absolutely nobody was ready for.


The kind of experience that strips away the work personas and reminds you that the people sitting next to you in the office are actually humans you genuinely enjoy spending time with.


When people like who they work with, performance follows. Not because someone told them to hit a number, because they don't want to let each other down.


Culture isn't a perk. It's the foundation everything else is built on.

The silent blocker holding most AI deployment and personalised health experiences back is something surprisingly basic.

Standardised lab data.

Despite shaping 70 percent of medical decisions and billions of tests run each year, lab data is still unusable for most healthtech and longevity companies.
Across hundreds of conversations with teams from labs, longevity clinics, insurers, startups and more, one pattern became impossible to ignore: the vision for personalised, AI-powered health is there, but the data foundation is not.

Why it is so difficult:
Â â€¢ The same biomarker can be measured in different materials, units and reference ranges, even inside the same country (especially in Europe and LatAm).
Â â€¢ Results arrive in every format you can imagine: PDFs, portals, APIs, images.
Â â€¢ Building standardisation or historical insights in-house means dedicated medical teams validating biomarker standards and months of engineering time mapping fragmented results.

The outcome is always the same: teams spend enormous resources on infrastructure instead of improving products, patient journeys or health outcomes. This is exactly the problem we built OpenHealth Technologies to solve. And next week, we want to share what we have learned supporting leading health organisations worldwide.

ğŸ™ï¸ Â On 16th December, I am hosting a 60 minute masterclass together with Frederic Muench, MD, andÂ Ivana Istochka: "Transforming Lab Data into Value with AI"

We will walk through:
Â â€¢ How to ingest biomarker data from any source at scale
Â â€¢ Why standardised data unlocks longitudinal insights, personalisation and AI
Â â€¢ How leading teams grow revenue, retention and customer love while saving engineering and medical resources
Â â€¢ Practical use cases from Aware, Roche, Oura, Function Health and others
Â â€¢ What is coming next in health data and AI deployment

Weâ€™re in a once in a generation moment not only in what technologies and companies get built, but also in who gets to build them.

Geopolitics, culture, AI, socio-economic shifts, access to information and toolsâ€¦ the world seems to be changing really fast. Itâ€™s very clear that weâ€™re living through a big moment.

Two weeks ago at Slush, Iâ€™m grateful I got the opportunity to connect with some of the founders, operators and investors shaping these changes (some who are huge inspirations of mine), spend time with friends, and learn. A lot.

A few learnings that really stayed with me:
> No matter what you're working on, speed of learning beats raw talent or unique ideas. Now more than ever.
> The real differentiator is constantly asking your customers "what is your biggest problem?" then putting stuff out for them, learning and iterating fast.
> Companies live in non-stationary reality: markets, constraints, and people change constantly. It's expected that your product, culture and story will keep evolving too. Don't fight it. 
> Stay open to a "yes, and" world where different, even competing truths coexist. Be careful of adopting someone else's experience as your own.
> Don't copy competitors, you'll converge. Learn from others doing one piece insanely well. Want sticky products in health? Maybe go study gaming.
> If you find something you enjoy doing, surround yourself with people who help you grow, and just show up every day, you can do things your own way and build something meaningful. (Proud to have a lot of this at OpenHealth Technologies)

The theme of the conference was about believing in Europe. I have to say, if Europe wants to matter, we need to create regulations that support innovation instead of blocking it ASAP, make it easier to incorporate and scale, and create smarter taxations and stock option plans (as someone who worked outside Europe most of my life, a lot of these things still shock me).

But I have a belief that we can, and we will.

Good Morning to the Xero developer/vendor community. What an email to wake up to. What do I think?

What weâ€™re NOT happy with: 
 - nothing. Iâ€™m okay with this. 

What weâ€™re HAPPY with: 

- ban on bots evens the playing field as vendors used this to short cut the strict rules Xero imposes on those of us building with their full API

- ban on using data for AI/ML training. This is going to knee cap some newer AI companies assuming quick wins without the hard yards to build your own IP and training data. 

Why am I happy? 

Weâ€™ve never accessed historical data - just about every accountant knows most clients donâ€™t have perfect, consistent data. Thatâ€™s a minefield leading to poor AI training anyway. 

We self-annotate every single document - and have done for 15months - with accountants on our payroll. Can you imagine how big and useful that asset is for us :D 

*Investors* in Accounting startups the last 24 months should audit their portfolio ASAP. 

Xero will want to audit some they already suspect, and ban them when/if they refuse. 

This is bad for innovation - as the data belongs to clients not Xero so I do think theyâ€™re overstepping a bit, but it proves how hard this problem is to solve. Donâ€™t take shortcuts. 

- Pay for access. Iâ€™m okay - I hated the marketplace % fee they forced on us as an Advanced Partner. As long as their API and documentation improves - I wonâ€™t complain. 

I know Xero want to make improvements to the API but this needs product & political support internally as they have the technical and BA capability to do this. Cause itâ€™s SUPER sh*te right now.

Results Series | Munich AI Hackathon

As a challenge sponsor, we provided participating teams with access to our ONE AI platform.

The challenge: Develop a working computer vision prototype within 24 hours and demonstrate how ONE AI can be used to
- run AI locally on lean devices,
- generate task-specific neural networks,
- and outperform generic AI approaches.

Our next spotlight:Â SkinGuard â€“ AI-powered initial skin assessment.

The Problem
Millions of people experience uncertainty when facing skin conditions:
- No trustworthy digital first assessment
- Google-driven worst-case anxiety
- Weeks of waiting for dermatology appointments

The team addressed a simple but powerful question: 

Can Vision AI provide a reliable first medical orientation directly on a smartphone?

The Solution: SkinGuard
Within 24 hours, a fully functional prototype was built. 
Users take a photo of the affected skin area. 
A task-specific dermatology model generated with ONE AI analyzes the image.

The system delivers:
- A predicted skin condition
- A clear recommendation (doctor needed or not)
- Over-the-counter treatment suggestions

A customized skin condition model was trained using ONE AI on labeled dermatological images.

What normally requires months of AI development, mobile integration and model optimization was implemented in ONE day.

SkinGuard demonstrates how ONE AI enables medical-grade Vision AI applications to be built rapidly: from dataset to deployable mobile app.

Healthcare is just one of many domains where ONE AI changes what is possible in 24 hours.

Results Series | Munich AI Hackathon

As a challenge sponsor, we gave the teams access to ourÂ ONE AI platform.

The challenge: Develop a working computer vision prototype in any application domain and demonstrate how ONE AI can be used to
- run AI creatively and locally on lean hardware,
- tailor models precisely to the specific application,
- and thereby outperform classical, generic AI approaches.

Our results seriesÂ starts with the winning team. They not only solved this challenge, but went on to win the entire hackathon.

The solution: Vision-based Process Mining.
Classic process mining stops where processes are carried out manually. This is exactly where the challenge began: Camera data from real workplaces had to be processed locally, semantically interpreted and automatically transformed into structured event logs. 

Within justÂ 24 hours, a fully functional prototype was created, demonstrating that ONE AI does not merely generate models, but enables an essential part of anÂ industrial AI pipeline at the edge. Video streams are processed in real time directly on edge devices. Objects and human activities are detected and classified using ONE AI models. Process steps (including timestamps) are dynamically extracted and automatically converted into structured event logs.
Training, inference, and event correlation all runÂ entirely locally. Process deviations such as missing steps, incorrect sequences or duplicates are detected automatically and the results can be directly integrated into existing process mining and analytics tools.

What was previously an â€œinvisibleâ€ manual process becomes aÂ digital twin of the real workflow.

Vision-based Process Mining is just one of nearlyÂ infinitely many possible use casesÂ that can be implemented with ONE AI in a very short time.

This inspired us so much that we decided to integrate this capability directly into ONE AI, making it possible to create a classification dataset from video dataÂ extremely quickly (last picture).

The winning solution at the Nuremberg Hackathon

â€œHow can AI help prevent safety violations in construction and manufacturing environments?â€

Over the course of three days, the winning team developed a Vision AI prototype focused specifically on this problem.

Using our ONE AI Vision Platform, they created a solution that:
- detects people in the scene
- identifies key body regions such as the head and upper body
- checks whether helmets and safety vests are present
- and visually marks situations where required safety equipment is missing

We are incredibly impressed by how quickly and effectively the team built this Vision AI solution with ONE AI. The prototype shows how AI can support organizations in recognizing potential safety risks earlier and increasing worker protection on-site. Even within a super fast development cycle.

And importantly:
This is just one of many possible Vision AI applications that can be built with ONE AI.

Litigation is messy. 

I'm often asked how Wexler is different to generalist legal AI.

We excel because we break down complex, interwoven narratives across hundreds of thousands of documents into structured, verified factual information to tell you what *actually* happened, not just which documents are relevant. 

The video below sums it up better than I can ğŸ‘‡

Don't sweat the competition!

Great to chat to Maria Ward-Brennan this morning about the hysteria over Anthropic moving into legal.

As a consumer of legal services, I (and pretty much every founder I know) welcome this to help us with the long tail of routine legal tasks you have to deal with.

For Wexler it's more validation of our litigation-focused approach.

Why are facts, not documents, the unit of analysis Wexler uses?

Because in disputes and investigations, it's useful to know which documents are relevant. But it's indispensable to know what actually happened.

The news is awash with the recent Epstein files release. The headlines don't say "Emails show correspondence between Epstein and Andrew". They say "Andrew visited the island on 12 April 1999."

If one document says Andrew flew to the island, another confirms the booking, and a third shows the flight manifest, you don't have three facts, you have one fact with three sources. Most AI tools miss this entirely. Wexler doesn't.

We've written a new blog examining why, when things get complex, facts are what you need.

I speak to hundreds of litigators per month. Many of them are at BigLaw firms with huge resources. They look to use technology to build their competitive advantage, find further efficiencies and win more cases.

But boutiques need efficiencies perhaps even more than these firms. 

When you are up against an AmLaw20 firm, and you are a firm of 20, using technology can help find things that would never otherwise see the light of day.

The upshot is, Wexler stores, manages and analyses evidence over the course of a decade+ long litigation, with users collaborating to attack different lines of inquiry.
