AI in litigation is extraordinarily powerful. But it needs to be used in the right way. 

From fabricated caselaw, to litigants in person showing up with their own ChatGPT created briefs, users, whether lay clients or senior attorneys, need to be educated about how to use these systems responsibly. Even using legal-specific AI tools requires training and understanding of how these systems work. 

We've seen that hallucinated cases are being drafted into precedent as example of AI-created caselaw, which then becomes caselaw itself! 

More than ever, it's critical to have systems that don't try to boil the ocean, but stick to retrieving information from a corpus of documents, not searching the internet or their training data. 

At Wexler we don't do legal research. Nor do we search the internet. We stick to the (incredibly time-consuming and difficult) task of extracting, analysing and organising facts for any dispute, in any jurisdiction. 

The economic value of this task is stratospheric. A single dispute can generate millions of documents. Associates spend weeks reviewing these documents. The smoking gun is rarely found. 

By grounding our system in the factual record, and painstakingly extracting each fact through a process of daisy-chained models, we have reduced the risk of fabrication. We ensure each user can verify every conclusion instantly. 

That's something we're proud of.

https://lnkd.in/e6YB2D8G

Wexler's new platform is now live. 

We have spent the past few months developing the ability to manage your case strategy end-to-end. You can store all your files in Wexler, carve them up into subsets based on person, entity, issue, time period and more. 

This means Wexler is now a one-stop-shop for every strategic, factual task in disputes. 

If you'd like to see it in action, get in touch.

Something I get asked often is where Wexler fits into the litigation lifecycle alongside eDiscovery.

The answer lies in the depth of analysis and Wexler's ability to analyse documents at a fact, rather than document level. 

That's what we have spent the last two years perfecting. In disputes, knowing which documents are most relevant is helpful. But knowing the who-what-when of what happened is what litigators crave.

We hosted the 'Wexler Seasonal Supper' last week. 

No Christmas jumpers, but a good ding-dong between barristers, partners and innovation lawyers about the future of AI in disputes.

A few moments that stuck with me: 

We discussed whether disputes could be prevented before they spiral: a "fence at the top of the cliff" rather than the ambulance at the bottom. 

If so, what role does the contract play? Perhaps AI-supported processes can map out early issue spotting and resolution.

The economics of legal work came up often. Routine tasks like drafting simple NDAs are becoming harder to charge for, while high-stakes matters depend heavily on factual precision and sound judgment.

One innovation lead noted she gets ten tech pitches a week but "none focus on the facts". This is precisely the gap Wexler fills. Most legal tools are broad assistants or help organise documents for disclosure. It was encouraging that we remained the expert's choice for complex disputes. 

The evening reinforced a key point: AI works best as a collaborator to find relevant information and shape it into work product. 

The human in the loop remains vital, but the right system can actually make that human *more* of an expert than they might have been otherwise.

The changes to the EMI scheme constitute a really positive step for startups building in the UK. Gross assets being increased to Â£120m means that startups can continue to grow, while incentivising new joiners with tax benefits on a potentially life-changing outcome, no matter how big the company gets. 

We have a unique opportunity to attract, retain and develop the world's best talent. 

Wexler is hiring for a number of roles across our tech and commercial teams. Link in the comments.

At Wexler we no longer offer pilots on dummy data.

While we have had success with dummy data pilots, the era of 'play-around with a genAI platform' is over. 

The first few years of genAI in legal were about experimentation. The next are about ROI. 

There is undoubtedly more friction in launching pilots on real data. But the pay-off is so much greater. The engagement from the users is up, the ROI can be benchmarked against how long it has taken to do things manually, and the feedback on the quality of the output is grounded in detailed knowledge of the subject matter. And it is the quality of the output where we shine. 

We're not precious and we can set up sandboxes on sample data (although everyone is sick of ENRON), but we have invested significantly in our security posture precisely so that Wexler can be used on live matters.

Recently there has been a lot of negative news on TV and social media about how tourists and foreigners are â€œruiningâ€ Japan.

As someone who works directly with international clients through Akiya, I want to share a story that reminded me of the good that still exists in our communities.

A retired couple from Australia purchased an Akiya in Wakayama. Their Japanese is limited, but their hearts are wide open. The wife once lived in Tokyo as an English teacher in the 1990s and had kept her Disneyland ticket from 1994 (see first photo below). Their dream was simple: a small countryside home where they could enjoy their retirement in Japan.

They viewed and purchased the home remotely through Akiya Air and finally arrived in Japan this fall to see it in person.

On the day I brought them to their new home, something felt off. The lot next door was now completely empty, even though a house had clearly stood there just a few months earlier.

As we tried to understand what had happened, the neighbor across the street came out and told us the truth. The house had burned down, and tragically a woman inside had lost her life.

It was heartbreaking news for anyone, let alone for someone visiting their newly purchased home for the first time. Then an elderly man arrived on an old bicycle and began surveying the land. He was the owner and the husband of the woman who had passed away. He had come to pay his respects.

We expressed our deepest condolences, and my client gave him a long, warm hug.

What happened next touched me deeply.

Despite their limited renovation budget, my clients asked if we could seek the ownerâ€™s permission to lay gravel and begin turning the empty lot into a small community garden in memory of his wife (see photos below).

He became emotional...and immediately agreed.

With the support of a local construction company, we have begun laying gravel. Our hope is to gradually transform this little space into something meaningful. A place where children can play, elderly neighbors can gather and chat, and where a husband can quietly remember his beloved wife.

This story will never be in the national news. It will not go viral. But I hope it serves as a reminder that beyond the headlines, kindness and community still thrive in unexpected places.

Regardless of our differences, foreign or local, Australian or Japanese, longtime resident or newcomer, we are all part of the same human family.

And our vision is for the world to live as one.

#EmptyBowls

I experiment with AI a lot. And not just for work.

I wanted to share this, I think it might be useful for someone else too.

Six years ago, I was seriously ill. The prognosis was unclear, my condition unstable, and I had to dive deep into medicine on my own.

I learned to read bloodwork, studied dozens of research papers. And I hit a wall: there's just too much data. The human body is a complex system affected by dozens of factors. No single doctor can cross-reference all of it in their head.
That's when I first thought: when AI matures enough, this could work very differently.

Over the years of illness, I accumulated a massive dataset about myself. And now I've finally brought it all together into one system:
â†’ Blood tests & medical records spanning several years 
â†’ DNA test results 
â†’ 6 years of Apple Health data export 
â†’ Training logs, journals, photos, notes

I structured everything with Claude and turned it into a personal knowledge base. Then I started experimenting.

I generated a report, the kind a nutritionist would normally prepare. And it surfaced things no one had noticed before, because for the first time, genetics data and bloodwork were cross-referenced.

For example: I've always had chronically low levels of certain micronutrients. Supplements didn't help. Turns out I have a genetic predisposition and my body doesn't absorb standard forms of these substances well. I need different formulations entirely. No doctor had connected these dots.

I also calculated various metrics: biological age based on cardiovascular, metabolic, musculoskeletal and other body systems, a personal health index, and condition-specific indicators that are important to track given my particular health profile. The graphs turned out beautiful.

My plan now: validate everything with my doctor, set up minimal regular data collection, and build an AI agent that automatically pulls new data, searches for relevant research, finds correlations and sends me daily, weekly, and monthly reports.

The most exciting part? I built all of this in two evenings 

Right now, I feel like Iâ€™m holding two perspectives at once. One is pessimistic, that we might end up living like in The Terminator ğŸ˜  The other is that the quality of services and products is about to increase exponentially. The level of personalization and overall quality will grow dramatically in the near future.

In 2025, I kept notes on how I use artificial intelligence.

Looking back, the evolution is very clear.
At first, it was about getting answers.
Then, thinking things through together.
Next, building simple prototypes: design, websites, videos.
After that, researching narrow topics.
Now, a personal knowledge base with templates and routine automation.

My next step in 2026 is to build a personal intellectual infrastructure, and to create the same kind of system for my business.

Not a helper, but an environment that remembers context, learns from mistakes, and amplifies my strengths. On the one hand, I no longer need to write 30 emails every morning. I only review them. On the other, I have more time for deep research and for the real world, where information turns into practical knowledge.

At the moment, there is no convenient infrastructure to build a truly personal operating system like this. But it feels like this is exactly what many products will start moving toward by the end of 2026.

For the past year, one question hasnâ€™t let me go: How do I need to change, and how does my business need to change, given whatâ€™s happening around us?

If I simplify things, I see two strategies in the age of AI.

1. Go extremely deep in one domain.
 Create work with an almost irrational level of attention to detail. AI gives us back time, and that time can be invested in taste, intuition, judgment, and craft.
But this only works if you already have experience, perspective, and a very high internal quality bar.

2. Go massive.
Weâ€™re moving fast toward a world where intellectual and creative work becomes standardized, more like factories: speed, volume, repeatability.

Everything else sits in between and feels increasingly unstable.

So the real questions for 2026 are simple, but uncomfortable:
â€¢ What am I a virtuoso at?
â€¢ What do I want to be world-class at?
â€¢ Where is my true specialization?

The era of pure executors is ending. If your work can be fully described as an instruction, youâ€™re already competing with AI. Looks like weâ€™re all becoming entrepreneurs, whether we planned to or not.

How does this year feel to you: a challenge, pressure, or an opportunity?

Hospitals in the Age of AI: Turning Clinical Data into Strategic Assets

Last week, I had the opportunity to share a keynote on a topic that keeps coming up in conversations with hospital and lab leaders:
Healthcare generates enormous amounts of data â€” but we still use only a fraction of its real potential.

While patients and clinicians are used to seamless digital experiences in other industries, healthcare data is often still fragmented across PDFs, legacy systems, and disconnected workflows. LIS, HIS, PACS, EHRs â€” all valuable, yet rarely speaking the same language.

Hospitals sit at the center of the healthcare ecosystem. They connect patients, physicians, labs, payers, public institutions, research, and innovation. That central role creates a unique opportunity â€” but only if data becomes accessible, interoperable, and clinically meaningful.

This is where we see a real inflection point.
With recent progress in AI and analytics, the challenge is no longer just data creation â€” itâ€™s data harmonization, context, and usage. In our view at OpenHealth Technologies , the missing piece is a semantic layer for medical data: one that works on top of existing systems, respects clinical reality, and turns fragmented information into usable insights.

When done right, the impact is tangible:
â€¢ More efficient workflows and better decision support for clinicians
â€¢ Clear, continuous digital experiences for patients
â€¢ Interoperability and analytics that help hospitals and labs reduce costs and unlock new value

Transformation doesnâ€™t start with big-bang projects. It starts with focused pilots, quick wins, and partnerships built on trust and domain expertise.

Grateful for the great discussions during and after the keynote â€” and excited to see more hospitals and labs treating data not as a byproduct, but as a strategic asset.

Yesterday, we probably hosted one of the largest law webinars ever in DACH.

395 registrations, with legal leaders from Fortune 500 companies, governments, and most major law firms in the region.

Why did all of these people attend?

Because if youâ€™re a lawyer on LinkedIn, much of what you see is that there is another AI model that is the best one yet and that it will replace legal work: Claude legal plugins, OpenClaw, I meanâ€¦

Has anyone actually ever seen how you're supposed to use one of these new tools to complete a legal task? We decided to show exactly that.

Most participants started using Omnilex yesterday afternoon to experience what a model like Claude Opus 4.6 can actually do when combined with citations, direct access to legal sources, and no technical setup.

Find the full webinar in the comments.

My favorite hiring story so far:

At a legal tech conference in Germany, I was presenting Omnilex and our AI Commentary to a room full of lawyers.

After 15 minutes, I opened the Q&A. The usual questions came up, reliability, data protection, product roadmap. Then one woman raised her hand.

She first just asked a question. Then she challenged the premise.

Why arenâ€™t you putting more focus on commentary, if this is one of the biggest pain points for lawyers?

Why is the structure not designed like X or Y?

What would it take for AI commentary to be truly usable in practice?

She kept going and turned the Q&A into a group discussion. Then shared her own vision of how AI commentary *should* look like.

After I went five minutes over time, I wrapped up the presentation and we had a 1on1 chat.

Itâ€™s rare to meet someone outside your team who is as passionate about your product and its impact as you are. 

Fast forward a few interviews and a visit to our Zurich office, Eluisa H. is now part of the Omnilex team, building the partnerships for the next generation of legal commentary. Commentary that is not gatekept by publishers and not locked behind outdated, overpriced models.

This is exactly who we want to build Omnilex with. Happy to grow the team with Eluisa who deeply understands commentary, cares about how lawyers actually work, and sees what AI could unlock here.

Switzerland led the way, Germany followed, and we never planned to leave Liechtenstein out.

We collaborated with some of the principalityâ€™s best and most forward-thinking lawyers. Now, Omnilex is available in Liechtenstein, including all public court decisions and laws.

The Omnilex team is already shaping the next major steps, and youâ€™ll hear about them soon.

Yesterday at the German Legal Tech Summit in Hannover, we discussed how we make AI legal research reliable with AI commentary.

It was great exchanging with the firms that are ahead in AI and talking about new ideas. And always exciting to see how strongly Omnilex is taking off in Germany.

Thanks for having me at the podcast, Sebastian Bluhm and KSB INTAX !

We are excited to welcome two new startups into our community ğŸŒŸ 

nunu.ai is building AI agents to test and play games. Their vision is to develop generally capable agents that can navigate and act in any given environment, starting with applications in gaming and moving towards general 3D simulations and robotics. The startup was co-founded by Kyrill Hux, Nicolas Muntwyler, and Jan Schnyder with support through a co-advised master thesis with core faculty member Prof. Elliott Ash.

OmnilexÂ is a legal AI workspace powered by the worldâ€™s first AI-generated legal commentary. It combines laws, court decisions, and commentary into one reasoning environment, enabling legal professionals to work faster and deeper on complex legal questions. The start-up was co-founded by Etienne Salimbeni and Ari Jordan, who worked and published with the Center for Law & Economics Lab and Prof. Elliott Ash. There, they focused on evaluating the legal reasoning capabilities of AI.

Testing random things, Part 4: I think I accidentally mapped the ERCOT grid. 

So, after Part 3, I was deep in the ERCOT data mines. The data is huge, but it is also a mess. The constraint names are just cryptic strings like "HARGRO_TWINBU1_1". No coordinates, no topology, just text.

My initial goal was simple: I just wanted to link these constraint names to the physical lines on the map so I could feed the geometry into Gridraven Claw and start monitoring them. But you know how it goesâ€”I wanted to see how far I could push the model, so I kept adding layer after layer of complexity.
One thing led to another, and I accidentally created a preliminary grid model for the entire ERCOT interconnection.

The problem is that OpenStreetMap data for power grids is oftenâ€¦ letâ€™s say â€œcreativeâ€. Lines are broken, voltages are missing, and connections don't always touch. You cannot just use a standard routing engine.

So I built a custom system to solve it.
1) The Logic: I wrote a graph based "Crystal Growth" algorithm. It starts with one substation we know for sure, and then it looks at the neighbors in the grid topology. Like solving a massive Sudoku puzzle, it propagates outwards, locking in substations one by one.
2) The Physics: I wrote a custom "Gap Jumping" router. If the line data in OSM is broken (which happens a lot!), my script calculates the physics (voltage, distance, direction) and "jumps" the gap to stitch the line segments together.

Midway through debugging the algorithm (see the GIF of congested lines), I stopped and looked at the graph.

I realized I hadn't just found the locations of the constraints: 
1) I had the substations.
2) I had the transmission lines connecting them.
3) I had the voltage levels.

At this point, it is just a matter of pulling the power plant locations from the EIA official registry and plugging them into the graph nodes. Suddenly, you aren't just looking at a map; you have the foundation for a power flow model.

It is definitely over-engineered for a weekend project. But you know how it is. You start by looking for a few congested lines, and you end up with an intial digital twin of the Texas grid on your laptop.

Next step? Maybe I finally put this all into a dashboard. Or verify the conductor ratings with some weather data. Letâ€™s see.

Our wind forecast is right 99% of the time, also in sheltered locations. We have the most accurate wind prediction in the world.

Our Dynamic Line Ratings customer, Fingrid Oyj, talks about how they validated Gridraven wind forecasts in this webinar in EPRI's GET SET series.

This is the breakthrough that makes sensorless Dynamic Line Ratings possible anywhere on the globe. Our vision is to boost grid capacity by 30% globally by 2030.

Even a light wind can double the capacity of an overhead line, but the transmission owner needs to be very sure that the wind is really there before allowing more power through the line.

When we say that the wind is at least 1 m/s at 3pm two days from now, then it will really be at least 1 m/s. The wind will not be lower than that with 99% certainty.

Accounting for wind cooling adds grid capacity up to half of the time. This capacity is available on day-ahead energy markets, reducing congestion and allowing power generators to produce more power.

Testing random things, Part 3: Texas (virtual) road trip and ERCOT

After doing the PJM analysis, I was asked if itâ€™s possible to do a similar thing in ERCOT since they also share a huge amount of data and use AAR.

So, I downloaded the 2025 real-time and day-ahead data and started digging. The scale is different here. I found roughly 1,200 unique transmission lines that were causing binding constraints in the grid.

Getting the raw data is the easy part. Making it usable is the real work. I had to map the constraint names to actual start and end substations and then query OpenStreetMap to extract the physical line geometries.

But geometry isn't enough. You need the physics. Since I don't have the operator's private asset database, I did the next best thing: I made my best (engineering) guess and traveled across Texas in Google Street View.

I think I did this year's vacation to Texas already by literally spending hours virtually driving down highways and dust roads to verify bundle configurations for the key corridors. I likely virtually drove past our CEO Georg Rute's home in Austin a dozen times, but I was too busy looking up at the transmission towers to stop and say hello.
It might sound a bit obsessive, but that is the only way to get the the main conductor assumptions right without insider info.

Long story short, I managed to clean the data and narrowed it down to the top 300 most critical lines by congestion cost to import into Gridraven Claw. Just like with the PJM experiment, I am now collecting the data to start running the conductor-finder brute-force tool to reverse-engineer the likely conductor types and operating temperatures that match the historical flow.

The good part? We are now effectively monitoring over $1 billion in annual congestion value continuously, with hourly updates and 60-hour forecasts. I have added a map to show all the lines we monitor in ERCOT and a sample 345kV line run by CPS Energy with forecasts.

It is nice to see what can be done with open data. Not sure if that is useful at all commercially yet, but at least it is great to see how the thermal models work and how well they correlate with actual market data

I am not sure yet if Part 4 will be about tackling another ISO or finally showing the validation results from the conductor finder, but letâ€™s see. A lot of good ideas pending.

Features in Reuters, Associated Press, Axios, Washington Post, New York Post, and 100+ other media outlets, plus a TV segment filming with CBS Austin, a strong start to the year for Gridraven.
Gridraven was founded by scientists and engineers, deep in the details of the power grid and focused on solving real energy problems. That perspective is why our CEO, Georg Rute, belongs in these global conversations.

Kudos to our brilliant PR partners Bridgette Borst Ombres and Jamie Meckley.

Testing random things, Part 2: The $2.2 Billion Blind Spot (and the "Short Line" Paradox)

After my first experiment (Harwoodâ€“Susquehanna 230kV DLR prediction) Iâ€™ve been digging deep into the 2025 PJM market data, and the numbers are staggering. Total congestion in PJM increased by over $840 million in the first nine months of 2025 aloneâ€”reaching a total of $2.23 billion.

I decided to map this chaos. I analyzed every 5-minute interval, mapped the congestion costs to specific substations, and identified the Top 100 most congested lines in PJM.

The Discovery
While doing the mapping, I noticed something that surprised me: a huge percentage of the highest-cost constraints aren't the massive 345/500kV backbones, but relatively short segments. For the engineers in the room: we know DLR isn't a silver bullet for every constraint. On long-haul lines, you usually hit Surge Impedance Loading (SIL) or stability limits long before you sag the conductor to its limit. But on these short, thermally-limited segments, the ampacity is the only thing standing between a clear path and a $1,000/MWh price spike. This is where AAR and DLR have the highest "delta" and the biggest market impact.

The Challenge: Beating the Market 
With FERC Order 881 now in effect, PJM has fully implemented Ambient Adjusted Ratings (AAR) into its congestion management. This means line limits now fluctuate hourly based on temperature.

My goal for Part 2: Can I use Gridraven Claw to predict these ratings for the Top 100 lines before PJM publishes them?

The Workflow
1. The Dataset: Focus on the 100 lines driving the highest congestion rent running in Claw.
2. The "Inference" Engine: Since exact conductor specs are rarely public, Iâ€™m using the brute-force tool from Part 1.1 to find the best-fit thermal parameters
3. Shadow Ratings: Running thermal models using only public geometry (OSM) and hyperlocal weather to generate a rating forecast up to 60 hours in advance.
Â 
Systematic Validation
By forecasting DLR/AAR for the Top 100 congested segments 24â€“36 hours ahead of the DA market clearing, we shift from reactive monitoring to predictive modeling of thermal constraints.

I am currently in the data-collection phase to establish high-confidence baselines for these specific line geometries. Once I have a statistically significant sample size, I will be conducting a formal back-test, benchmarking these "Blind Predictions" against the published PJM Day-Ahead ground truth.

Stay tuned for Part 3.

Renewables have made power cheap in the middle of the Continent. Transmission constraints are keeping it from reaching you.

In central parts of the country, solar and wind are above 25% of the fuel mix. Day-ahead power prices have normalized there, despite continual cold temperatures. 

But that affordable power is not traveling very far due to transmission constraints. For example, Kansas City and Minneapolis are surrounded by affordable power, but that affordable power is not getting in. 

Transmission constraints are especially visible in the nodes that have negative prices right next to Kansas City. Generators are probably trapped there and not turned on, even though that power would be needed in the City. 

Further, prices remain very high in PJM and NE-ISO that have only 8% and 6% solar and wind respectively in their fuel mix right now.

More transmission capacity is needed both locally to the cities, as well as across the continent to the entire North East, which is a densely populated area and where it's more difficult to site renewables.

The quickest way to add transmission capacity is by deploying DLR software on all lines. Gridraven is the world's largest DLR provider, and our solution is ready to be turned on. It would directly reduce congestion across the country and increase affordability of power.

A reliable power supply doesn't just mean that the lights will turn on when you flick the switch. It also means that it won't bankrupt you when you do. These high day-ahead prices will eventually find their way into your bill.

Day-Ahead prices consistently exceeded Real-Time prices throughout the peak period of stress (from yesterday evening into this morning) in ERCOT during Winter Storm Fern.

But why, and what did it mean for batteries across the system?

ERCOT forecasted peak demand as high as 86 GW as late as 8 hours before Monday morning's peak. Actual load came in at just 75 GW.

Meanwhile, thermal outages stayed around 9 GW for the bulk of the storm, with the only major event being the forced outage of ~1 GW of generation at 8 PM on Sunday evening, which coincided with an emergency notice being issues for the loss of some transmission and generation in the Houston and San Antonio areas. 

ERCOT expected ~7.5 GW of thermal generation outages in the highest-concern hour according to its January 2026 Monthly Outlook for Resource Adequacy (MORA) report.

Renewable production was also roughly in line with ERCOT's expectations for a Winter 2026 Hour Ending 8 event. 

In its most recent Capacity, Demand, and Reserves Report, ERCOT projected intermittent renewable production just before 8 AM would be ~GW in an event like today's. 

As a result of the load forecast and generators across the system holding up under tough conditions, Day-Ahead Energy and AS markets priced in scarcity that didn't fully materialize in Real-Time. DAM energy hit $1,800/MWh for Monday morning, while RTM peaked around $1,000/MWh on Sunday evening.

Batteries remained nearly idle on Jan 24-25, maintaining a high state of charge, despite elevated prices on the 25th. 

Discharge peaked at just 1.7 GW on the 25th.

Then Monday morning: discharge peaked at around 7 GW, as operators who'd cleared in the Day-Ahead market executed their strategy.

Most batteries likely stacked Day-Ahead Ancillary Service awards throughout the weekend (which cleared above $100/MW, hitting $1,000/MW for RRS, ECRS, and Reg Up on Monday), allowing them to collect revenue with limited cycling requirements.

The most successful operators likely went even further.

On Sunday evening, with RT AS prices below $10/MW, they could have forgone those DA obligations, capturing the DA/RT spread, and discharging into the $750-1,000/MWh RT Energy peak instead. They then could recharge overnight at $250-450/MWh to meet Monday's DA commitments.

This kind of strategy requires precise DA market positioning, confidence in overnight price behavior, and willingness to charge at prices that would normally be prohibitive. 

Winter Storm Fern showcased how forecast uncertainty and a willingness to leverage a battery's flexibility create strategic opportunities. 

When Day-Ahead markets price in more scarcity than Real-Time delivers, the operators who can position accordingly (and maintain discipline through volatile periods) can optimize both system support and economics.

Congestion in this one transmission line costs up to $1 million per hour. The irony is the congestion only exists on paper and does not reflect physical reality.

The winter storm has thankfully passed with the grid largely intact, but wild power prices are hitting consumers regardless.

In the image shown, day-ahead prices for Sunday evening in San Antonio are $1,600 per MWh. Just on the other side of the Spruce-Pawnee 345 kV line, prices are negative -$326 per MWh.

The price difference reflects generating capacity in the South that's just not allowed onto the grid. Generators are losing money while people are paying much more than they should.

Physically, the Spruce-Pawnee 345 kV overhead line would have at least 170 MW extra capacity at this time (dynamic ratings at 98% confidence, vs ambient ratings), which would almost certainly be enough to reduce prices in San Antonio. Compared with seasonal ratings, the extra capacity could be up to 500 MW. The value of this congestion relief would be up to $1 million per hour.

Throughout the weekend generation has been and continues to be trapped in the South, because of grid congestion that only exists on paper. This is not just a Texas problem, grid congestion is a problem nationally and globally, unnecessarily raising prices.

Even a light wind doubles the capacity of a transmission line by cooling it down. But that's not accounted for by transmission owners nor ERCOT. As a result, lines are limited more than they should be and the "congestion" does not reflect the physical reality of the grid.

Up until recently, wind forecasts were not reliable enough to account for the cooling effect, so grid operators had to assume almost no wind all the time. But that's no longer the case.

Gridraven has fixed wind forecasting and is the world's largest provider of software-only dynamic line ratings. With no hardware, this additional transmission capacity could be made use of. Grid operators in Europe have gone all in with this already. What's stopping us in Texas?

Aaron Zubaty, Richard Medina, Eric Meier, Brian Friedrichs, Ed Hirs, WATT Coalition, Julia Selker, Tim McLaughlin, Joshua D. Rhodes, PhD, Jack Farley, Doug Lewin, Patricia Zavala

As I was quoted in Reuters: "I think there's very little chance of a 2021 rerun, but no blackout happens the same way twice."

This winter storm has roughly half the intensity of Uri, and ERCOT's grid is much better prepared: gas wells have been winterized and there's about 100x more battery storage. Still, there's less margin for error during peak demand and icing risk, and disasters always happen in a new manner.

Catch up with developments by reading Tim McLaughlin's piece! 

https://lnkd.in/dd7TakjF

The winter storm is already causing high power prices. 

Austin will see -8Â°C (17Â°F) over the weekend, which is exceptional here. Minneapolis will see -26Â°C (-15Â°F). As a result of high demand, more expensive power plants are being dispatched that normally sit in reserve and the price goes up.

The image shows the day-ahead power price for Friday evening at 8pm CT. A large part of the country will see prices above $200 per MWh. For comparison, the below image shows prices for last week Friday at the same time when prices were only $30 or so. (Price maps from GridStatus, temperature map from Windy)

ERCOT, the Texas system operator, has stated that there is sufficient generation capacity available this time. Available capacity on Monday morning is projected at 94 GW while demand is forecasted at 81 GW. This is comfortable, as long as there are no unforeseen problems in the grid.

However, no blackout happens twice. It's always something new. For example, ice storms can lead to a buildup of ice on the optical grounding wire, which in a worst case scenario can sag and come in contact with a conductor. If that happens in a critical transmission line then it could lead to a cascading failure. Unlikely, and hasn't happened in Texas yet. Or?

Besides, the risk of local power cuts on the distribution side remains high. So I'm still stocking up on drinking water.

In most control rooms, weatherâ€™s effect on grid capacity - the actual transmission lines themselves -Â  is still largely ignored, leaving significant amounts of usable power stranded. This oversight is increasing reliability risks and costs for consumers.

If we start accounting for the weather's effect on the actual lines in transmission system operation:

1. Congestion becomes manageable

Weather-aware operations reveal unused capacity on constrained lines. Power can be routed when and where conditions allow, which causes congestion costs to fall. Ultimately, power becomes more affordable for consumers.

2. Prices reflect reality

Price spikes often reflect assumed scarcity, not actual system limits. Dynamic ratings unlock more accurate market price signals and create fewer extreme spreads between regions.

3. Reliability improves without new steel

During stress events, flexibility matters. Knowing what the grid can safely carry at that moment reduces the risk of shortages or cascading failures.

It also allows neighboring regions to help supply capacity when extreme conditions cause strain. This is especially critical as load growth accelerates and extreme weather becomes more frequent.

None of this requires new hardware or long transmission buildouts. A software-based approach can be deployed quickly, and scale across networks in a matter of months, not years.

tldr: My initial post might have bit understated how easy it was to guess/get line parameters. I started with educated guess, but then made a solution to brute-force it.

Testing random things, Part 1.1: How did you choose the conductor on Harwoodâ€“Susquehanna 230 kV line?

After my last post a few people asked the question that every engineer working with line ratings asks first:
â€œOkâ€¦ but how did you know what conductor to use?â€

Fair question. If you get the conductor wrong, you can be very correct about the physics and still be offset by a couple hundred MVA. When modelling a line from public geometry (OSM) + weather, the conductor (and its operating temperature!) is the biggest missing piece. Operator documents exist, but theyâ€™re rarely public. So you either:
Â·Â Â Â Â Â assume, and live with the bias, or
Â·Â Â Â Â Â treat conductor selection as an inference problem.
I did the second.

Step 0 â€” make an explicit â€œinitial guessâ€ (and write it down).
Before fitting anything I pinned a baseline based on â€œwhatâ€™s common at 230 kV in USâ€ and what I could verify visually:
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Conductor: Lapwing/ACSS (1590 class)
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Max operating temp: 90Â°C (used a value commonly used with Lapwing)
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Bundle: 1 subconductor / phase (Street View / photos)
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Surface: Îµ = 0.9, Î± = 0.9 (yes, this is the part everyone argues about)
Then I ran the same thermal model + hyperlocal forecasts and compared the resulting time series against PJM Day-Ahead normal rating.

Step 1 â€” brute-force the conductor parameters.
Instead of guessing forever, I brute-forced a grid of plausible parameter sets:
Â·Â Â Â Â Â possible conductor family candidates
Â·Â Â Â Â Â max allowed temperature (set limits)
Â·Â Â Â Â Â emissivity / solar absorptivity
For each candidate I recomputed the ampacity time series on the same limiting spans and scored it against the PJM series (error + correlation). The top scorer is my best-fit parameter set for this line under these assumptions.
No magic, no ML hype, it's just a dumb grid search and a score function.

Step 2 â€” the plot I shouldâ€™ve shown in the Part 1 post.
I added an extra plot:
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Black: PJM Day-Ahead (treated as ground truth here)
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Orange: P50 with my initial guess
Â·Â Â Â Â Â Green: P50 with the best-fit parameters

This makes the point obvious: the weather/physics capture a lot of the shape, but the conductor parameters decide whether youâ€™re â€œclose enough to be usefulâ€ or â€œnice academic curveâ€.

And why that is important?
Line ratings arenâ€™t just engineering trivia. They change:
Â·Â Â Â Â Â congestion patterns,
Â·Â Â Â Â Â binding constraints,
Â·Â Â Â Â Â and the effective capacity of paths you assume are â€œstaticâ€ or only temperature related

Gridraven can accurately forecast other providers' DLR values based on public data. 

Line ratings affect congestion patterns and determine day-ahead locational marginal prices. Predicting LMPs helps optimize battery operations for example.

PJM publishes ratings and the Harwoodâ€“Susquehanna 230kV line (owned by PPL Electric Utilities) has DLR on day-ahead operations. Our forecasts match up quite nicely, with only public information as input.

How is it possible for a team of 16 to have built a software solution that can increase transmission capacity across the entire globe by up to a third? 

Read our software architect's, Joosep's, blog post for a glimpse into how we do our work.

The short answer is: give excellent people full freedom and accountability.

Fingrid Oyj, the transmission system operator in Finland, is rolling out Gridraven's fully sensorless Dynamic Line Ratings across its 400 kV network of roughly 5500 km. 

In this webinar, representatives from Fingrid will introduce their choice and motivation for sensorless DLR and describe how they validated the results. 

Gridraven's probabilistic sensorless DLR solution is based on a hyper-local weather and wind prediction that accounts for meter-scale landscape features.

The webinar will feature a general presentation followed by a private discussion for GET SET members. Note that participation is limited to members of GET SET by EPRI or to affinity group members - see you there if you're a member, or reach out to EPRI to join.

Did you know that our transmission lines have more capacity available? They are actually dynamically rated, meaning the amount of safe capacity varies. 

What controls the transmission capacity, and how can we utilize more of said capacity? 

That's what I talk about with Georg Rute of Gridraven. They are increasing the capacity utilization of existing grids, through their software solution.

Wednesday = ramen, layouts, and design systems

Built a 4-node automation that creates a continuous user feedback loop

Here's how it works:
User signs up â†’ Supabase triggers a webhook â†’ n8n waits 48 hours â†’ checks status in Stripe to see if they're free/paid â†’ sends the right email

So every new user gets an email from me 48 hours after they sign up. All replies go straight to my inbox. There's also a Calendly link to book a call or they can leave a voice note using Typeform

All this took about an hour. Will probably add more segment logic based on usage soon

Definitely not scalable or pretty but it's helping me extract insights on autopilot

intent â†’ interface â†’ implementation shouldnâ€™t be three separate worlds. It should feel like one shared language.

Hoy he tenido el placer de pasar por CIBERCOTIZANTE en Capital Radio (Business) junto a JosÃ© JoaquÃ­n Flechoso Sierra y Santiago Moral Rubio, PhD para hablar de Laguun.io y de cÃ³mo la IA estÃ¡ transformando la ciberseguridad. Y ademÃ¡s ha coincidido con un dÃ­a que no quiero dejar pasar: el DÃ­a Internacional de la Mujer y la NiÃ±a en la Ciencia. Un buen dÃ­a para recordar que en este sector todavÃ­a nos faltan muchas.

#MujerYCiencia #11F #Ciberseguridad #InteligenciaArtificial #Laguun

Quoting Paco Moral Rubio, CMO at Dedge Security:

â€œThe lab phase is over.â€

- JPMorganâ€™s Kinexys processes large-scale institutional flows.
- Siemens uses blockchain for treasury operations.
- BlackRock tokenizes money market funds.

When client money depends on it and regulators are watching, this is no longer experimental infrastructure.

Itâ€™s production.
And production requires production standards.

This is where most institutions hit the same wall.

Point-in-time security does not scale in Web3.

Infrastructure changes constantly. Code deployments, permission changes, evolving dependencies. Weekly, sometimes daily. Yet most security models still rely on periodic audits, one to three reviews per year, with coverage that drops the moment the audit is done.

The outcome is predictable:

â€¢ Industry analyses consistently show that a majority of Web3 incidents occur after audits, between review cycles.
â€¢ The same issues tend to resurface across subsequent reviews.

As a result, a meaningful share of senior engineering time is absorbed by reactive remediation instead of preventive control.

In Europe, Web3 is only viable for banks when technical control is continuous and defensible.

There are no â€œWeb3 operational standardsâ€ versus â€œtraditional standardsâ€.
There are only operational standards.

Risk committees do not care whether a system is blockchain or legacy. They care whether it is controlled.

The difference is not avoiding incidents entirely.
It is containing impact and being able to demonstrate control when it matters.

Without continuous security, Web3 is ungovernable.
And ungovernable infrastructure is simply not operable for banks.

The institutions scaling fastest are not treating Web3 as a parallel universe.
They are treating it as infrastructure that happens to use distributed ledgers, and governing it accordingly.

Bug bounties are still mentally filed under â€œsecurity done right.â€

And they do matter.

They surface edge cases and unexpected behavior that internal testing can miss. As a signal, they are useful.

But they answer a different question than governance.

They donâ€™t explain how a risk reached production. They donâ€™t explain why it was approved. They donâ€™t explain who was accountable for the decision.
In regulated environments, â€œa researcher found itâ€ is not an acceptable explanation.

Governance is about internal, verifiable control across the full development and deployment lifecycle. 

Ownership. Traceability. Evidence.

Bug bounties provide signals. Governance provides answers.

What's a signal without a system?

Everyone has the same question.
â€œWhat is the best ecommerce platform?â€

Dan Coleman from Coleman Marketing Limited says the real question is completely different.

Shopify is incredibleâ€¦ if you do not try to bend it beyond how it expects you to operate.
Magento is a powerhouseâ€¦ if you actually need and can handle that power.
WooCommerce, BigCommerce, the restâ€¦ they all come with trade-offs.

There is no universal answer.
There is only cultural fit.
Your platform should match your ambition, your catalogue complexity, your teamâ€™s capability and your operational reality. Not just your wishlist.

The headache comes when retailers choose tech based on what they hope to be instead of what they are set up to do right now.

Platform choice does not define success.
Alignment does.

Retail is Detail Podcast

Most retailers chase traffic and ROAS like trophies.
But as Dan Coleman from Coleman Marketing Limited puts it, profit is the only KPI that truly matters.

Because it is not the blended margin that keeps your business alive.
It is the reality at SKU level.
What does that specific sofa earn after returns, replacements, fulfilment, payment fees and acquisition costs.
What can your marketing spend actually sustain.
And are you measuring the contribution back into the business or the fantasy numbers that make a dashboard look good.

This is where retailers either scale.
Or suffocate.

Dan and I got into this on the latest episode of Retail is Detail Podcast.
If you want a clear-eyed view of what growth really requires, do not miss this one.

Retailers love to talk about product market fit. Dan Coleman from Coleman Marketing Limited believes there is an even bigger question:

Do you have the right to ask for the sale in the first place?

If your product is a basket-add on Amazon, why would a customer visit your dedicated website?
If convenience is your competitorâ€™s edge, why pretend it is yours too?
If your proposition is not attractive enough, no amount of traffic solves the problem.

Dan has audited hundreds of sites. He can tell within minutes whether a retailer understands real shopping behavior or is living in fantasy ecommerce land.

It is not innovation to break what the customer expects.
It is not a strategy to ignore where the market is already eating your lunch.


The full episode airs today.

Saturday morning in Mannheim. Coffee, sunshine, silence. 
The kind of morning where you actually have space to think. Time for preparing the #boardmeeting next week. 

We've had an incredible start to the year at Resourcly - new talent joining the team, new customers trusting us with their journey. The energy is there. The momentum is real.

But here's what I've learned: the real value of prep isn't in the deck. It's about those quiet hours of real reflection. 

Thinking through the strategic questions that actually matter. Identifying the topics worth a deep dive. Making sure we get the most out of the conversation.

Between the years, Ian Draxten and I already took time to reflect, prep and plan. We've done sessions with the team. That work is essential.

But this? This focused time alone, writing by hand, letting thoughts surface without structure - this is where the right questions emerge.

The most valuable meetings don't come from perfect slides. They come from asking the right questions.

Two years ago Bsure went to Silicon Valley through Innovation Norway's TINC program (thank you Ã…se) in the US with an idea of the problem we were solving. It was a crash course in how to build a company, it pushed us to think much bigger, and we did not know it then, but we pitched to the firm that we today welcome as our newest investor, Scale Capital.

At the time Bsure was mainly about saving money on unused Microsoft licenses. Along the way it has become clear that the real problem was much bigger, too many identities, too many permissions, and not enough visibility, especially around inactive and forgotten accounts. Today Bsure helps organisations close that visibility gap at scale, and the challenge is highlighted as one of the main areas to focus on in cybersecurity by Microsoft and highlighted in Gartnerâ€™s Identity Hype Cycle as an emerging area.Â For most customers, the total cost of using Bsure actually ends up being lower than doing nothing, because cleaning up unused identities also removes unnecessary licenses and software spend. Quite nice, right!

Since our last raise last summer, Bsure has grown to more than 200 customers across nine countries. With this new round, led by Scale Capital together with our existing investors, we will accelerate product development, grow the team and continue our international expansion. We are grateful to bring in an experienced investor such as Scale Capital, and excited to have them on board for this next phase. We now have a clear direction for where we are going, and we are focused on delivering even more value to our customers in the months ahead.

ğŸ‘€ Something new is coming to Ploy ğŸ‘€

Most access reviews fail before they even start.

Not because people donâ€™t careâ€¦â€¦but because reviewers are asked to make decisions with no context.

You get a list of users. Some role names. Maybe an â€œaccess levelâ€ if youâ€™re lucky. 

And then the system expects you to magically know who should keep what.

So people guess. Or approve everything. Or spend hours chasing the information they need.

This is the part of identity governance no one talks about â€” the bit thatâ€™s meant to keep you safe, but often turns into an admin chore that achieves nothing.

This is exactly where Luna steps in.

In Ploy , access reviews arenâ€™t just lists.Theyâ€™re AI-generated decisions with the context you wish you always had:

ğŸŸ¢ Who actually needs the access (based on role, function, and historical patterns)
ğŸ”´ Who shouldnâ€™t have it (department misalignment, unused accounts, over-privilege)
âŒ Terminated employees with lingering access
ğŸ“‰ Accounts with no usage â€” even in engineering tools
ğŸ“Œ A clear explanation of why Luna recommends each action

And instead of forcing reviewers into a black-and-white approve/reject workflow, Luna frames each group the way humans actually think.

It turns a painful, time-consuming process into something reviewers can complete quickly and confidently â€” because they finally have the context to make real decisions.

It was great to read about the UK government's new "first-customer" pledge to buy British AI inference chips as a sign of support for UK AI hardware innovation ğŸ‡¬ğŸ‡§ in the Financial Times this morning. 

But the headline figure of Â£100 million (which the minister herself calls â€œsmall compared to the billions being spent in the US and Chinaâ€) still sends a risk-message: that this is a nice gesture rather than a full-scale bet.

In my view, there are a few important next steps:

1ï¸âƒ£ The UK needs to show itâ€™s happy to bet broadly on all forms of AI innovation, not just hardware. The ecosystem spans software, data pipelines, infrastructure, services, models and hardware.

2ï¸âƒ£ Public procurement needs to become more streamlined, predictable and start-up friendly. At the UK Cyber Flywheel event this theme came up repeatedly! (shoutout to Alastair Paterson for hosting this). Government must act as a modern buyer of tech and not a slow legacy purchaser that select incumbent safety nets over innovation.

3ï¸âƒ£ The message matters. Saying â€œweâ€™re showing leadershipâ€ is fine, but if the backing remains modest, investors and founders might read it as â€œweâ€™ll do something, but itâ€™s not urgentâ€.

ğŸ‘Š This is a good signal, an okay start - but we need to do more to be able to compete on a Global scale and for the UK to truly become a destination of choice for AI innovation. 

If we want to lead the world in AI-enabled sectors like life sciences, financial services and cybersecurity, then the government needs to do more.
